this study is dedicated to the wind waves parameters distribution on the black sea with a focus on coastal areas wind waves were simulated using the swan model forced by the ncep cfsr and ncep cfsv2 reanalyses for the period 1979 2016 an unstructured computational grid with resolution varying between 15 km and 200 m was applied modelling results were validated against in situ and remote sensing data for the entire sea distributions of total and seasonal maxima of wave parameters are analyzed maximal significant wave heights exceed 8 5 m and are found in the southwestern areas of the sea maximal wave lengths over 160 m and periods over 10 5 s are located in the eastern part of the sea total and seasonal time series extracted for 12 locations along the coasts of the black sea were studied maximal values of significant wave heights over 6 m correspond to areas along the northeastern and southwestern coasts of the black sea and the southern coast of the crimean peninsula maximal values of wave lengths and wave periods over 140 m and 10 s are located along the northeastern and southern coasts of the black sea nomenclature adcp acoustic doppler current profiler cfsr climate forecast system reanalysis cfsv2 climate forecast system version 2 dhi danish hydration institute gebco general bathymetric chart of the oceans jonswap joint north sea wave atmosphere program mae mean average error mm5 mesoscale model 5 ncar national center for atmospheric research ncep national centers for environmental prediction noaa national oceanic and atmospheric administration rads radar altimeter database system rfbr russian foundation for basic research rmse root mean square error saral satellite with argos and altika si scatter index swan simulating waves nearshore swh significant wave height wam wave model wl wave length wp wave period wrf weather research and forecasting wrf arw advanced research version of wrf 1 introduction wind waves are probably the most evident manifestation of the ocean atmosphere interaction being a mean to transfer energy from the wind to the water surface they significantly influence the state of the upper ocean layer leading to intensified vertical mixing and modifying other physical fields such as currents surface roughness and albedo in nearshore areas wind waves also interact with the topography resulting in the shoreline changes sediment transport and rip currents extreme wind waves occurring during storms can cause significant damage to coastal and offshore engineering structures such as drilling platforms masts pipelines piers berths and beaches moreover such catastrophic events may lead to shipwrecks resulting in pollution of surrounding waters and coastal areas and elimination of seaweed fish marine mammals and birds the black sea is an enclosed sea and has minimal interaction with the world ocean via the bosphorus strait moreover it has a remarkable significance for the economic activity of the riparian countries russia s most significant port in terms of freight turnover novorossijsk is located in the northeastern part of the black sea other significant ports of the black sea are tuapse and taman in russia odesa in ukraine constanța in romania varna and burgas in bulgaria samsun and filyos in turkey batumi in georgia these ports produce intense ship traffic between themselves as well as between them and the other parts of the world ocean via the bosphorus strait besides since hydrocarbon petroleum fields were found several offshore drilling platforms are present e g karkinit platform to the west of the crimean peninsula or gloria platform off the romanian coast three underwater gas pipelines are located on the bottom of the black sea first the blue stream pipeline connects the terminals in arkhipo osipovka russia and dursu turkey second a pipeline goes along the russian coast between dzhubga and sochi finally the turkstream pipeline was recently launched connecting the terminals located in the vicinity of anapa russia and kiyiköy turkey last but not least the black sea s coasts are a popular tourist destination the most remarkable resort areas are located e g close to anapa gelendzhik and sochi in russia batumi in georgia and varna in bulgaria therefore information on wind waves in the black sea in general and its coastal areas in particular is of high importance and interest for science industry and society following these needs numerous studies of this phenomenon were implemented during recent years the majority of them were carried out using numerical modelling based on meteorological reanalyses since they are found to be a modern reliable and adequate method akpınar et al 2012 akpinar and de león 2016 rusu 2016 research dealing with wind waves in the black sea is usually devoted to the peculiarities of waves and wind distribution in the entire sea their results are mainly focused on the spatial distribution of average and extreme wave parameters and its temporal variability various methods and materials are applied during such studies for example arkhipkin et al 2014 obtained a database of the wind wave parameters using the numerical model swan booij et al 1999 ris et al 1999 which was forced by wind data from the ncep ncar reanalysis kalnay et al 1996 for the period between 1949 and 2010 the model output was validated against satellite altimetry data kovzova et al 2006 used the same reanalysis to create a handbook on wind and wave parameters for the entire black sea this modelling was performed on a rectangular computational grid the black sea was divided into five regions for each region typical values of wind and wave parameters were assessed akpinar et al 2016 also used the swan model but it was run on a finer grid based on the gebco bathymetry the results were validated against in situ buoy measurements divinsky and kosyan 2017 used another model namely the dhi mike 21 sw to calculate wind wave parameters on an unstructured grid forced by the era interim reanalysis for the period from 1979 until 2015 data from multiple sources buoys a moored adcp string recorders and visual observations at offshore platforms and satellite measurements were used for calibration shokurov et al 2016 assessed the quality of results produced by the wam model forced with data from mesoscale atmospheric models mm5 and wrf their study was limited to the southern coastal area of the crimean peninsula wave measurements performed at katziveli were used for validation onea and rusu 2017 performed their study using data on wind waves obtained directly from the era interim reanalysis dee et al 2011 and corresponding to several points located along the perimeter of the black sea a similar approach but applied for the study of wind and wave parameters along shipping routes is used in rusu et al 2018 aydoğan and ayat 2018 focused their study on the spatial distribution of their multiannual trends the spatial variability of long term trends of wave heights in the coastal areas of the black sea was described by akpınar and bingölbali 2016 according to their results these trends are either negligible or weak extreme storm waves their spatial and temporal distribution long term trends and synoptic background are also of high interest several studies focused on the analysis of direct measurements or modelling results in a specific location or area thus bilyay et al 2011 analyzed wave measurements performed for the construction of a port near filyos a town in the southwestern area of the black sea myslenkov et al 2016 analyzed the quality of modelling results obtained during modelling experiments forced with ncep cfsr and wrf arw winds regarding the northeastern part of the black sea surkova et al 2013 polonsky et al 2014 and kislov et al 2016 studied the relationship between the atmospheric circulation patterns and corresponding storm waves valchev et al 2012 zăinescu et al 2017 and galabov et al 2018 examined long term trends of storminess in the western part of the black sea and close to the danube delta as well as their relation to teleconnection patterns in november 2007 a severe storm occurred to the south of the crimean peninsula and close to the kerch strait during this storm several vessels crashed which led to the pollution of marine and coastal environments with oil and other chemical products bukhanovskij et al 2009 studied the meteorological background of this storm while the ecological consequences were discussed in several studies e g matishov et al 2013 among others dan et al 2009 and trifonova et al 2012 described the effects of wind waves on erosion accretion and sediment transport these studies were focused on the danube delta and the western black sea respectively as the coast are strongly affected by wave induced impacts rusu 2009b described a study of the wave current interaction at the danube delta anton et al 2019 performed a case study devoted to the features of waves off the coast of magnalia romania several studies focused on the interaction of waves with artificial objects such as piers and breakwaters e g alekseev et al 2013 an essential application of wind waves is the extraction of wave energy numerical experiments can give comprehensive data for the assessment of wave energy recourses regarding the black sea numerous papers showed results of wave energy resources studies and its possible use rusu 2009a akpınar and kömürcü 2012 akpınar and kömürcü 2013 citiroglu and okur 2014 rusu 2015 akpınar et al 2019 in our study we assess the spatial and seasonal variability of significant wave heights swh wave lengths wl and mean absolute wave period tm02 wp the computations were carried out on an unstructured computational grid with resolution up to 200 m in the coastal areas seasonal and total distributions of maximal and average values of these parameters are assessed over the entire basin twelve key locations in the nearshore areas which as we believe present specific interest for science industry transport and society were selected for a more comprehensive analysis we were motivated by the fact that there are no detailed studies of wind wave statistics along the whole black sea coast based on the swan model and the ncep cfsr reanalysis using a high resolution unstructured computational grid thus bingölbali et al 2019 used a downscaling approach to assess the wind waves statistics but their study area was limited to the southwestern area of the black sea rusu et al 2018 analyzed the wind and wave conditions at locations along the coast of the sea and some offshore points however regarding the waves they evaluated only the swh parameter akpınar and bingölbali 2016 assessed data corresponding to coastal areas but the focus of their study was on long term trends of swh and wind speeds 2 data and methods any study of wind waves carried out using numerical models requires four following components information on wind speed and direction covering the area of interest a computational grid containing information on the water depths a numerical wave model and results of instrumental wave observations to validate the model output in this study we used an unstructured computation grid wind data from the ncep cfsr and ncep cfsv2 reanalyses the swan wave model and three types of wave measurements performed in situ by a laser level sensor a buoy and remote satellite observations we will discuss these data and methods in detail in the following sections 2 1 wind data the numerical experiment was forced with data on the wind speed and direction at 10 m above the sea surface this data was acquired from the ncep cfsr reanalysis saha et al 2010 for the period between 1979 and 2010 and from the ncep cfsv2 reanalysis saha et al 2014 for the period between 2011 and 2016 the timestep of this data is 1 h it has a spatial resolution of 0 3 in both latitudinal and longitudinal direction comparisons of different reanalyses van vledder and akpınar 2015 akpinar and de león 2016 demonstrated that the ncep cfsr reanalysis turned out to be the most preferable one to model extreme wind waves on the black sea among others myslenkov et al 2016 akpınar et al 2016 and bingölbali et al 2019 used this reanalysis to study wind waves in the black sea 2 2 bathymetry and computational grid a specific feature of the black sea is its coastal and bottom topography their comprehensive description can be found in ignatov 2007 we will provide here a brief description of its main characteristics the coastline of the northwestern and northern part of the sea as well as the western crimean coast is generally plain the deltas of major rivers running into the black sea danube dnieper dniester are also located on the northern part of the shoreline the coastline of the southern part of the crimean peninsula as well as the eastern southern and southwestern coasts of the sea are mountainous except the kolkhida lowland in the southeastern part of the black sea the coasts are mostly abrasive in mountainous areas and accumulative in plain and lowland areas the black sea shelf extends till depths of 200 m and has a diverse morphology it is most expressed in the northwestern part of the black sea whereas in many other areas the shelf width does not exceed 10 km the narrowest shelf is observed along the mountainous coasts of the black sea ignatov 2007 subdivides the black sea shelf into 7 regions bulgarian near bosporus northwestern crimean kerch taman caucasian east anatolian and west anatolian the principal characteristics of these areas are given in table 1 the shelf is followed by a relatively steep continental slope and an abyssal plain with maximal depths exceeding 2200 m there are two types of computational grids commonly used in modelling studies of wind waves rectangular and unstructured ones rectangular grids allow to perform faster computations but their resolution is constant therefore detailed data on wave parameters in coastal areas can be acquired either using a single high resolution mesh or using multiple nested meshes both options lead to increasing of computational time another option is to use unstructured triangular computational grids in such grids the density of the nodes can be customized thus one can obtain high resolution results concerning a specific region of interest during a single model run general concepts related to the generation and application of unstructured grids were described by zijlema 2010 dietrich et al 2011 and dietrich et al 2012 in this study we applied an unstructured grid created using the sms aquaveo software the grid is based on digitized nautical maps of the entire black sea and its coastal areas these maps contain isolines corresponding to the shoreline and depths of 5 10 20 50 100 200 300 500 1000 1500 and 2000 m as well as depth values at selected individual locations afterwards the grid itself was created using the paving method the initial distance between the points located along the coast was set to 500 m the grid resolution linearly decreases towards the offshore areas to reach 15 km thus the grid resolution depends only from the offshore distance finally grid nodes were added manually at areas of specific interest increasing the resolution there till 200 m the grid contains 42 284 nodes and 77 036 elements fig 1 the model output grid is equivalent to the computational grid 2 3 model setup in this study we used the third generation swan wind wave model version 41 10 the spectral directional resolution was set to 5 in frequency space there were 38 logarithmically distributed discrete frequencies between 0 03 and 1 hz gen3 mode was applied exponential wave growth was parametrized according to komen et al 1984 bottom friction was described according to the jonswap formulation hasselmann et al 1973 the processes of refraction and diffraction whitecapping quadruplets triad wave interactions and bottom friction were considered the timestep of the computations was 30 min whereas the results were recorded to output files every 3 h the computations were performed continuously for every year to avoid gaps caused by model heat up the computations for each year except for 1979 started at midnight of december 29th of the previous year thus there were 3 days which corresponds to 144 computational time steps for the model to reach adequate performance 2 4 model validation the importance of model validation is crucial since it is the only reliable method to assess the adequacy of the model output and avoid unrealistic results results of trusted instrumental measurements are needed to perform the validation in this study we use various types of such data results of in situ wave measurements in the coastal area of the black sea performed by a laser level sensor and a buoy and remote satellite observations during validation we compared first of all swh values since it is the only parameter available from all four datasets modelling results laser level measurements buoy measurements and satellite altimetry in the case of the buoy measurements we also compared wp and wave directions we will first provide brief technical descriptions of each dataset a discussion on the statistical validation parameters is given afterwards in section 2 4 4 2 4 1 laser level sensor data to assess model performance in shallow water conditions data of instrumental swh measurements carried out in the harbour of novorossijsk port were used for these measurements a riegl ld90 3200hip laser level meter was applied which was mounted at the end of a 1 km long pier the accuracy of the laser level varies between 25 and 75 mm depending on the environmental conditions and its resolution is 2 mm the water depth at the installation point is 20 m the timestep of these measurements was 15 20 min myslenkov and chernyshova 2016 described these measurements in more details measurements corresponding to the model output timestep were extracted from the initial dataset data for the period from 2010 until 2012 was selected for validation which corresponds to 8103 data values the comparison of measured and modelled swh values is shown on a scatter diagram fig 2 and a timeseries plot for the year 2010 fig 3 a trend to underestimate swh values is observed on the scatter diagram however the timeseries show that this trend is mostly due to calmer months between may and september when typical values of measured swh are around 0 5 m and only seldom exceed 1 m it means that the model s uncertainties increase in calmer conditions in other seasons almost all storms are represented adequately by the model 2 4 2 wave buoy data buoy measurements were performed by a datawell wave buoy installed off the city of gelendzhik on the northeastern coast of the black sea the offshore distance of the buoy is 7 km the water depth at the installation point is 85 m the buoy was installed within the nato tu waves project and operated with several interruptions from july 1996 until december 2003 the default timestep of the measurements was 3 h during storms it increased till 1 h 10 126 pairs of measured and modelled significant wave height values were used for validation a detailed description of the applied data is given in bukhanovskij et al 2000 the comparison of these values is illustrated on a scatter diagram fig 4 and a timeseries plot for the year 1997 fig 5 figs 5 and 6 show a quite good agreement between the model and the buoy measurements the modelled significant wave height values may be somewhat lower than the measured ones at the same time all individual storms recorded by the buoy are represented by the model as well besides swh the buoy measures wave periods and directions as well the comparison of modelled and measured wp values is illustrated on a scatter diagram fig 6 and a timeseries plot for the year 1997 fig 7 these figures show a quite good agreement between the wp values obtained during instrumental measurements and modelling experiments the model seems to slightly underestimate wp between may and september more detailed parameters of the wp validation will be given in section 2 4 4 fig 8 shows the comparison of wave directions measured by the buoy and calculated by the model no systematical shifts can be noted regarding the comparison however a higher variance is observed in case of buoy data especially during the stormy months between october and january 2 4 3 satellite altimeter data data obtained with the altika altimeter installed on the saral satellite steunou et al 2015 was used as another source to validate the modelling results as shown by previous studies the data quality of this altimeter is better if compared to similar results acquired by e g envisat or jason 1 and jason 2 satellites janssen et al 2007 jayaram et al 2015 compared data on wave height and wind speed obtained with the altika altimeter with buoys and concluded that for the wave heights the standard deviation is 0 21 m and the bias is 0 04 m for the wind speed these values are 1 75 m s and 0 25 m s respectively altimeter data on the significant wave height have an approximately 7 km spatial resolution and are available via the rads http rads tudelft nl rads rads shtml data corresponding to the period from march 15th 2013 until december 31st 2016 was used for validation according to the principles described by abdalla et al 2011 the following data was rejected from the validation process values with a standard deviation of the altimeter significant wave height exceeding 0 4 m values with swh lower than 0 3 m values with distance to the shore closer than 10 km moreover significant wave heights from the altimeter were compared with modelling results for grid points located not more than 8 km and 1 h from the place and time the satellite observation was made thus 61 289 data pairs were selected for validation figs 9 and 10 fig 10 shows a good agreement between measured and modelled significant wave height values the linear approximation in this case is similar to the one obtained for in situ buoy observations 2 4 4 seasonal variability in the validation parameters for comparisons against each data set following statistical parameters were calculated the bias b i a s 1 n i 1 n m o d i o b s i the mean absolute error m a e 1 n i 1 n m o d i o b s i the root mean square error r m s e 1 n i 1 n m o d i o b s i 2 the scatter index s i r m s e 1 2 i 1 n m o d i o b s i the correlation coefficient r 1 n 1 i 1 n m o d i m o d σ m o d o b s i o b s σ o b s where mod and obs are the modelled and observed swh or wp values σ m o d and σ o b s are their standard deviations respectively these parameters were calculated for the entire available datasets and each month separately their seasonal variability is shown on figs 11 and 12 their monthly averaged and total values are also given in appendix a table a 1 and a 2 regarding swh values the following features can be observed on fig 11 and table a 1 the correlation coefficient r is commonly higher if we compare modelled data against satellite measurements this seems to happen because the volume of satellite data is approx 6 8 times larger than the volume of each other dataset moreover satellite data are located all across the black sea and not in a single point next to its coast monthly r values vary from 0 77 in may to 0 89 in september on the other hand r values corresponding to buoy and laser level measurements have a well pronounced intra annual variability thus r for laser level measurements varies from 0 39 in july to 0 86 in november the same values for buoy measurements vary from 0 51 in august to 0 80 in april and 0 81 in june overall larger r of in situ measurements is observed from october until april whereas in late spring summer and early autumn their values tend to decrease the si for satellite data which varies from 0 32 to 0 38 is lower than this index for in situ measurements for all months moreover highest si values calculated using the in situ data up to 0 76 m for the case of laser level are observed between july and september at the same time when minimal r values were found the differences in the bias mae and rmse calculated for various data sources are not that expressed as in the case of r and si average monthly bias values are always below 0 which means that modelling results systematically underestimate observations some conclusions can be made from the above described results the general slight underestimation of modelled swh which is most pronounced when comparing modelling results with satellite measurements can be explained by a certain underestimation of the wind speed by the reanalysis itself it is a common problem reported within others by akpınar et al 2012 and arkhipkin et al 2014 furthermore the reanalysis often does not represent adequately enough local wind effects caused by orography such as mountain valley circulations and bora winds this issue is best observed in the comparison of modelled results with in situ nearshore measurements especially the laser level thus in summer the mean monthly bias and r values are minimal because local winds mainly govern the wave generation in this season myslenkov and chernyshova 2016 showed that these calm months contribute significantly to the weak correlation in other seasons higher swh values in the region where in situ observations were carried out may be caused not only by the prevailing atmospheric circulation but also by strong bora winds alpers et al 2011 gavrikov and ivanov 2015 such winds are not always represented by the reanalysis but can generate waves with swh up to 2 5 m toropov et al 2012 in case of the wave periods no seasonal variability of r can be found its values vary between 0 6 in august and 0 84 in february the only parameter with an expressed intra annual variability is the bias which drops to values below 0 4 s in the period between may and september in contrast in other months it varies between 0 21 and 0 10 s it is due to the already mentioned underestimation of wp values during the warm season finally we can compare our validation parameters with those obtained in some other similar research for example divinsky and kosyan 2017 also used an unstructured computational grid and validated their model output using several data sources in situ adcp measurements wave buoys string wave recorders and satellite altimetry akpınar and bingölbali 2016 in their study used the same model and wind forcing as we did our validation parameters generally agree with those published in the mentioned studies 3 results and discussion 3 1 offshore areas to demonstrate some features of the wind wave climate of the entire black sea we will describe the distribution of total and seasonal 1 1 in this paper seasons are defined as follows winter december january and february spring march april and may summer june july and august autumn september october and november swh wl and wp maxima and means produced by the model figs 13 15 shows the distribution of annual maxima according to our results the highest swh in the black sea are observed in the southwestern area of the sea where they exceed 8 5 m two other areas with swh exceeding 8 m are found one spreading from the southeastern coasts of the crimean peninsula towards the northeastern coast of the sea between anapa and novorossijsk in russia and another located in the southeastern part of the sea maximal swh decrease around the coasts of the sea and in its shallow northwestern area the distributions of annual wl and wp maxima look quite similar moreover areas with wl and wp maxima in general coincide with those where swh maxima are observed wl and wp maxima are found in the southeastern part of the sea and a relatively narrow area adjacent to its southwestern coast to the east of the bosphorus wl maxima in these areas exceed 160 and 150 m respectively wp maxima 10 5 s typical values of wl and wp maxima on the remaining areas of the sea vary between 80 and 140 m and 8 10 s respectively the seasonal variability of swh wl and wp maxima can be seen on figs 16 18 absolute swh maxima correspond to winter in this season they exceed 8 5 m in the southwestern part of the sea close to the bosphorus at the same time another area with swh maxima is observed in the eastern part of the sea where this parameter exceeds 8 0 m both these areas are observed in the total distribution of the swh maxima as well in spring swh maxima slightly decrease and do not exceed 7 5 m another clearly expressed area with swh maxima appears close to the southwestern coast of the crimean peninsula in summer the storminess is weaker therefore swh maxima in this season are the lowest compared to other seasons they exceed 6 m only in several compact areas in the southwestern part of the sea on the bigger part of the remaining black sea swh maxima in summer are below 5 0 m finally in autumn storminess intensifies and swh maxima exceed 8 0 m again however in this season the area with such values spreads along the southern coasts of the crimean and taman peninsulas which makes a difference between the distribution of this parameter in winter and autumn wl maxima are observed in autumn in the southeastern part of the black sea fig 17d they exceed 160 m in this case in other seasons higher values of wl maxima are observed in winter and spring when they may be over 150 m long such wl maxima correspond to areas in the southwest and southeast of the sea in winter and in the southeast only in spring in summer wl maxima do not exceed 130 m the spatial distribution of wp maxima in all seasons is similar to that of the wl maxima fig 18 the most pronounced area with highest wp is observed in the southeastern part of the sea in autumn in this case wp maxima exceed 10 5 s in winter and spring wp maxima are usually somewhat lower between 10 0 and 10 5 s finally in summer wp maxima do not exceed 9 5 s except a compact area close to the eastern shore of the black sea the distributions of annual swh wl and wp means are shown on figs 19 21 annual swh means do not exceed 1 1 m and their highest values are found in the southwestern part of the black sea it means that this region is generally more affected by higher waves a finding shown earlier by arkhipkin et al 2014 in terms of the total duration of waves with swh exceeding 4 m on the bigger part of the remaining black sea annual swh means are between 0 8 and 1 0 m lower annual swh means correspond to southeastern and northwestern marginal areas of the sea generally annual swh means decrease towards the coasts regarding the nearshore areas highest swh means correspond to the southwestern coasts of the sea as well as to some areas on the western and southern coast the spatial pattern of annual wl and wp means distribution is quite similar figs 20 and 21 these parameters increase southwards and reach their highest values along the southeastern coast of the black sea in these areas wl and wp means exceed 22 m and 4 0 s correspondingly in the central areas of the sea annual wl and wp means are somewhat lower 18 22 m and 3 6 4 0 s correspondingly a decrease of these parameters is best observed in the shallow northwestern area of the black sea where minimal annual wl and wp means are observed below 8 m and 2 8 s correspondingly unlike the case of swh maxima the spatial pattern of mean swh distribution remains nearly the same in all seasons fig 22 the most expressed swh means are found in the southwestern part of the black sea with values ranging from 1 3 to 1 4 m in winter till 0 7 0 8 in summer consequently the highest swh averages in the nearshore areas correspond to winter in this season average swh exceed 1 0 m along the southwestern western and northeastern coasts of the sea the increase of average swh from the shoreline towards the high seas is most expressed in winter along the northwestern western and southwestern coasts of the black sea regarding the wl and wp means their highest values are also observed in winter figs 23 and 24 on the bigger part of the sea they exceed 26 m and 4 4 s but their highest values correspond to a compact area located to the northwest of sinop where they exceed 28 m and 4 6 s lowest wl and wp means in winter correspond to the northwestern part of the black sea where their values are below 12 m and 3 2 s respectively this spatial pattern remains nearly unchanged in spring and autumn but the highest values decrease till 20 22 m and 24 26 s in spring in summer average wl and wp are minimal and exceed 16 m and 3 6 s along the southern coasts of the sea 3 2 coastal areas an advantage of the unstructured computational grid used in this study is the possibility to obtain high definition data for the coastal areas in this section we will describe the results based on analysis of timeseries of wind wave parameters for 12 points located in the coastal areas of the black sea the kerch strait gelendzhik sochi hopa giresun sinop zonguldak bosphorus galata gloria the karkinit platform and katziveli fig 25 table 2 these points were selected because they are of high interest for scientific or industrial purposes thus long time wave observations were carried out at sinop hopa gelendzhik katziveli the karkinit platform and gloria within the nato tu waves project furthermore scientific investigations in the nearshore areas are continuously carried out by research institutions located at gelendzhik katziveli and galata several other locations have an expressed transportation significance since they are located close to ports e g sochi giresun and sinop and on intense shipping routes bosphorus and kerch strait a similar criterion for selecting research locations was used by rusu et al 2018 at these points data from a grid node located 2 6 km offshore was selected for further analysis such a distance was selected to take into account the wave energy generated by winds blowing from the shore if they occur and are represented by the reanalysis an exception was made for the stations corresponding to kerch strait karkinit platform gloria and galata despite these 4 stations are located rather far away offshore 14 50 km their wave conditions still may be affected by relatively small depths 22 43 m generally the water depth at selected locations varies from 22 to 97 m examples of model performance in nearshore areas can be observed on figs 26 and 27 which show the distribution of maximal wave parameters around the points in kerch strait and gelendzhik the plotted fields are smooth and have no outbursts data corresponding to the selected locations adequately represents the wave parameters in the adjacent areas moreover the interaction of wave fields with the complex coastal shoreline e g in the entrance of the kerch strait and bays located in novorossijsk and gelendzhik is observed as well however such maps are not the best way to represent long term data series corresponding to a single location therefore in order to describe the typical wave climate features in these points we will discuss the wave roses which show the joint distribution of swh and wave direction and box and whisker diagrams of swh wl and wp designed for the entire dataset and each of the seasons the distribution of the predominant wave directions shown on fig 28 is usually defined by the location of the study point relatively to the shoreline at several points which are located closer to the shoreline or at relatively small depths the bigger part of waves comes from directions perpendicular the coast or close to such directions which may be caused by refraction and predominant winds this is best observed in cases of bosphorus fig 28 a galata fig 28 b and giresun fig 28 d thus in bosphorus 34 7 of the waves correspond to the ne direction 23 3 correspond to nne and 16 9 correspond to ene which gives nearly 75 altogether in galata the parts of waves coming from e and ene are nearly equal 21 9 and 22 0 correspondingly beside them remarkable are ese ne and se directions each having 10 9 11 8 of waves in giresun most expressed are the nnw 30 5 and nw 27 5 directions all other have less than 15 of waves the diversity of wave directions is minimal in hopa fig 28 f where 53 9 of waves correspond to wnw 19 3 to nw and 10 7 to w making 83 9 altogether this can be explained by constant winds blowing from the seaside at this point furthermore the wind patterns here are governed by the orographic conditions the coast is surrounded by mountains which block winds blowing from the shore on the other hand wave directions are most diverse at points located further away from the coast such are gloria fig 28 e and the karkinit platform fig 28 g thus in gloria there are three predominant wave directions s 12 9 ene 12 6 and ne 12 0 altogether they constitute only 37 5 of waves the remaining part is distributed among other directions at the karkinit platform the predominant directions are sw 11 8 ssw 10 5 and ene 8 3 the least amount of waves come from se 2 2 due to the fine resolution of the computational grid and the reanalysis quality it is sometimes possible to reproduce typical wave features caused by local winds this is most evident in the case of gelendzhik fig 28 c where a local peak corresponding to ne and ene is observed 9 7 of waves there come from these directions this is the effect of the bora a strong cold katabatic wind typical for the northeastern coastal areas of the black sea especially for the shoreline between novorossijsk and gelendzhik such winds usually occur during autumn and winter if they are associated with negative air temperatures they can lead to ice accretion on vessels and coastal constructions which is the most dangerous consequence of the bora gavrikov and ivanov 2015 a detailed numerical study of such winds and associated waves was performed by toropov et al 2012 at several points which are located close to the shoreline there are two expressed peaks in the distribution of wave directions thus in katziveli fig 28 h at the very south of the crimean peninsula 23 8 of waves come from e and 25 3 from wsw and w only 13 4 of waves come from sse s and ssw which are the directions relatively perpendicular to the coastline this can be due to the fact that waves here are generated by winds blowing along the coastline and that the effects of refraction are still not fully displayed because of the considerable depth 61 m a similar effect is observed at sochi fig 28 k where 22 2 of waves come from sse 23 7 from w and 17 1 from wsw the distribution of swh wl and wp and their seasonal variability is better observed on the box and whisker plots 2 2 box and whisker plots for this study were designed in the following way the lower and upper limits of the boxes represent the 25 and 75 percentile of the data correspondingly the lines inside the boxes indicate the median 50 percentile of the data the lower and upper whiskers represent the 5 and 95 percentiles correspondingly the dots indicate individual data values lying beyond the 5 95 percentiles interval fig 29 shows such a plot for all values of the swh without seasonality swh maxima exceed 6 m at six studied locations gelendzhik 6 7 m kerch strait 6 9 m katziveli 7 1 m karkinit platform 6 6 m bosphorus 7 1 m and sinop 6 3 m which corresponds to the swh maxima pattern shown on fig 13 at other locations swh maxima are between 4 7 m at sochi and 5 5 m at zonguldak the 95th percentile of swh exceeds 2 m only at bosphorus 2 1 m at other points this value is below 2 m with a minimal record at giresun 1 4 m a remarkable feature is that despite equal swh maxima are observed at katziveli and bosphorus 7 1 m in both cases the 95th percentiles values are significantly different 2 1 m at bosphorus and 1 7 at katziveli this demonstrates that higher waves are more frequent at bosphorus and in the surrounding area of the black sea which was demonstrated earlier by arkhipkin et al 2014 the seasonal swh variability at the study points can be observed on fig 30 highest swh values are achieved in winter and autumn in winter storminess in terms of maximal significant wave heights and their 95th percentile is slightly higher in the southwestern and southern areas of the black sea thus at bosphorus the highest swh value and their 95th percentile are 7 1 and 2 8 m and in sinop 6 3 and 2 4 m correspondingly on the other hand in autumn highest swh values correspond to points located in the northern and northeastern parts of the sea gelendzhik kerch strait katziveli and karkinit platform however highest 95th percentile values are found at points located mainly in other regions of the sea bosphorus 2 2 m sinop 2 0 m karkinit 2 0 m and gloria 2 0 m summer is the calmest season on the black sea swh maxima exceed 4 m only at four points bosphorus 5 7 m sinop 5 2 m katziveli 4 2 m and zonguldak 4 0 m lowest swh maxima are located along the western coast of the black sea these values in gloria and galata are 2 7 and 2 6 m correspondingly the swh maxima in sochi is somewhat lower 2 5 m however in terms of the 95th percentile calmest is the northern and northeastern area of the sea where the 95th percentile is below 1 m e g at sochi 0 8 m gelendzhik 0 9 m and katziveli 0 9 m the total distribution of the wl values is shown on fig 31 wl maxima correspond to hopa 154 m sochi 150 m gelendzhik 145 m and bosphorus 143 m the 95th percentiles are highest along the southern coast of the black sea at bosphorus 56 7 m zonguldak 57 3 m sinop 51 6 m and giresun 52 0 m and on the northeastern coast in gelendzhik 51 1 m on the other hand in terms of wl maxima and their 95th percentile the waves are shortest in the northwestern area of the sea and along its western coast thus at the karkinit platform the maximal wave length is 102 4 m and the 95th percentile is 35 9 m at gloria these values are 109 4 m and 41 5 m at galata 109 2 m and 41 1 m correspondingly such a difference may be caused by the considerable fetch length which reaches the southern and eastern coasts of the black sea on the one hand and relatively small depths of the northwestern black sea shelf on the other the seasonal distribution of wl is shown on fig 32 a significant decrease is observed in summer in this season highest wl values are observed along the eastern and southeastern coasts of the black sea in sochi 119 4 m hopa 117 5 m and giresun 112 8 m the 95th percentile of wave lengths in summer is below 40 m at all stations except zonguldak 41 1 m moreover kerch strait is the only location where this parameter is below 20 m 18 5 m the distribution of wp is relatively uniform along the coasts of the black sea fig 33 wp maxima are between 9 0 s in gloria and 10 7 s in sochi the 95th percentile of wave periods is higher along the southern coasts of the sea where it is between 6 5 s at bosphorus and 6 1 s in hopa the minimal value of the 95th percentile of wp corresponds to the karkinit platform 5 2 s similar to the case of significant wave heights and wave lengths wave periods are lower in summer and higher in winter and autumn fig 34 thus in summer maximal wave periods do not exceed 10 s and their 95th percentile is between 4 s and 6 s at all stations except kerch strait 5 5 s an increase of median wp values relative to other regions is observed at points corresponding to the southern coast of the sea bosphorus zonguldak sinop and giresun this tendency is most evident in summer and autumn and it agrees with the location of highest wp means along this part of the shoreline compare with figs 21 and 24 4 conclusions this study shows the results of a 38 years long wind wave hindcast covering the period from 1979 until 2016 for the black sea which was carried out using the swan wind wave model an original unstructured computational grid and ncep cfsr and ncep cfsv2 wind data as forcing modelling results were validated against wave buoy measurements and remote satellite observations both comparisons showed satisfactory results typical values of the average monthly bias were between 0 and 0 2 m of the correlation coefficient between 0 8 and 0 9 to show the features of the wave climate for the entire black sea we have described spatial distributions of annual and seasonal swh wl and wp maxima and means maximal values of significant wave heights exceed 8 5 m and correspond to the southwestern area of the black sea areas with maximal wave lengths and periods are located in the eastern part of the sea these values there exceed 160 m and 10 5 s correspondingly annual swh means exceed 1 m in the southwestern area of the sea while annual wl and wp means reach 24 m and 4 2 s in areas along the southern coast of the black sea generally such spatial patterns match well with previous results obtained in similar studies e g by rusu et al 2018 and akpınar and bingölbali 2016 to assess the features of wind wave climate in the coastal areas total and seasonal timeseries corresponding to 12 points located along the coasts of the black sea were studied maximal values of significant wave heights over 6 m correspond to areas along the northeastern and southwestern coasts of the black sea and the southern coast of the crimean peninsula maximal values of wave lengths and wave periods over 140 m and 10 s correspondingly are located along the northeastern and southern coasts of the black sea the data described in this paper are expected to be the autonomy of any airborne land borne or waterborne vehicle starts with controlling its speed to achieve cruise speed control the conventional approach is to use closed loop feedback control systems that require high precision sensors underwater sensors are expensive due to harsh environment and corrosive properties of seawater in this study we propose a speed control system for autonomous underwater vehicles auvs that closes the control loop via a feedforward mechanism eliminating the need for these expensive sensors the feedforward control is based on the recently developed self propulsion estimation model which can accurately predict propeller rotation rate for conventional auv forms the model is first validated by comparing the predicted resistance and propeller rotation rate of darpa suboff with the experimental and numerical results published in the literature after observing a good match the feedforward control system is used to ensure that the auv reaches a predetermined surge speed two different underwater vehicles are considered in presenting the results of this study the darpa suboff and the gavia auv which has real time measurements available in the literature the feedforward control system developed in this study achieves the desired speed with negligible errors transient response analysis shows that the computer simulation results are in good agreement with experimental results for the gavia auv keywords auv motion control cruise control self propulsion hull propeller interaction darpa suboff gavia auv 1 introduction as autonomous water vehicles increasingly occupy the world s maritime agenda nowadays marine and control engineers work together to develop and enhance control systems to increase the robustness of these marine vehicles although airborne drones have found extensive use in our daily lives it is not possible to make similar statements for waterborne drones recently there has been a surge of interest in utilizing autonomous underwater vehicles auvs to study the underwater environment combined with high precision sensors and robust control systems these underwater vehicles provide us with considerable capabilities to discover the seas as the autonomy levels of underwater vehicles increase so do our capabilities to work in the marine field an intelligent underwater vehicle shall first meet the fundamental requirement of floating in water therefore most studies concerning auvs focus on keeping the depth of the vehicle at a desirable and constant level to achieve this auvs need to reach a minimum speed due to the hydrodynamic properties of these types of water vehicles nickell and woolsey 2005 auvs are generally positively buoyant and to keep their depth at desired levels they are required to cruise with a certain speed the reference eng et al 2016 presents a novel algorithm to keep a given auv at a minimum speed so that it maintains a constant depth the algorithm regulates the cruising speed at a minimum level to keep the desired depth and is experimentally verified with starfish auv an underwater vehicle developed by the national university of singapore chitre 2008 the paper tanakitkorn et al 2017 studies the energy consumption of delphin2 auv on board and considers the impact of net positive buoyancy on the control performance the authors focus on the vertical motions of the vehicle so that it has three degrees of freedom and use a proportional integral derivative pid based diving control system the authors in yu et al 2018 also consider speed depth relationship of auvs and describe a unified control architecture for variable speed following missions the authors claim that the controller guarantees smooth speed switching in the entire speed profile controlling an underwater vehicle s speed is important to fulfill its tasks an example of such tasks can be found in mallios et al 2016 where auvs are utilized in mapping underwater caves surfaces it is shown that the mapping quality obtained by the vehicle depends on the estimation of its trajectory and speed due to high sensitivity of speed estimation in such tasks there is a considerable ongoing research on velocity measurements with different techniques the reference rui fang et al 2011 states that convenient methods to measure velocity are limited by external disturbances in the oceans the authors propose a velocity measurement based on geomagnetic data to increase precision besides the high precision measurements of the vehicle speed motional aspects of the vehicle should also be considered fast vehicle response is one of the desired capabilities an auv is expected to possess so that it can reach the desired speed as quickly as possible continuous interference to propeller rotation increases fuel consumption and delays the vehicle response in catching the desired speed speed control using feedback control systems usually results in an oscillatory behavior due to consistent changes in the propeller rotation rate reducing the economic life of the auv as well as increasing the cost of transportation this study focuses on the stabilization of the auv to a given target velocity unlike the conventional closed loop systems using feedback from sensors this study uses a feedforward mechanism that can accurately predict the propeller rotation rate with respect to the target velocity two different underwater vehicles are considered in this study the darpa suboff and the gavia auv the latter having real time measurements available in the literature the controller is based on a novel self propulsion estimation model published recently in the literature by the first author of this study kinaci et al 2020 the self propulsion estimation model can predict the propeller rotation rate for any target auv velocity section 2 presents the iterative nature of the self propulsion estimation model and its minimum requirements prior to the implementation of the model it is first tested in various cases to see its predictions versus real measurements and numerical simulations section 3 is devoted to the validation of the self propulsion estimation model the total resistance of the darpa suboff and its propeller rotation rate are predicted by the model and compared with the experimental and cfd computational fluid dynamics based results section 4 presents the simulation conditions and the feedforward control mechanism adopted to the control of vehicle speed computer simulation results are given in section 5 finally the conclusions are presented in section 6 2 self propulsion estimation model the self propulsion estimation model employed in this study can also be found in kinaci et al 2018 gokce et al 2019 and kinaci et al 2020 we describe an iterative process with the following inputs for the feedforward speed estimation of interest to be formally defined in section 4 i bare hull resistance r t resistance of the vehicle in a range of given speeds excluding the propeller is needed this is conventionally obtained by towing tank experiments or cfd application ii open water propeller performance diagram hydrodynamic performance diagram of the propeller should be given as an input which also includes the propeller s thrust with respect to its advance coefficient coefficient values of k 0 k 1 and k 2 are extracted from the thrust curves by fitting a second order equation iii wake fraction w the underwater vehicle changes the flow received by the propeller the effect of the vehicle on the propeller is reflected on the hydrodynamic performance of the propeller by wake fraction w iv thrust deduction factor t a running propeller increases the total resistance of the ship this effect of the propeller on vehicle resistance is reflected on the vehicle propeller system by thrust deduction factor t details of the aforementioned self propulsion estimation parameters and their practical algebraic derivations are presented in the following sections the flow diagram of the propeller rotation rate calculation for the self propulsion estimation model can be seen in fig 1 2 1 water resistance for underwater vehicles water resistance for underwater vehicles is based on hughes decomposition of total ship resistance molland 2011 the vehicle body resistance r t is given by 1 r t r f r v p r w where r f is the frictional resistance r v p is the viscous pressure resistance and r w is the wave resistance resistance components can be defined by morison s equation written as 2 r x 1 2 ρ s v 2 c x in this equation r x denotes resistance and c x resistance coefficient where x stands for t f v p or w indicating total frictional viscous pressure and wave resistances respectively ρ is the density of the fluid s is the wetted area of the underwater vehicle body and v is the underwater vehicle velocity procedures and guidelines by the international towing tank conference ittc recommend the following model vehicle correlation line for frictional resistance coefficient ittc 2017 3 c f 0 075 log r e 2 2 r e denotes the reynolds number given by 4 r e ρ v l μ where l is the underwater vehicle length and μ is the dynamic viscosity of the fluid after determining the frictional resistance coefficient using equation 3 frictional resistance r f can be calculated by equation 2 viscous pressure resistance r v p can be related to frictional resistance using form factor ittc 2017 denoted by k as 5 r v p k r f the form factor of an underwater vehicle is generally based on its block coefficient and length to breadth ratio in the case that experiments are not available the form factor can be found by the relation 6 k 32 8 c b l d s 2 0 03 here d s is the diameter of the underwater body and c b is its block coefficient which can be calculated by 7 c b 4 π d s 2 l where is the displacement of the underwater vehicle equation 6 is originally given for surface ships ittc 1975 and here it is simplified for a cylindrical underwater body underwater vehicles operate far from the free surface boundary and therefore it can generally be assumed that they are not generating waves in this case wave resistance can be neglected i e 8 r w 0 2 2 propeller thrust a conventional fixed pitch propeller thrust t can be calculated by the following equation 9 t k t ρ n 2 d 4 where n is the propeller rotation rate per second d is the propeller diameter and k t is the thrust coefficient propeller performance is assessed in open water propeller tests where the thrust torque and open water efficiency can be graphed with respect to its advance coefficient j given by 10 j v a n d where v a denotes the flow velocity that the propeller receives v a is different than the underwater vehicle speed v because the underwater vehicle disturbs the flow coming to the propeller these two speeds can be related via the wake fraction denoted by w and v a can be calculated by the equation 11 v a v 1 w calculation of v a makes it possible to compute the advance coefficient j by equation 10 the propeller performance can be found for a given range usually 0 1 j 1 2 either by experiments or numerical simulations after determining the advance coefficient j of the propeller the corresponding thrust coefficient k t the torque coefficient k q and the propeller efficiency η 0 can be read from propeller performance diagrams the thrust and torque identities may be used when finding the speed of an underwater vehicle in our case we will go with the thrust identity case and thus only k t will be required a second order equation to the thrust coefficient curve is fitted by the least squares method described in appendix 1 12 k t k 0 k 1 j k 2 j 2 the coefficients k 0 k 1 and k 2 will be used in this study to represent the propeller in estimating the underwater vehicle speed the steps of the flow diagram given in fig 1 are listed below for better assessment of the self propulsion estimation model s1 wake fraction w is considered as an initial input of the iteration v a is calculated for the underwater vehicle of interest using equation 11 s2 select an arbitrary propeller rotation rate n as an initial value for the propeller rotation rate s3 we know the propeller diameter d from its geometry using v a obtained in step s1 calculate the advance coefficient j using equation 10 s4 using open water propeller performance diagram curve fit the open water propeller thrust coefficient to obtain k 0 k 1 and k 2 s5 using j obtained in step s3 and k 0 k 1 k 2 in step s4 calculate the thrust coefficient k t by equation 12 s6 using the fluid density ρ propeller diameter d propeller rotation rate selected in step s2 and thrust coefficient k t obtained in step s5 calculate the thrust t by equation 9 s7 thrust deduction factor t and bare hull resistance r t are given as inputs check if r t t 1 t is satisfied by using the thrust t calculated in step s6 as it can be seen from the flowchart in fig 1 and the detailed definitions of steps given s1 s7 the high fidelity model behavior is derived by means of sole underwater vehicle and sole propeller hydrodynamics kinaci et al 2018 the model takes hull propeller interactions into account and uses the underwater vehicle propulsion interaction parameters t and w the effects of wake fraction and thrust deduction factor on the underwater vehicle propulsion are briefly visualized in fig 2 2 3 wake fraction and thrust deduction factor the self propulsion estimation model considers the interaction between the underwater vehicle and the propeller via the wake fraction w and the thrust deduction factor t with the following assumptions a1 an open water propeller receives uniform flow but the inflow coming to a propeller working behind an underwater vehicle is non uniform when the underwater vehicle is moving with a speed v the propeller does not receive a flow with speed v the difference is because of the disturbances on the flow coming to the propeller due to the body of the underwater vehicle this effect of the underwater vehicle on the hydrodynamic performance of the propeller is compensated by the wake fraction parameter as denoted by w in this paper a2 a bare hull underwater vehicle s resistance is lower than an underwater vehicle with a running propeller when the propeller is fitted at the stern side of the underwater vehicle it speeds up the flow due to its rotation this increase in the flow velocity creates a low pressure zone at the aft of the underwater vehicle which creates an additional resistance the additional resistance due to the existence of the propeller is represented by thrust deduction factor and denoted by t the self propulsion estimation model presented in this paper is dependent on w and t there are two conventional methods to obtain these parameters either by model tests in towing tanks or numerical simulations table 1 lists the recommended wake fraction w values for single or twin propellers by the international maritime organization imo a linear interpolation for intermediate values of block coefficient c b is advised imo recommends a conservative estimate for the thrust deduction factor t given by 13 t 0 7 w recommendations of the imo will be followed in this study in order to obtain the wake fraction and thrust deduction parameters for practical purposes 3 validation of self propulsion estimation model as stated previously at the self propulsion estimation model steps s1 s7 and detailed assumptions in a1 a2 in section 2 the feedforward self propulsion estimation model requires four sets of information bare hull resistance open water propeller performance wake fraction and thrust deduction factor the wake fraction and thrust deduction factor are determined empirically from the imo guidelines as given in table 1 however the underwater vehicle resistance and propulsion parameters should be investigated first for the assessment of the validity of the self propulsion estimation model therefore we selected the darpa suboff aff 1 model given in groves et al 1989 different perspectives of the model are illustrated in fig 3 the geometric properties of the aff 1 model used in this study are given in table 2 3 1 validation of bare hull total resistance experimental results of total resistance of the model are given in liu and huang 1998 sezen 2018 conducted numerical simulations of the same form the total resistance obtained via the self propulsion estimation model are given in comparison with these two results in fig 4 as it can be seen from fig 4 all computational results are compatible and the self propulsion estimation model is well correlated with the experimental total resistance 3 2 validation of underwater vehicle propulsion the total resistance of the underwater vehicle should be compensated by the propeller to drive the vehicle forward the validity of the underwater vehicle resistance of the self propulsion estimation model was tested and good results were obtained in this section validation of the underwater vehicle propulsion will be given to do that we will also make use of the wake fraction and thrust deduction factor and this will lead us to test the validity of the self propulsion estimation model as a whole as a prerequisite for using the model open water propeller diagram is required in the literature the darpa suboff is fitted with e1619 propeller the propeller has 7 blades and its open water tests are conducted by chase and carrica 2013 results of the experiments are given in fig 5 we will be using thrust identity during the estimation of the underwater vehicle speed therefore a second order equation will be fitted to the thrust coefficient curve given in fig 4 as in equation 12 and obtain coefficients k 0 k 1 and k 2 while validating the underwater vehicle propulsion case the wake fraction w and thrust deduction factor t should also be considered all these values and the diameter of the propeller are given in table 3 using the values presented in table 3 and the bare hull total resistance given in fig 4 the self propulsion estimation model can be applied and propeller rotation rates at each underwater vehicle speed can be obtained results of the model are computed and compared with numerical simulation results in fig 6 sezen et al 2018 self propulsion estimation model results are found to be in coherence with sezen et al 2018 having very good agreement especially in lower underwater vehicle speeds 4 simulation scenarios after a thorough validation of the self propulsion estimation model in section 3 simulation scenarios for the underwater vehicle in forward motion are conducted the underwater vehicle is considered to be only moving in the forward direction sway heave roll pitch and yaw motions are neglected in this study hence a single degree of freedom simulation model is derived for an underwater vehicle for the surge motion only 4 1 simulation model newton s second law of motion is given by 14 f d m t v d t the force acting on an underwater vehicle during its surge motion can be split into two propeller thrust t that drives the vehicle forward and its resistance r t which opposes it the displacement of the underwater vehicle is assumed to be stable during the motion therefore the total mass in motion m t is constant in this case equation 14 can be written as follows 15 r t t m t d v d t an underwater vehicle moves a mass of water as it moves through it considering only the forward motion an underwater vehicle with mass m will move an added mass of water m x in surge direction decomposition of total mass in motion m t into its components yields 16 m m x d v d t r t t we are interested in finding the forward speed v of the underwater vehicle integrating the equation and rearranging it to leave ship speed alone on the left hand side results in 17 v v 0 r t t m m x d t transforming the integral form of equation 16 into the numerical form we obtain 18 v i 1 v i r t i t i m m x δ t 4 2 simulation conditions accelerating motion of darpa suboff aff 1 model is simulated to see the speed variations of the underwater vehicle in time the simulation model is based on equation 18 the underwater vehicle starts from zero speed and zero propeller rotation rate initially v 0 0 and n 0 0 the time step is selected as δ t 0 005 s in equation 18 the bare hull resistance r t the thrust t the mass m and the added mass m x are the unknowns for the bare hull resistance r t we use a third order taylor series expansion using the self propulsion estimation model curve in fig 6 20 n n v v n v v v 2 n v v v v 3 in equation 20 n v n v v and n v v v are the first second and third order derivatives of propeller rotation rate with respect to the velocity these derivatives are obtained from the self propulsion estimation model curve given in fig 6 a curve fitting process via the least squares approach summarized in appendix 1 is used to extract the derivatives from equation 19 and equation 20 the inputs and outputs of the underwater vehicle resistance and underwater vehicle propulsion blocks are given in fig 7 the mass of the underwater vehicle can be calculated by the following equality 21 m ρ where the water is assumed to be at 20 c and the water density is ρ 998 21 k g m 3 the surge motion added mass m x can be taken as 5 of the vehicle s mass as advised by clarke et al 1983 all these parameters have been calculated and given in table 4 coefficients of resistance are intentionally given as negative values due to the coordinate system used it opposes the direction of thrust in this case equation 18 can be reorganized as follows 22 v i 1 v i r v v i r v v v i 2 r v v v v i 3 k t ρ n i 1 2 d 4 m m x δ t note that the propeller diameter d is determined from its geometrical properties and the thrust coefficient k t can be calculated using the self propulsion estimation model explained in section 2 the parameters used in the simulations are given in table 4 4 3 feedforward speed control mechanism the feedforward speed control system considered in this study makes use of the self propulsion estimation model defined with 7 steps given in section 2 the block diagram of the feedforward speed control mechanism of the underwater vehicle is described in detail in fig 8 the underwater vehicle dynamics block based on the self propulsion estimation model consists of underwater vehicle resistance and propulsion sub blocks first the self propulsion estimation model is run for a given range of underwater vehicle velocities as in fig 1 then bare hull resistance and propeller rotation rate values obtained with respect to the vehicle velocity are expanded into a third order taylor series as in equation 19 and equation 20 respectively the values of the parameters r v r v v r v v v n v n v v and n v v v are obtained using the curve fitting algorithm described in appendix 1 the rotation rate coefficients are used along with equation 20 for obtaining the predicted rotation rate n p used in simulations the value of the propeller rotation rate starts from zero n 0 0 at time t 0 and reaches n s n p the settling condition depends on the selected rate of change of propeller rotation n the speed of the underwater vehicle converges to the desired steady speed when the equality r t s t s is satisfied the algorithm for the propeller rotation rate denoted by n c o n t is given as follows 24 n i 1 n i n δ t n c o n t 0 n i 0 n i 1 0 n i n p n p n i n p n p n v v t n v v v t 2 n v v v v t 3 here n p is the rotation rate at which the underwater vehicle reaches the desired speed v t simulation converges to the steady speed gradually until the equality r t s t s is achieved the resistance r t s is calculated using equation 19 and the thrust t s is determined by equation 9 the thrust coefficient k t is determined from the open water propeller diagram given in fig 5 and it is being handled inside the underwater vehicle propulsion block the underwater vehicle mass and added mass are calculated from the geometric properties of the vehicle as explained previously the desired speed is the main input of the control system and the propeller rotation rate control saturates as soon as the propeller reaches n p appendix 2 presents a summary of parameters involved in the feedforward control mechanism with the self propulsion estimation model used in this study the i o relationship of the underwater vehicle dynamics block can be clearly seen in fig 9 5 results results of this study are presented in two parts the first part discusses the results obtained for darpa aff 1 model comparison of the feedforward speed control mechanism presented in this paper with the available real time measurement data is given in the second part of this section 5 1 darpa aff 1 model results two simulations were carried out for target underwater vehicle speeds of v t 1 4 m s and v t 2 7 5 m s using the rotation rate coefficients given in table 4 and equation 20 the self propulsion estimation model predicts the propeller rotation rates for these cases as n p 1 13 349 r p s and n p 1 24 492 r p s the vehicle speed and the propeller rotation rate are initially zero i e v 0 0 and n 0 0 the propeller s rotational acceleration is n d n d t 20 r p s s the propeller reaches n p 1 and n p 2 in 0 665 and 1 225 s respectively this can also be seen in fig 10 upper left for the first 5 s of simulation after propeller reaches the predicted rotation rate it keeps this rate to the end of the simulation the plots of the resistance r t s upper right the thrust t s lower left and the sum of the thrust and resistance lower right graphs are given in fig 10 only the first 30 s of simulations for r t s t s are given to show the additional thrust at the beginning of motion which results in acceleration of the underwater vehicle fig 11 shows the time plot of the speed in the simulations the thrust resistance and speed converge to the steady state values given in table 5 in this table r t r is the steady state resistance that satisfies r t r r t s after a steady value for r t s is achieved the same holds for the steady state thrust and the steady state velocity where t r t s and v r v s after t s and v s convergence the percent error given in table 5 is computed as 25 e v t v r v t x 100 in order to clearly show the stability convergence for a wide range of initial conditions a monte carlo esque simulation scheme is provided in fig 12 that investigates a family of initial propeller rates spanning from 0 to 100 rps with an increment of 10 rps the scheme is carried out for simulation 2 case as seen the speed converges to the initial target v t 2 7 5 m s for each propeller rotation rate set at the start of the simulation 5 2 comparison with real time measurements the feedforward speed control mechanism presented in this study was implemented for a commercialized autonomous underwater vehicle named gavia auv and developed by teledyne marine gavia s length can be in the range between 1 8 m l 4 5 m depending on the configuration but it has a fixed diameter of d s 0 2 m configurations depend on the market it can be designed for commercial defense and security or scientific purposes fig 13 shows a profile view of the auv taken from its brochure gavia auv and sea raptor brochure 2019 helgason 2012 conducted a thorough study on the motions of gavia auv and measured surge sway and heave velocities as well as its heading velocities and covered distances by the auv are recorded and published in this study this paper focuses only on surge results surge velocities were measured for three different propeller rotation rates 187 r p m 197 r p m and 203 r p m simulations in this study were conducted for 187 r p m case our feedforward speed control mechanism is based on the self propulsion estimation model and as previously stated in section 2 this model strictly requires bare hull total resistance r t open water propeller diagram so that we have k 0 k 1 and k 2 wake fraction w and thrust deduction factor t it is possible to estimate the bare hull total resistance the wake fraction and the thrust deduction using the geometrical properties of the auv but we also require knowing the propeller characteristics the geometrical properties of the auv in helgason 2012 are given but there are no data about its propeller neither in this study nor in gavia auv and sea raptor brochure 2019 therefore we used the propeller of darpa aff 1 model k 0 k 1 and k 2 values are taken from the open water propeller diagram of e1619 considering the diameter of the vehicle propeller diameter was chosen to be d 0 085 m the geometric properties of the auv are given in table 6 and propulsion parameters used in our simulations are given in table 7 the wetted area s of the gavia auv is not provided and we do not have the exact geometry of the auv due to lack of data we calculated the wetted area of a cylinder having dimensions of l x d 1 8 m x 0 2 m and used it in our simulations table 6 after running the self propulsion estimation model the resistance coefficients r v r v v r v v v and the rotation rate coefficients n v n v v n v v v were obtained these coefficients are given in table 8 simulations are conducted in a water at 20 c with density ρ 998 21 k g m 3 and dynamic viscosity μ 0 001002 k g m 1 s 1 the propeller s rotational acceleration is as in darpa aff 1 case n 20 r p s s helgason 2012 published surge velocity measurements at 187 r p m which correspond to a propeller rotation rate of 3 117 r p s at this rotation rate the self propulsion estimation model returns a target vehicle velocity of v t 0 2024 m s the feedforward speed control system results and helgason s measurement data are compared in fig 14 unfortunately helgason provides only the first 28 s of measurement data therefore it was not possible to extend the comparison beyond 28 s we could not make the assessment of steady state error as the vehicle did not reach a steady velocity in his measurements however the transient speed increase in the simulation shows a satisfactory agreement with the measurement data it is considered that the uncertainties in the gavia auv parameters especially the propulsion system lead to the discrepancy in the transient state results parameters after 350 s when the simulation settled to a steady state are given in table 9 the simulation reached a perfect steady state as the percent error between the target and achieved speeds is found to be e 0 2 6 conclusions in this paper we elaborate the feedforward speed control of underwater vehicles in surge direction the controller relies on the self propulsion estimation model that predicts the propeller rotation rate for any given target speed the results of this study illustrate that the control system can accurately predict and control cruising speed for conventional auv forms in all cases studied in this paper the percent errors between the target speeds and the steady state speeds were found to be less than 1 additionally the simulation results show that the controller does not only predict the steady state response but it can also predict accurately the transient response of these vehicles it is believed that the feedforward control system proposed in this study is more cost effective than the conventional feedback systems because it eliminates the need for expensive underwater sensors to be implemented in commercial auvs future studies are planned to relate the auv cruising speed with its desired depth this will require coupling the surge and heave motions of the auv in which the buoyancy of the vehicle should also be regarded we plan to take real time measurements so that we can implement parameter identification methods to determine the hydrodynamic coefficients experimentally this will allow us to achieve a better perspective on the control of underwater vehicle motion credit authorship contribution statement omer kemal kinaci conceptualization methodology
