the autonomy of any airborne land borne or waterborne vehicle starts with controlling its speed to achieve cruise speed control the conventional approach is to use closed loop feedback control systems that require high precision sensors underwater sensors are expensive due to harsh environment and corrosive properties of seawater in this study we propose a speed control system for autonomous underwater vehicles auvs that closes the control loop via a feedforward mechanism eliminating the need for these expensive sensors the feedforward control is based on the recently developed self propulsion estimation model which can accurately predict propeller rotation rate for conventional auv forms the model is first validated by comparing the predicted resistance and propeller rotation rate of darpa suboff with the experimental and numerical results published in the literature after observing a good match the feedforward control system is used to ensure that the auv reaches a predetermined surge speed two different underwater vehicles are considered in presenting the results of this study the darpa suboff and the gavia auv which has real time measurements available in the literature the feedforward control system developed in this study achieves the desired speed with negligible errors transient response analysis shows that the computer simulation results are in good agreement with experimental results for the gavia auv keywords auv motion control cruise control self propulsion hull propeller interaction darpa suboff gavia auv 1 introduction as autonomous water vehicles increasingly occupy the world s maritime agenda nowadays marine and control engineers work together to develop and enhance control systems to increase the robustness of these marine vehicles although airborne drones have found extensive use in our daily lives it is not possible to make similar statements for waterborne drones recently there has been a surge of interest in utilizing autonomous underwater vehicles auvs to study the underwater environment combined with high precision sensors and robust control systems these underwater vehicles provide us with considerable capabilities to discover the seas as the autonomy levels of underwater vehicles increase so do our capabilities to work in the marine field an intelligent underwater vehicle shall first meet the fundamental requirement of floating in water therefore most studies concerning auvs focus on keeping the depth of the vehicle at a desirable and constant level to achieve this auvs need to reach a minimum speed due to the hydrodynamic properties of these types of water vehicles nickell and woolsey 2005 auvs are generally positively buoyant and to keep their depth at desired levels they are required to cruise with a certain speed the reference eng et al 2016 presents a novel algorithm to keep a given auv at a minimum speed so that it maintains a constant depth the algorithm regulates the cruising speed at a minimum level to keep the desired depth and is experimentally verified with starfish auv an underwater vehicle developed by the national university of singapore chitre 2008 the paper tanakitkorn et al 2017 studies the energy consumption of delphin2 auv on board and considers the impact of net positive buoyancy on the control performance the authors focus on the vertical motions of the vehicle so that it has three degrees of freedom and use a proportional integral derivative pid based diving control system the authors in yu et al 2018 also consider speed depth relationship of auvs and describe a unified control architecture for variable speed following missions the authors claim that the controller guarantees smooth speed switching in the entire speed profile controlling an underwater vehicle s speed is important to fulfill its tasks an example of such tasks can be found in mallios et al 2016 where auvs are utilized in mapping underwater caves surfaces it is shown that the mapping quality obtained by the vehicle depends on the estimation of its trajectory and speed due to high sensitivity of speed estimation in such tasks there is a considerable ongoing research on velocity measurements with different techniques the reference rui fang et al 2011 states that convenient methods to measure velocity are limited by external disturbances in the oceans the authors propose a velocity measurement based on geomagnetic data to increase precision besides the high precision measurements of the vehicle speed motional aspects of the vehicle should also be considered fast vehicle response is one of the desired capabilities an auv is expected to possess so that it can reach the desired speed as quickly as possible continuous interference to propeller rotation increases fuel consumption and delays the vehicle response in catching the desired speed speed control using feedback control systems usually results in an oscillatory behavior due to consistent changes in the propeller rotation rate reducing the economic life of the auv as well as increasing the cost of transportation this study focuses on the stabilization of the auv to a given target velocity unlike the conventional closed loop systems using feedback from sensors this study uses a feedforward mechanism that can accurately predict the propeller rotation rate with respect to the target velocity two different underwater vehicles are considered in this study the darpa suboff and the gavia auv the latter having real time measurements available in the literature the controller is based on a novel self propulsion estimation model published recently in the literature by the first author of this study kinaci et al 2020 the self propulsion estimation model can predict the propeller rotation rate for any target auv velocity section 2 presents the iterative nature of the self propulsion estimation model and its minimum requirements prior to the implementation of the model it is first tested in various cases to see its predictions versus real measurements and numerical simulations section 3 is devoted to the validation of the self propulsion estimation model the total resistance of the darpa suboff and its propeller rotation rate are predicted by the model and compared with the experimental and cfd computational fluid dynamics based results section 4 presents the simulation conditions and the feedforward control mechanism adopted to the control of vehicle speed computer simulation results are given in section 5 finally the conclusions are presented in section 6 2 self propulsion estimation model the self propulsion estimation model employed in this study can also be found in kinaci et al 2018 gokce et al 2019 and kinaci et al 2020 we describe an iterative process with the following inputs for the feedforward speed estimation of interest to be formally defined in section 4 i bare hull resistance r t resistance of the vehicle in a range of given speeds excluding the propeller is needed this is conventionally obtained by towing tank experiments or cfd application ii open water propeller performance diagram hydrodynamic performance diagram of the propeller should be given as an input which also includes the propeller s thrust with respect to its advance coefficient coefficient values of k 0 k 1 and k 2 are extracted from the thrust curves by fitting a second order equation iii wake fraction w the underwater vehicle changes the flow received by the propeller the effect of the vehicle on the propeller is reflected on the hydrodynamic performance of the propeller by wake fraction w iv thrust deduction factor t a running propeller increases the total resistance of the ship this effect of the propeller on vehicle resistance is reflected on the vehicle propeller system by thrust deduction factor t details of the aforementioned self propulsion estimation parameters and their practical algebraic derivations are presented in the following sections the flow diagram of the propeller rotation rate calculation for the self propulsion estimation model can be seen in fig 1 2 1 water resistance for underwater vehicles water resistance for underwater vehicles is based on hughes decomposition of total ship resistance molland 2011 the vehicle body resistance r t is given by 1 r t r f r v p r w where r f is the frictional resistance r v p is the viscous pressure resistance and r w is the wave resistance resistance components can be defined by morison s equation written as 2 r x 1 2 ρ s v 2 c x in this equation r x denotes resistance and c x resistance coefficient where x stands for t f v p or w indicating total frictional viscous pressure and wave resistances respectively ρ is the density of the fluid s is the wetted area of the underwater vehicle body and v is the underwater vehicle velocity procedures and guidelines by the international towing tank conference ittc recommend the following model vehicle correlation line for frictional resistance coefficient ittc 2017 3 c f 0 075 log r e 2 2 r e denotes the reynolds number given by 4 r e ρ v l μ where l is the underwater vehicle length and μ is the dynamic viscosity of the fluid after determining the frictional resistance coefficient using equation 3 frictional resistance r f can be calculated by equation 2 viscous pressure resistance r v p can be related to frictional resistance using form factor ittc 2017 denoted by k as 5 r v p k r f the form factor of an underwater vehicle is generally based on its block coefficient and length to breadth ratio in the case that experiments are not available the form factor can be found by the relation 6 k 32 8 c b l d s 2 0 03 here d s is the diameter of the underwater body and c b is its block coefficient which can be calculated by 7 c b 4 π d s 2 l where is the displacement of the underwater vehicle equation 6 is originally given for surface ships ittc 1975 and here it is simplified for a cylindrical underwater body underwater vehicles operate far from the free surface boundary and therefore it can generally be assumed that they are not generating waves in this case wave resistance can be neglected i e 8 r w 0 2 2 propeller thrust a conventional fixed pitch propeller thrust t can be calculated by the following equation 9 t k t ρ n 2 d 4 where n is the propeller rotation rate per second d is the propeller diameter and k t is the thrust coefficient propeller performance is assessed in open water propeller tests where the thrust torque and open water efficiency can be graphed with respect to its advance coefficient j given by 10 j v a n d where v a denotes the flow velocity that the propeller receives v a is different than the underwater vehicle speed v because the underwater vehicle disturbs the flow coming to the propeller these two speeds can be related via the wake fraction denoted by w and v a can be calculated by the equation 11 v a v 1 w calculation of v a makes it possible to compute the advance coefficient j by equation 10 the propeller performance can be found for a given range usually 0 1 j 1 2 either by experiments or numerical simulations after determining the advance coefficient j of the propeller the corresponding thrust coefficient k t the torque coefficient k q and the propeller efficiency η 0 can be read from propeller performance diagrams the thrust and torque identities may be used when finding the speed of an underwater vehicle in our case we will go with the thrust identity case and thus only k t will be required a second order equation to the thrust coefficient curve is fitted by the least squares method described in appendix 1 12 k t k 0 k 1 j k 2 j 2 the coefficients k 0 k 1 and k 2 will be used in this study to represent the propeller in estimating the underwater vehicle speed the steps of the flow diagram given in fig 1 are listed below for better assessment of the self propulsion estimation model s1 wake fraction w is considered as an initial input of the iteration v a is calculated for the underwater vehicle of interest using equation 11 s2 select an arbitrary propeller rotation rate n as an initial value for the propeller rotation rate s3 we know the propeller diameter d from its geometry using v a obtained in step s1 calculate the advance coefficient j using equation 10 s4 using open water propeller performance diagram curve fit the open water propeller thrust coefficient to obtain k 0 k 1 and k 2 s5 using j obtained in step s3 and k 0 k 1 k 2 in step s4 calculate the thrust coefficient k t by equation 12 s6 using the fluid density ρ propeller diameter d propeller rotation rate selected in step s2 and thrust coefficient k t obtained in step s5 calculate the thrust t by equation 9 s7 thrust deduction factor t and bare hull resistance r t are given as inputs check if r t t 1 t is satisfied by using the thrust t calculated in step s6 as it can be seen from the flowchart in fig 1 and the detailed definitions of steps given s1 s7 the high fidelity model behavior is derived by means of sole underwater vehicle and sole propeller hydrodynamics kinaci et al 2018 the model takes hull propeller interactions into account and uses the underwater vehicle propulsion interaction parameters t and w the effects of wake fraction and thrust deduction factor on the underwater vehicle propulsion are briefly visualized in fig 2 2 3 wake fraction and thrust deduction factor the self propulsion estimation model considers the interaction between the underwater vehicle and the propeller via the wake fraction w and the thrust deduction factor t with the following assumptions a1 an open water propeller receives uniform flow but the inflow coming to a propeller working behind an underwater vehicle is non uniform when the underwater vehicle is moving with a speed v the propeller does not receive a flow with speed v the difference is because of the disturbances on the flow coming to the propeller due to the body of the underwater vehicle this effect of the underwater vehicle on the hydrodynamic performance of the propeller is compensated by the wake fraction parameter as denoted by w in this paper a2 a bare hull underwater vehicle s resistance is lower than an underwater vehicle with a running propeller when the propeller is fitted at the stern side of the underwater vehicle it speeds up the flow due to its rotation this increase in the flow velocity creates a low pressure zone at the aft of the underwater vehicle which creates an additional resistance the additional resistance due to the existence of the propeller is represented by thrust deduction factor and denoted by t the self propulsion estimation model presented in this paper is dependent on w and t there are two conventional methods to obtain these parameters either by model tests in towing tanks or numerical simulations table 1 lists the recommended wake fraction w values for single or twin propellers by the international maritime organization imo a linear interpolation for intermediate values of block coefficient c b is advised imo recommends a conservative estimate for the thrust deduction factor t given by 13 t 0 7 w recommendations of the imo will be followed in this study in order to obtain the wake fraction and thrust deduction parameters for practical purposes 3 validation of self propulsion estimation model as stated previously at the self propulsion estimation model steps s1 s7 and detailed assumptions in a1 a2 in section 2 the feedforward self propulsion estimation model requires four sets of information bare hull resistance open water propeller performance wake fraction and thrust deduction factor the wake fraction and thrust deduction factor are determined empirically from the imo guidelines as given in table 1 however the underwater vehicle resistance and propulsion parameters should be investigated first for the assessment of the validity of the self propulsion estimation model therefore we selected the darpa suboff aff 1 model given in groves et al 1989 different perspectives of the model are illustrated in fig 3 the geometric properties of the aff 1 model used in this study are given in table 2 3 1 validation of bare hull total resistance experimental results of total resistance of the model are given in liu and huang 1998 sezen 2018 conducted numerical simulations of the same form the total resistance obtained via the self propulsion estimation model are given in comparison with these two results in fig 4 as it can be seen from fig 4 all computational results are compatible and the self propulsion estimation model is well correlated with the experimental total resistance 3 2 validation of underwater vehicle propulsion the total resistance of the underwater vehicle should be compensated by the propeller to drive the vehicle forward the validity of the underwater vehicle resistance of the self propulsion estimation model was tested and good results were obtained in this section validation of the underwater vehicle propulsion will be given to do that we will also make use of the wake fraction and thrust deduction factor and this will lead us to test the validity of the self propulsion estimation model as a whole as a prerequisite for using the model open water propeller diagram is required in the literature the darpa suboff is fitted with e1619 propeller the propeller has 7 blades and its open water tests are conducted by chase and carrica 2013 results of the experiments are given in fig 5 we will be using thrust identity during the estimation of the underwater vehicle speed therefore a second order equation will be fitted to the thrust coefficient curve given in fig 4 as in equation 12 and obtain coefficients k 0 k 1 and k 2 while validating the underwater vehicle propulsion case the wake fraction w and thrust deduction factor t should also be considered all these values and the diameter of the propeller are given in table 3 using the values presented in table 3 and the bare hull total resistance given in fig 4 the self propulsion estimation model can be applied and propeller rotation rates at each underwater vehicle speed can be obtained results of the model are computed and compared with numerical simulation results in fig 6 sezen et al 2018 self propulsion estimation model results are found to be in coherence with sezen et al 2018 having very good agreement especially in lower underwater vehicle speeds 4 simulation scenarios after a thorough validation of the self propulsion estimation model in section 3 simulation scenarios for the underwater vehicle in forward motion are conducted the underwater vehicle is considered to be only moving in the forward direction sway heave roll pitch and yaw motions are neglected in this study hence a single degree of freedom simulation model is derived for an underwater vehicle for the surge motion only 4 1 simulation model newton s second law of motion is given by 14 f d m t v d t the force acting on an underwater vehicle during its surge motion can be estimation model explained in section 2 the parameters used in the simulations are given in table 4 4 3 feedforward speed control mechanism the feedforward speed control system considered in this study makes use of the self propulsion estimation model defined with 7 steps given in section 2 the block diagram of the feedforward speed control mechanism of the underwater vehicle is described in detail in fig 8 the underwater vehicle dynamics block based on the self propulsion estimation model consists of underwater vehicle resistance and propulsion sub blocks first the self propulsion estimation model is run for a given range of underwater vehicle velocities as in fig 1 then bare hull resistance and propeller rotation rate values obtained with respect to the vehicle velocity are the equality r t s t s is achieved the resistance r t s is calculated using equation 19 and the thrust t s is determined by equation 9 the thrust coefficient k t is determined from the open water underwater vehicle speeds of v t 1 4 m s and v t 2 7 5 m s using the rotation rate coefficients given in table 4 and equation 20 the self propulsion estimation model predicts the propeller rotation predicted rotation rate it keeps this rate to the end of the simulation the plots of the resistance r t s upper right the thrust t s lower left and the sum of the thrust and resistance lower right graphs are given in fig 10 only the first 30 s of simulations for r t s t s are given to show the additional thrust at the beginning of motion which results in acceleration of the underwater vehicle fig 11 shows the time plot of the speed in the simulations the thrust resistance and speed converge to the steady state values given in table 5 in this table r t r is the steady state resistance that satisfies r t r r t s after a steady value for r t s is achieved the same holds for the steady state thrust and the steady state velocity where t r t s and v r v s after t s and v s convergence the percent error given in table 5 is computed as 25 e v t v r v t x 100 in order to clearly show the stability convergence for a wide range of initial conditions a monte carlo esque simulation scheme is provided in fig 12 that investigates a family of initial propeller rates spanning from 0 to 100 rps with an increment of 10 rps the scheme is carried out for simulation 2 case as seen the speed converges to the initial target v t 2 7 5 m s for each propeller rotation rate set at the start of the simulation 5 2 comparison with real time measurements the feedforward speed control mechanism presented in this study was implemented for a commercialized autonomous underwater vehicle named gavia auv and developed by teledyne marine gavia s length can be in the range between 1 8 m l 4 5 m depending on the configuration but it has a fixed diameter of d s 0 2 m configurations depend on the market it can be designed for commercial defense and security or scientific purposes fig 13 shows a profile view of the auv taken from its brochure gavia auv and sea raptor brochure 2019 helgason 2012 conducted a thorough study on the motions of gavia auv and measured surge sway and heave velocities as well as its heading velocities and covered distances by the auv are recorded and published in this study this paper focuses only on surge results surge velocities were measured for three different propeller rotation rates 187 r p m 197 r p m and 203 r p m simulations in this study were conducted for 187 r p m case our feedforward speed control mechanism is based on the self propulsion estimation model and as previously stated in section 2 this model strictly requires bare hull total resistance r t open water propeller diagram so that we have k 0 k 1 and k 2 wake fraction w and thrust deduction factor t it is possible to estimate the bare hull total resistance the wake fraction and the thrust deduction using the geometrical properties of the auv but we also require knowing the propeller characteristics the geometrical properties of the auv in helgason 2012 are given but there are no data about its propeller neither in this study nor in gavia auv and sea raptor brochure 2019 therefore we used the propeller of darpa aff 1 model k 0 k 1 and k 2 values are taken from the open water propeller diagram of e1619 considering the diameter of the vehicle propeller diameter was chosen to be d 0 085 m the geometric properties of the auv are given in table 6 and propulsion parameters used in our simulations are given in table 7 the wetted area s of the gavia auv is not provided and we do not have the exact geometry of the auv due to lack of data we calculated the wetted area of a cylinder having dimensions of l x d 1 8 m x 0 2 m and used it in our simulations table 6 after running the self propulsion estimation model the resistance coefficients r v r v v r v v v and the rotation rate coefficients n v n v v n v v v were obtained these coefficients are given in table 8 simulations are conducted in a water at 20 c with density ρ 998 21 k g m 3 and dynamic viscosity μ 0 001002 k g m 1 s 1 the propeller s rotational acceleration is as in darpa aff 1 case n 20 r p s s helgason 2012 published surge velocity measurements at 187 r p m which correspond to a propeller rotation rate of 3 117 r p s at this rotation rate the self propulsion estimation model returns a target vehicle velocity of v t 0 2024 m s the feedforward speed control system results and helgason s measurement data are compared in fig 14 unfortunately helgason provides only the first 28 s of measurement data therefore it was not possible to extend the comparison beyond 28 s we could not make the assessment of steady state error as the vehicle did not reach a steady velocity in his measurements however the transient speed increase in the simulation shows a satisfactory agreement with the measurement data it is considered that the uncertainties in the gavia auv parameters especially the propulsion system lead to the discrepancy in the transient state results parameters after 350 s when the simulation settled to a steady state are given in table 9 the simulation reached a perfect steady state as the percent error between the target and achieved speeds is found to be e 0 2 6 conclusions in this paper we elaborate the feedforward speed control of underwater vehicles in surge direction the controller relies on the self propulsion estimation model that predicts the propeller rotation rate for any given target speed the results of this study illustrate that the control system can accurately predict and control cruising speed for conventional auv forms in all cases studied in this paper the percent errors between the target speeds and the steady state speeds were found to be less than 1 additionally the simulation results show that the controller does not only predict the steady state response but it can also predict accurately the transient response of these vehicles it is believed that the feedforward control system proposed in this study is more cost effective than the conventional feedback systems because it eliminates the need for expensive underwater sensors to be implemented in commercial auvs future studies are planned to relate the auv cruising speed with its desired depth this will require coupling the surge and heave motions of the auv in which the buoyancy of the vehicle should also be regarded we plan to take real time measurements so that we can implement parameter identification methods to determine the hydrodynamic coefficients experimentally this will allow us to achieve a better perspective on the control of underwater vehicle motion credit authorship contribution statement omer kemal kinaci conceptualization methodology in recent years coastal erosion in the vietnamese mekong delta vmd is occurring at a rapid rate which is leading to considerable damage of infrastructure and the human made environment various solutions have been proposed to protect the coastline in the vmd including pile rock breakwaters prbws prbws have several advantages that make them particularly applicable to the coast of west ca mau and the mekong delta the focus of this study is to test prbw efficiency in the vmd by evaluating a physical experimental model followed by evaluation of observations in the field from the ca mau province a series of experiments were undertaken to build an empirical formula of the wave transmission coefficient the results show that the prbw structure works effectively in the case of emergence when the wave transmission coefficient kt is between 0 3 and 0 4 but in this case the wave reflection coefficient is quite large i e kr of 0 45 0 6 the experimentally obtained and measured transmission coefficient kt show strong agreement the analytical results show that a prbw dissipates most of the energy for short periodic waves however long periodic waves can still be transmitted through the prbw the prbw shows significant advantages over other styles of breakwaters including an increased potential to reduce erosion high stability and a reduced deadweight of construction materials these advantages mean that prbws have a great potential to aid restoration of mangrove forests that are sheltered behind the breakwater in the vmd region keywords pile rock breakwater prbw wave transmission wave reflection wave dissipation wave spectra coastal mekong delta 1 introduction in recent decades coastal provinces and cities in the vietnamese mekong delta vmd have suffered severe land erosion in the west coast south of vietnam in particular this severe erosion has led to hundreds of hectares of land being washed away along the coastline and has destroyed many houses and infrastructure for example approximately 200 km of shoreline in the ca mau and kien giang provinces have been affected by severe erosion according to xing et al 2017 see fig 1 coastal erosion in the vmd typically begins with erosion of the topsoil around the mangrove roots this process accelerates over time gradually depleting the remaining headlands covered with mangrove vegetation albers and jan 2015 to decrease the rate of erosion a range of breakwater technologies have been deployed in the vmd including rubble mound breakwaters t fence breakwaters geotube breakwaters perforated wall breakwaters and pile rock breakwaters prbws due to their construction prbws have several advantages over other styles of breakwaters compared to traditional trapezoidal rubble mound breakwaters prbws have a typically smaller geometrical size leading to the benefit of a reduced deadweight of construction materials prbw construction consists of a frame of two rows of piles which is then infilled with rock rubble during construction the piles penetrate deep into the seabed which fastens the rock core and provides the structure with strong wave resistance due to their deep penetration prbws are also typically more suitable for weak soil foundation and severe seabed scour liu 2012 an example application of a prbw is in the ca mau province where they have successfully been constructed to minimize critical erosion that threatens the safety of sea dykes and protected mangrove forests the first construction of prbws in this region was 300 m long and constructed in 2010 at the coastline in khanh tien u minh district ca mau province this initial construction was later extended to approximately 22 km in 2019 see fig 2 after a decade of operation this prbw has demonstrated high efficiency and has reduced the impact of incoming waves leading to accretion and regeneration of mangroves on the west coast of the ca mau province the success of this prbw is a good indication that this style of breakwater is applicable for broader application across the soft soil foundation across the coast of the vmd a range of studies have considered the effectiveness of prbws for example nguyen huu nhan 2015 applied a coupled modelling of hydrodynamics and spectral sea wave on shallow water to evaluate the effectiveness of a prbw on the west sea of ca mau the results from this study showed high effectiveness of the prbw for aiding alluvial accumulation preventing rip circulation and wave action and protecting the coastline and mangrove belt liu 2012 applied linear potential theory to analyze the wave absorption of prbws the results from this study showed the relationship between wave transmission reflection and dissipation coefficients when the wave interacts with this a prbw but they did not validate their results with physical model experiments furthermore herbich 1998 conducted experiments to predict the transformation of waves passing through closely spaced pile or large cylinder breakwaters several researchers have conducted experiments and numerical modelling to reproduce the hydrodynamic near field processes and the vortex generation and dissipation by applying the reynolds averaged navier stokes rans equations for low crested permeable breakwaters garcia et al 2004 hsu et al 2004 martinelli et al 2006 this rans model has the ability to reproduce the near field flow characteristics around low crested structures moreover hur 2004 and hur et al 2011 investigated the effect of the slope gradient of submerged breakwaters by using a three dimensional numerical model and a three dimensional wave basin for their experiments johnson et al 2005 and johnson 2006 conducted research to study waves currents and wave breaking around submerged breakwaters and verified their results with three dimensional wave basin experiments and wave flume experiments at aalborg university denmark and the university of cantabria spain kramer et al 2005 respectively the results from these studies showed that the mike 21 model offers some confidence in the ability of the models to reproduce waves and currents of submerged breakwaters more recently ha 2019 undertook research on analytical and numerical analysis for the stability of prbw that are subjected to combined loading the authors of this study developed a method to calculate the bearing capacity of the prbw on soft clay soils this investigation of wave performance was not a comprehensive analysis in the contest of the west coast vmd and the research was mainly based on applying a formula for conventional rubble mound breakwaters that was not suitable to be applied to prbws based on the previous research on prbws the main objective of this study is to better understand the hydraulic performance of this type of breakwaters by analyzing the results from performing a series of physical model wave transmission experiments the specific objectives of this study are to 1 propose innovative structures of prbw that are both suitable for the soft soil foundation and also have a fast construction process that has the potential to save concrete and rubble construction materials in the vmd 2 determine the wave reduction transmission and dissipation coefficients through these prbws 3 develop an experimental formula for wave transmission to inform future design and construction of prwbs to address these specific objectives this paper is structured as follows in section 2 we describe the experimental setup and results of investigating wave transmission through a prbw based on observations in the laboratory in section 3 we then validate the experimental results by investigating wave transmission through prbw from observations in the field finally in section 4 we make conclusions from both the laboratory experiments as well as the observations in the field and provide recommendations for future work 2 wave transmission through prbw from observations in the laboratory in this section we first introduce the experimental model configuration followed by more details on the flume setup and instrumentation in the laboratory we then present the experimental scenarios explored and finish with a discussion of the experimental results 2 1 model configuration the in situ dimensions of the designed prbw structure were collected during a project that investigated coastal protection works in the vmd in 2017 the type of pile used in this structure is a pre stressed concrete pile with a diameter of 30 cm length of 8 m and a width crest of 2 6 m as indicated in the longitudinal cross section see fig 3 there is a row of piles with spacing of 30 cm between each pile in addition to the piles this prbw structure used rock rubble with dimensions of approximately 25 35 cm the cross section a a in fig 3 shows the melaleuca mattresses and geo textile layer below the rocks as well as the vertical beams 50 30 cm and the horizontal beam 30 30 cm above the rocks to fit the prbw into the wave flume in the laboratory the dimensions of the model structure were scaled to 1 5 of the in situ size the maximum model scale was selected based on the ability of the wave flume to house the breakwater and the boundary conditions of the experiment the model scale was selected as the following nl 5 scale of length and height n t n l 2 24 scale of time n v n l 2 24 scale of velocity and nm n3 l 125 scale of mass the dimensions of the actual breakwater and the model breakwater considered in this study are described in table 1 according to the designed parameters of the actual structure the rubbles had a grade of dn 25 35 cm the experimental rubbles grade is calculated from the model scale and is specified in table 2 the experimental rubbles grade is sieved according to laboratory standards to ensure consistency in the dimensions porosity and overall similarity in front of the structure there is rip rap which prevents erosion at a 7 cm height equal to 2 layers of rubble and is 50 cm wide fig 4 2 2 flume setup and instrumentation the experiments were carried out in the wave flume at the river and marine hydrodynamic laboratory of the southern institute of water resources research binh duong province vietnam the experimental equipment was installed by hr wallingford the flume is 35 m long effective 1 2 m wide and 1 5 m high it is equipped with an automated system of active reflection compensation arc and is capable of generating both regular and irregular waves up to 0 3 m in height and 3 s in peak period fig 4 reliable resistance type wave gauges have the ability to measure wave signals at a sampling frequency up to 100 hz accuracy 0 1 mm the single piston paddle long crested wavemaker has a width of 1 2 m the maximum water depth in the flume is 1 0 m and the maximum wave height is 0 6 m corresponding to a period of 2 0 s the wave flume setup has two wave absorbers that are separated by a thick foam sheet at the wave generator side and a trapezoidal prism of rubbles and gravel in rear side the remaining energy after the wave passes through the breakwater after 90 of the total wave energy is absorbed is absorbed by the rubble absorber the reflected wave energy from the paddle is absorbed after 95 of the total wave energy is absorbed by the thick foam sheet it is important to note that in the vmd the wave height in the southwest monsoon is largest in the deep water of the study area and is about 1 1 5 m with a period of 3 6 s the experiments in this study are instead built under the assumption that wave conditions are under medium weather conditions without storms the boundary conditions of the wave parameters were generated by the joint north sea wave observation project jonswap spectra with a γ value of 3 30 which was validated by the agence française de développement afd project the selection of featured wave parameters is based on various research of wave observation in the vmd by the southern institute of water resources research siwrr and is combined with wave transmission derived from a numerical model wave parameters in the front and behind the breakwater were measured with 6 capacitance wave gauges incident and reflected waves were separated by using 4 gauges with software processing in wave measurement by the hr wallingford system the wave gauge system to measure water level fluctuation included the following wave probes calibration stems calibration pins wave probe tripod stands twin wire cables and a wave probe monitor the wave height measurable range of this system was 300 mm the output signal was 10 v accuracy was 0 1 mm and internal noise limiting filter was 3 db at 20 hz signal bandwidth four gauges were installed in front of the breakwater wg1 2 3 4 and were used for measuring the incident wave and to separate the reflected wave and the incident wave in front of the breakwater two gauges were installed behind the breakwater wg5 6 and were used to determine the height of the wave passing through the breakwater each of the experiments lasted approximately 500 tp s to adequately produce the main frequency domain of the desired wave spectra the locations of wave gauges are described in the experiment layout illustrated in fig 5 2 3 experimental scenarios to investigate the wave transmission through the prbw 78 scenarios were used including 6 scenarios for changing water level and crest freeboard rc and 13 scenarios for changing wave parameters hs tp l the experimental scenarios are shown in detail in table 3 the water levels corresponding to the experimental scenarios considered are shown in fig 6 2 4 results and discussion wave transmission through prbws is generally a function of relative crest freeboard crest width breakwater slope porosity permeability and wave characteristics van der meer and daemen 1994 angremond et al 1996 in this study we analyzed the experimental data to formulate an empirical equation for wave transmission and examined the effects on wave transmission of the most influential parameters including the relative crest freeboard and the wave slope other secondary parameters implicitly included in this study are the crest width and the porosity of the prbw 2 4 1 change in the wave spectra and the wave period before and after the breakwater the changes in the wave spectra after passing the breakwater are show in fig 7 the wg4 and wg5 gauges indicate the recorded wave signal in front of and after the construction respectively fig 7 provides a visual representation of an important characteristic of the wave hydrodynamics for prbw and it is clear that the wave amplitude in front of the breakwater is significantly higher than the amplitude after transmitting through the breakwater the spectral transformation across the breakwater with a high crest emergence rc 0 and submergence rc 0 are illustrated in fig 8 logically wave energy considerably dissipates when the crest of the breakwater has an emergence of rc 0 see fig 8b than when the crest of breakwater has submergence with rc 0 see fig 8d in the submergence situation rc 0 the wave arrives in front of the structure with high energy of 7 10 3 m2 hz see fig 8c and after the wave transmits through the breakwater the energy is still high and equivalent to 2 10 3 m2 hz with a range of frequency within 0 5 1 hz see fig 8d the energy for both the emergence and the submergence case in front of structure are approximately the same comparing fig 8a c channel 4 this is not the case however after the breakwater where the differences in the energy spectra distribution for the emergence and the submergence cases are significant see fig 8b d this result occurs due to the wave energy being dissipated or reflected when the waves interact with the breakwater structure under the emergence case the changes about the peak period of the spectra crest tp and period of t1 3 of the measured waves in front of and behind the structure are shown in fig 9 the trend illustrates that the period of t1 3 has a significant change when comparing the peak period of spectra tp in front of and behind the breakwater structure behind the structure t1 3 has a trend of becoming larger than in front of the structure see deviation from the 1 1 line while tp has no significant change follows the 1 1 line this relationship is consistent with the theory of wave spectra analysis the reason this occurs is that the waves have a shorter period when dissipated after interacting with structure only long waves transmit through the structure because their t1 3 behind the structure are bigger than those in front of the structure this observed trend agrees with earlier studies by liu 2012 and dhinakaran 2011 the changes of wave period in front of and behind the breakwater structure have noticeable differences when considering either the case of the emerged breakwater rc 0 and the case of the submerged breakwater rc 0 with period wave spectra tm see fig 9 right panel in the case of the emerged breakwater the tm behind the structure has a larger trend than those in front of the structure this behavior is vice versa in the case of the submerged breakwater in the case of rc 0 the breakwater with crest width structure b 1 4lm min and b 1 10lm max works for wave transmission in the shallow water region however the crest width of the prbw is not large enough for waves to break on in the observable laboratory experiments the effect of shallow water makes the waves periods behind the structure reduce in comparison with those in front of the structure 2 4 2 change of wave height in front of the breakwater structure the fluctuation of water level in front of the structure increases due to the influence of wave reflection created from the interaction of the incident waves and the breakwater structure when the incident waves interfere with the reflected waves a fluctuated synthetic water level is created which then impacts the total wave height in front of the breakwater structure hm0 f as the resonance waves are always larger than the incident waves it follows that as the incident waves increase so do the resonance waves this variation is expressed by the before construction wave coefficient kf which is determined by the ratio between the wave height before construction hm0 f and the incident wave height hm0 i according to the formula 1 k f h m 0 f h m 0 i fig 10 shows that when the breakwater works in the submerged condition the coefficient kf is small i e kf 1 1 2 this is because most of the waves pass through the breakwater crest when the breakwater works in the emerged condition the coefficient kf is typically equal to 1 1 4 and reaches a maximum value corresponding to rc hm0 1 5 this relationship shows that incident and reflected waves can interact with each other to create a high total wave that interacts with the prbw and this relationship should be taken into consideration when designing prbw constructions 2 4 3 equations describing the influence of factors on the wave transmission process when a wave impacts a porous breakwater one part of the wave energy will be reflected in front of the structure another part of the wave energy will be dissipated and absorbed and the rest of the wave energy will be transmitted through the back of the breakwater theoretically this hydrodynamic problem obeys the law of conservation of energy and can be expressed in mathematical form by the energy balance formula burcharth and hughes 1993 2 e i e t e r e d in which ei et er and ed are the energy of the incident wave the transmitted wave the reflected wave and the dissipated wave respectively this energy balance formula can be rewritten as follows 3 1 h t h i 2 h r h i 2 e d e i n r n r 4 1 k t 2 k r 2 k d 2 in which the wave transmission coefficient k t h m 0 t h m 0 i is determined by the height of transmitted wave behind the structure hm0 t over the height of the incident wave in front of the structure hm0 t the k r h m 0 r h m 0 i wave reflection coefficient is determined by the height of reflected wave in front of the structure over the height of the incident wave in front of the structure hm0 t finally the kd coefficient can be determined based on the results of formula 4 5 k d 2 1 k t 2 k r 2 2 4 4 influence of the breakwater crest freeboard the relative crest freeboard rc hm0 i plays the most important role in wave transmission with regard to coastal structures this relative crest freeboard rc hm0 i depends on the following factors water level d structure height h and incident wave height hm0 i it follows that the transmission coefficient quickly declines in a linear trend with the increase of the relative freeboard and becomes almost constant kt 0 30 when rc hm0 0 50 generally a wave has low transmission through the breakwater when there is high crest emergence on the other hand the breakwater structure is not effective in damping the wave transmission when it gets submerged i e kt 0 7 0 8 as rc hm0 0 50 the reflection coefficient is plotted against the relative freeboard in fig 11 which indicates that this breakwater is highly reflective particularly in the case when the crest emerges above the water level i e kr 0 45 0 60 reflection generally increases as rc hm0 increases as the breakwater structure is not sufficiently porous to absorb wave energy in the case of high crest emergence reflected waves reach maximum value when rc hm0 i 1 2 with kr 0 55 0 60 when rc hm0 i 2 as in the low water level case the reflected waves have a slight decrease due to the rip rap in front of the structure this rip rap serves as a preventative measure to reduce erosion and absorbs a part of the reflected waves in front of the breakwater structure the relationship between rc hm0 i and kt kr kd is shown clearly when 1 5 rc hm0 i 1 5 fig 11 this is because it is the transitional boundary between the emerged and the submerged state of the breakwater the wave transmission coefficient kt demonstrates an inverted relationship with respect to the relative crest freeboard while the coefficients of wave reflection and wave energy dissipation illustrate a covariate trend with respect to relative crest freeboard when the breakwater submerges rc 0 a large number of waves transmit through the breakwater leading to a large wave transmission coefficient and small coefficients of wave reflection and wave energy dissipation on the other hand as the breakwater emerges rc increases wave reflection and wave energy dissipation increase leading to a smaller wave transmission coefficient the breakwater emerges until the wave overflows its crest rc hm0 i 1 5 and then the relationship chart between rc hm0 i with kt kr kd is almost horizontal this proves that the relative crest freeboard is not influential to the coefficient this observed trend in fig 11 is in agreement with the earlier work on linear potential theory by liu 2012 the higher the relative crest freeboard the more the wave energy dissipates see fig 12 the reflected waves reach maximum value when rc hm0 i 1 2 and kr 0 5 0 56 when rc hm0 i 2 the reflected wave energy has a slight decrease due to the rip rap in front of the breakwater structure this rip rap prevents erosion and absorbs a part of the reflected wave energy in front of the structure at low water level fig 12 shows the percentage of transmitted reflected and dissipated wave energy through the prbw corresponding to a varying relative crest freeboard rc hm0 i we see that the smallest dissipated wave energy 26 corresponds to the prbw in the submerged state rc hm0 i 1 5 in the case of the largest transmitted wave energy 68 the reflected wave energy is the smallest 6 the value of the dissipated wave energy increases gradually when changing from submerged state to emerged state 58 we also see that the reflected wave energy also increases with this trend and the largest 32 corresponds to rc hm0 i 1 5 which has a decreased transmitted wave energy 10 as the relative crest freeboard continues to increase rc hm0 i 1 5 the wave energy dissipated continues to increase the transmitted wave energy decreases slightly almost unchanged by about 10 and the reflected wave energy decreases slightly 2 4 5 influence of the wave slope on the front of the breakwater structure the relationship between the slope of waves and the wave coefficients is considered based on sp in which sp is slope of the wave corresponding to the peak period of the spectra crest tp the slope of the wave in front of the breakwater structure has an inverted relationship with coefficients of wave transmission and wave reflection see fig 13 between the wave reflection coefficient and the wave transmission coefficient that are measured directly in experiment the sensitivity of the correlation between the slope of the wave in front of the structure to the wave transmission coefficient is higher than the wave reflection coefficient this is indicated in fig 13 by the angular coefficient a which is greater in the resulting correlation lines direct measurements from the experiments of the wave transmission and the wave reflection coefficients results in the formulation of the correlation between the wave dissipation coefficient and the slope of wave this is a covariate relationship as indicated by fig 13 where the effect of the slope of the wave on the coefficient of wave dissipation depends on the value of the crest freeboard rc the relationship between rc hm0 i and both the wave transmission coefficient kt and the coefficient of wave reflection kr with different periods of waves is shown in fig 14 the effect of changing the wave period on the coefficient of wave transmission tends to be clearer than the wave reflection coefficient in the three wave conditions of hs 8 cm 12 cm and 16 cm especially in the case where rc hm0 i 0 1 5 with the same experimental wave height the greater the periodic wave t 2 23s the greater the transmission coefficient and the reflection coefficient compared to the small period wave t 1 34s the trend of the changing of the kt wave transmission coefficient is the most clear in the cases corresponding to rc hm0 i 0 1 5 2 4 6 developing an experimental formula to describe the wave transmission through a pile rock breakwater the earlier analysis of parameters that influence wave transmission through prbws is the base for building an experimental formula to describe this process the experimental formula that we present is built based on the previously available formula of van der meer and daemen 1994 and angremond et al 1996 therefore the wave transmission coefficient and the wave reflection coefficient are effected by several main factors including the relative freeboard rc hm0 i and the slope of the waves so note that compared to angremond et al 1996 the crest width b is not present in our equation eq 6 since in this case the porous breakwater is considered a narrow crested type of structure in fact its effect is implicitly included the general experimental formula is shown as 6 k t f r c h m 0 i s p k t a r c h m 0 i b s p c where a b are experimental constants of effectiveness of the factors relative freeboard rc hm0 i slope of waves sp c is a featured constant of other factors that is not considered in this experiment a b and c are determined by regression analysis with the data of the corresponding variables obtained from the experimental results the values of a b and c in this formula are obtained from regression analysis of the experimental data results from the fitting of the formulation of wave transmission with the relative freeboard rc hm0 i and the slope of the waves so the values of a b c are calculated my maximizing the correlation coefficient r2 results of this analysis are shown in fig 15 and demonstrate that the r2 value reaches a maximum of 0 83 when a 0 167 b 4 172 c 0 634 the fitted negative values of a and b show that there is an inverted relationship between the relative freeboard and the slope of the waves so the result of the regression analysis method gives the corresponding formula 7 k t 0 167 r c h m 0 i 4 172 s 0 0 634 with the range of application of the formula corresponding to r c h m 0 i 1 49 1 48 s o 0 009 0 051 k t 0 28 0 84 3 wave transmission through pile rock breakwater from observation in the field 3 1 observational setup to calculate the effectiveness of wave reduction from a prbw in the field a measurement campaign was carried out at a prbw structure located along the ganh hao coastline from the 18 19th of february 2020 a north east monsoon dominant time period along the coastline of the mekong delta there are two main wind seasons and the east sea is influenced by the northeast monsoon from november to march next year the installed instruments to measure wave reduction include two wave gauges with code ossi 010 022 that were provided by ocean sensor systems inc usa the locations of the installed equipment are approximately 30 m in front of and behind the prbw the measuring instrument locations on the front side of the prbw instrument sn001 and on the rear side of the prbw instrument sn002 at ganh hao are illustrated in fig 16 3 2 analysis of the results and comparison with experimental laboratory results the relationship between the wave height h1 3 and the wave period t1 3 from the field measured data is shown in fig 17 the observed wave height h1 3 ranges from 0 09 m to 0 81 m and the wave period values ranged from 3 04 s to 7 72 s analyzing the results we see that there is a positive trend between h1 3 and t1 3 when h1 3 0 4 m and in this range the wave period increases from 3 s to 7 s however when h1 3 0 4 m and h1 3 increases from 0 4 m to 0 8 m the wave period has only a slight variation around a value of t1 3 7 s indicated by the red line in fig 17 this stabilizing of the t1 3 is an indication that the wave threshold and the wave characteristic in this region has fully reached its maximum value the similarity in the shape of the wave spectrum between the observed field measurements and the laboratory experimental data is shown in fig 18 at the location before the construction the blue line the wave spectrum has a peak shape of power spectrum with a high energy distribution within frequency range of 0 1 0 16 hz in the field observations fig 18a and a frequency range of 0 5 1 0 hz in the laboratory experiments fig 18b note that in both cases there are some other frequency bands with smaller energy distributions at the location behind construction the red line the wave spectrum is flattened and the frequency bands are larger than is typical with a very small power spectrum due to the energy dissipation process when the wave transmits through the breakwater interestingly the appearance of gravity waves i e infragravity waves is also found in both field measurement and experimental data with frequency ranges from 0 006 hz to 0 02 hz see fig 18 the measured wave spectra as shown in fig 18 at a location on the foreshore instruments wg4 and sn002 clearly exhibits multiple peaks and flattens as the wave increases low frequency or infragravity waves are present and generated by the breaking processes of short period waves on the shallow foreshore as noted by baldock 2012 alternatively forced bound long waves induced by wave grouping are also released as free infragravity waves at the breaking points of the gravity waves the existence of these infragravity waves is probably inherent to the wave dynamics on a shallow foreshore as short gravity waves break the relative importance of infragravity waves start to increase this trend is in agreement with the earlier study performed by baldock 2012 fig 19 shows the results of analyzing the transmission coefficient between the field measurement and the laboratory experiment the results show that the transmission coefficient kt is similar in both the trends and the variable values in relation to the relative crest freeboard rc hi the transmission coefficient kt through the breakwater ranges from 0 26 to 0 56 corresponding to the rc hi value varying from 0 to 1 4 in the field measurements notably the wave transmission coefficient obtained from field measurement tends to be smaller than those derived from the laboratory experiment this difference may be due to the influence of the model ratio and other factors that impact the field measurement moreover the physical model reproduces wave propagation in two dimensions with a scale of 1 5 however the field measurement results are three dimensional and the ratio is 1 1 4 conclusions and recommendations pile rock breakwaters show significant potential to reduce erosion and rehabilitate mangrove forests in the vmd prbws have significant advantages over other styles of breakwaters these advantages include a reduced deadweight of construction materials and additional stability when compared to traditional trapezoidal breakwaters based on previous research that focused on prbw the main objective of this study was to better understand the hydraulic performance of prbws by analyzing the results from performing a series of physical model wave transmission experiments to address this objective this study has built a physical model to test hydraulic performance and wave transmission through prbw in the laboratory and compared with observations in the field the wave transmission process through the prbw is influenced by two important factors the relative crest freeboard rc hm0 and the slope of waves the results from the wave transmission through a prbw from observations in the laboratory showed the following 1 the short wave energy is mostly dissipated or reflected and that the waves behind the prbw are mostly long wave energy 2 the prbw structure works effectively with the wave transmission coefficient kt 0 3 0 4 when the breakwater works in the emerged state 3 the effect of the slope of the wave on the wave transmission coefficient is clearer than the wave reflection coefficient following the observations in the laboratory an experimental formula to describe the wave transmission through a prwb was developed and then applied to observations in the field this allowed the development of a relationship diagram between the transmission coefficient kt and the relative crest freeboard rc hi in both the experimental data and the field measured data the results indicate a high reliability for further design of prbws in addition to this relationship the experimental and measured results both showed the emergence of and increase of gravity waves the results from this work provide direction on the future design process of prbws firstly particular attention should be paid to the case of a high wave reflection coefficient kr 0 45 0 56 secondly in the case of an emerged breakwater special attention must be paid to the design of toe scour protection and for the case when the wave height before the prbw hm0 f is larger than the incident wave height hm0 i when this is 1 1 4 times larger this needs to be considered carefully to calculate the stability and the structure of the prbw future investigations related to prbws will need to consider the additional complexity of analyzing the complex wave energy dissipation by permeable breakwaters in addition to this future work will need to investigate variables that were not considered in this study including the influence of the width of the breakwater s crest and influence of the size of the rocks in the prbw on the wave transmission coefficient declaration of competing interest the authors declare that they have no known competing financial interests or personal relationships that could have appeared to influence the work reported in this paper acknowledgments this stabilize the coastline and estuaries of the mekong river from tien giang to soc trang and the southern institute of water resources research the authors greatly appreciate the editor and also deeply thank the three anonymous reviewers for their constructive comments to improve the manuscript
