this style of breakwater is applicable for broader application across the soft soil foundation across the coast of the vmd a range of studies have considered the effectiveness of prbws for example nguyen huu nhan 2015 applied a coupled modelling of hydrodynamics and spectral sea wave on shallow water to evaluate the effectiveness of a prbw on the west sea of ca mau the results from this study showed high effectiveness of the prbw for aiding alluvial accumulation preventing rip circulation and wave action and protecting the coastline and mangrove belt liu 2012 applied linear potential theory to analyze the wave absorption of prbws the results from this study showed the relationship between wave transmission reflection and dissipation coefficients when the wave interacts with this a prbw but they did not validate their results with physical model experiments furthermore herbich 1998 conducted experiments to predict the transformation of waves passing through closely spaced pile or large cylinder breakwaters several researchers have conducted experiments and numerical modelling to reproduce the hydrodynamic near field processes and the vortex generation and dissipation by applying the reynolds averaged navier stokes rans equations for low crested permeable breakwaters garcia et al 2004 hsu et al 2004 martinelli et al 2006 this rans model has the ability to reproduce the near field flow characteristics around low crested structures moreover hur 2004 and hur et al 2011 investigated the effect of the slope gradient of submerged breakwaters by using a three dimensional numerical model and a three dimensional wave basin for their experiments johnson et al 2005 and johnson 2006 conducted research to study waves currents and wave breaking around submerged breakwaters and verified their results with three dimensional wave basin experiments and wave flume experiments at aalborg university denmark and the university of cantabria spain kramer et al 2005 respectively the results from these studies showed that the mike 21 model offers some confidence in the ability of the models to reproduce waves and currents of submerged breakwaters more recently ha 2019 undertook research on analytical and numerical analysis for the stability of prbw that are subjected to combined loading the authors of this study developed a method to calculate the bearing capacity of the prbw on soft clay soils this investigation of wave performance was not a comprehensive analysis in the contest of the west coast vmd and the research was mainly based on applying a formula for conventional rubble mound breakwaters that was not suitable to be applied to prbws based on the previous research on prbws the main objective of this study is to better understand the hydraulic performance of this type of breakwaters by analyzing the results from performing a series of physical model wave transmission experiments the specific objectives of this study are to 1 propose innovative structures of prbw that are both suitable for the soft soil foundation and also have a fast construction process that has the potential to save concrete and rubble construction materials in the vmd 2 determine the wave reduction transmission and dissipation coefficients through these prbws 3 develop an experimental formula for wave transmission to inform future design and construction of prwbs to address these specific objectives this paper is structured as follows in section 2 we describe the experimental setup and results of investigating wave transmission through a prbw based on observations in the laboratory in section 3 we then validate the experimental results by investigating wave transmission through prbw from observations in the field finally in section 4 we make conclusions from both the laboratory experiments as well as the observations in the field and provide recommendations for future work 2 wave transmission through prbw from observations in the laboratory in this section we first introduce the experimental model configuration followed by more details on the flume setup and instrumentation in the laboratory we then present the experimental scenarios explored and finish with a discussion of the experimental results 2 1 model configuration the in situ dimensions of the designed prbw structure were collected during a project that investigated coastal protection works in the vmd in 2017 the type of pile used in this structure is a pre stressed concrete pile with a diameter of 30 cm length of 8 m and a width crest of 2 6 m as indicated in the longitudinal cross section see fig 3 there is a row of piles with spacing of 30 cm between each pile in addition to the piles this prbw structure used rock rubble with dimensions of approximately 25 35 cm the cross section a a in fig 3 shows the melaleuca mattresses and geo textile layer below the rocks as well as the vertical beams 50 30 cm and the horizontal beam 30 30 cm above the rocks to fit the prbw into the wave flume in the laboratory the dimensions of the model structure were scaled to 1 5 of the in situ size the maximum model scale was selected based on the ability of the wave flume to house the breakwater and the boundary conditions of the experiment the model scale was selected as the following nl 5 scale of length and height n t n l 2 24 scale of time n v n l 2 24 scale of velocity and nm n3 l 125 scale of mass the dimensions of the actual breakwater and the model breakwater considered in this study are described in table 1 according to the designed parameters of the actual structure the rubbles had a grade of dn 25 35 cm the experimental rubbles grade is calculated from the model scale and is specified in table 2 the experimental rubbles grade is sieved according to laboratory standards to ensure consistency in the dimensions porosity and overall similarity in front of the structure there is rip rap which prevents erosion at a 7 cm height equal to 2 layers of rubble and is 50 cm wide fig 4 2 2 flume setup and instrumentation the experiments were carried out in the wave flume at the river and marine hydrodynamic laboratory of the southern institute of water resources research binh duong province vietnam the experimental equipment was installed by hr wallingford the flume is 35 m long effective 1 2 m wide and 1 5 m high it is equipped with an automated system of active reflection compensation arc and is capable of generating both regular and irregular waves up to 0 3 m in height and 3 s in peak period fig 4 reliable resistance type wave gauges have the ability to measure wave signals at a sampling frequency up to 100 hz accuracy 0 1 mm the single piston paddle long crested wavemaker has a width of 1 2 m the maximum water depth in the flume is 1 0 m and the maximum wave height is 0 6 m corresponding to a period of 2 0 s the wave flume setup has two wave absorbers that are separated by a thick foam sheet at the wave generator side and a trapezoidal prism of rubbles and gravel in rear side the remaining energy after the wave passes through the breakwater after 90 of the total wave energy is absorbed is absorbed by the rubble absorber the reflected wave energy from the paddle is absorbed after 95 of the total wave energy is absorbed by the thick foam sheet it is important to note that in the vmd the wave height in the southwest monsoon is largest in the deep water of the study area and is about 1 1 5 m with a period of 3 6 s the experiments in this study are instead built under the assumption that wave conditions are under medium weather conditions without storms the boundary conditions of the wave parameters were generated by the joint north sea wave observation project jonswap spectra with a γ value of 3 30 which was validated by the agence française de développement afd project the selection of featured wave parameters is based on various research of wave observation in the vmd by the southern institute of water resources research siwrr and is combined with wave transmission derived from a numerical model wave parameters in the front and behind the breakwater were measured with 6 capacitance wave gauges incident and reflected waves were separated by using 4 gauges with software processing in wave measurement by the hr wallingford system the wave gauge system to measure water level fluctuation included the following wave probes calibration stems calibration pins wave probe tripod stands twin wire cables and a wave probe monitor the wave height measurable range of this system was 300 mm the output signal was 10 v accuracy was 0 1 mm and internal noise limiting filter was 3 db at 20 hz signal bandwidth four gauges were installed in front of the breakwater wg1 2 3 4 and were used for measuring the incident wave and to separate the reflected wave and the incident wave in front of the breakwater two gauges were installed behind the breakwater wg5 6 and were used to determine the height of the wave passing through the breakwater each of the experiments lasted approximately 500 tp s to adequately produce the main frequency domain of the desired wave spectra the locations of wave gauges are described in the experiment layout illustrated in fig 5 2 3 experimental scenarios to investigate the wave transmission through the prbw 78 scenarios were used including 6 scenarios for changing water level and crest freeboard rc and 13 scenarios for changing wave parameters hs tp l the experimental scenarios are shown in detail in table 3 the water levels corresponding to the experimental scenarios considered are shown in fig 6 2 4 results and discussion wave transmission through prbws is generally a function of relative crest freeboard crest width breakwater slope porosity permeability and wave characteristics van der meer and daemen 1994 angremond et al 1996 in this study we analyzed the experimental data to formulate an empirical equation for wave transmission and examined the effects on wave transmission of the most influential parameters including the relative crest freeboard and the wave slope other secondary parameters implicitly included in this study are the crest width and the porosity of the prbw 2 4 1 change in the wave spectra and the wave period before and after the breakwater the changes in the wave spectra after passing the breakwater are show in fig 7 the wg4 and wg5 gauges indicate the recorded wave signal in front of and after the construction respectively fig 7 provides a visual representation of an important characteristic of the wave hydrodynamics for prbw and it is clear that the wave amplitude in front of the breakwater is significantly higher than the amplitude after transmitting through the breakwater the spectral transformation across the breakwater with a high crest emergence rc 0 and submergence rc 0 are illustrated in fig 8 logically wave energy considerably dissipates when the crest of the breakwater has an emergence of rc 0 see fig 8b than when the crest of breakwater has submergence with rc 0 see fig 8d in the submergence situation rc 0 the wave arrives in front of the structure with high energy of 7 10 3 m2 hz see fig 8c and after the wave transmits through the breakwater the energy is still high and equivalent to 2 10 3 m2 hz with a range of frequency within 0 5 1 hz see fig 8d the energy for both the emergence and the submergence case in front of structure are approximately the same comparing fig 8a c channel 4 this is not the case however after the breakwater where the differences in the energy spectra distribution for the emergence and the submergence cases are significant see fig 8b d this result occurs due to the wave energy being dissipated or reflected when the waves interact with the breakwater structure under the emergence case the changes about the peak period of the spectra crest tp and period of t1 3 of the measured waves in front of and behind the structure are shown in fig 9 the trend illustrates that the period of t1 3 has a significant change when comparing the peak period of spectra tp in front of and behind the breakwater structure behind the structure t1 3 has a trend of becoming larger than in front of the structure see deviation from the 1 1 line while tp has no significant change follows the 1 1 line this relationship is consistent with the theory of wave spectra analysis the reason this occurs is that the waves have a shorter period when dissipated after interacting with structure only long waves transmit through the structure because their t1 3 behind the structure are bigger than those in front of the structure this observed trend agrees with earlier studies by liu 2012 and dhinakaran 2011 the changes of wave period in front of and behind the breakwater structure have noticeable differences when considering either the case of the emerged breakwater rc 0 and the case of the submerged breakwater rc 0 with period wave spectra tm see fig 9 right panel in the case of the emerged breakwater the tm behind the structure has a larger trend than those in front of the structure this behavior is vice versa in the case of the submerged breakwater in the case of rc 0 the breakwater with crest width structure b 1 4lm min and b 1 10lm max works for wave transmission in the shallow water region however the crest width of the prbw is not large enough for waves to break on in the observable laboratory experiments the effect of shallow water makes the waves periods behind the structure reduce in comparison with those in front of the structure 2 4 2 change of wave height in front of the breakwater structure the fluctuation of water level in front of the structure increases due to the influence of wave reflection created from the interaction of the incident waves and the breakwater structure when the incident waves interfere with the reflected waves a fluctuated synthetic water level is created which then impacts the total wave height in front of the breakwater structure hm0 f as the resonance waves are always larger than the incident waves it follows that as the incident waves increase so do the resonance waves this variation is expressed by the before construction wave coefficient kf which is determined by the ratio between the wave height before construction hm0 f and the incident wave height hm0 i according to the formula 1 k f h m 0 f h m 0 i fig 10 shows that when the breakwater works in the submerged condition the coefficient kf is small i e kf 1 1 2 this is because most of the waves pass through the breakwater crest when the breakwater works in the emerged condition the coefficient kf is typically equal to 1 1 4 and reaches a maximum value corresponding to rc hm0 1 5 this relationship shows that incident and reflected waves can interact with each other to create a high total wave that interacts with the prbw and this relationship should be taken into consideration when designing prbw constructions 2 4 3 equations describing the influence of factors on the wave transmission process when a wave impacts a porous breakwater one part of the wave energy will be reflected in front of the structure another part of the wave energy will be dissipated and absorbed and the rest of the wave energy will be transmitted through the back of the breakwater theoretically this hydrodynamic problem obeys the law of conservation of energy and can be expressed in mathematical form by the energy balance formula burcharth and hughes 1993 2 e i e t e r e d in which ei et er and ed are the energy of the incident wave the transmitted wave the reflected wave and the dissipated wave respectively this energy balance formula can be rewritten as follows 3 1 h t h i 2 h r h i 2 e d e i n r n r 4 1 k t 2 k r 2 k d 2 in which the wave transmission coefficient k t h m 0 t h m 0 i is determined by the height of transmitted wave behind the structure hm0 t over the height of the incident wave in front of the structure hm0 t the k r h m 0 r h m 0 i wave reflection coefficient is determined by the height of reflected wave in front of the structure over the height of the incident wave in front of the structure hm0 t finally the kd coefficient can be determined based on the results of formula 4 5 k d 2 1 k t 2 k r 2 2 4 4 influence of the breakwater crest freeboard the relative crest freeboard rc hm0 i plays the most important role in wave transmission with regard to coastal structures this relative crest freeboard rc hm0 i depends on the following factors water level d structure height h and incident wave height hm0 i it follows that the transmission coefficient quickly declines in a linear trend with the increase of the relative freeboard and becomes almost constant kt 0 30 when rc hm0 0 50 generally a wave has low transmission through the breakwater when there is high crest emergence on the other hand the breakwater structure is not effective in damping the wave transmission when it gets submerged i e kt 0 7 0 8 as rc hm0 0 50 the reflection coefficient is plotted against the relative freeboard in fig 11 which indicates that this breakwater is highly reflective particularly in the case when the crest emerges above the water level i e kr 0 45 0 60 reflection generally increases as rc hm0 increases as the breakwater structure is not sufficiently porous to absorb wave energy in the case of high crest emergence reflected waves reach maximum value when rc hm0 i 1 2 with kr 0 55 0 60 when rc hm0 i 2 as in the low water level case the reflected waves have a slight decrease due to the rip rap in front of the structure this rip rap serves as a preventative measure to reduce erosion and absorbs a part of the reflected waves in front of the breakwater structure the relationship between rc hm0 i and kt kr kd is shown clearly when 1 5 rc hm0 i 1 5 fig 11 this is because it is the transitional boundary between the emerged and the submerged state of the breakwater the wave transmission coefficient kt demonstrates an inverted relationship with respect to the relative crest freeboard while the coefficients of wave reflection and wave energy dissipation illustrate a covariate trend with respect to relative crest freeboard when the breakwater submerges rc 0 a large number of waves transmit through the breakwater leading to a large wave transmission coefficient and small coefficients of wave reflection and wave energy dissipation on the other hand as the breakwater emerges rc increases wave reflection and wave energy dissipation increase leading to a smaller wave transmission coefficient the breakwater emerges until the wave overflows its crest rc hm0 i 1 5 and then the relationship chart between rc hm0 i with kt kr kd is almost horizontal this proves that the relative crest freeboard is not influential to the coefficient this observed trend in fig 11 is in agreement with the earlier work on linear potential theory by liu 2012 the higher the relative crest freeboard the more the wave energy dissipates see fig 12 the reflected waves reach maximum value when rc hm0 i 1 2 and kr 0 5 0 56 when rc hm0 i 2 the reflected wave energy has a slight decrease due to the rip rap in front of the breakwater structure this rip rap prevents erosion and absorbs a part of the reflected wave energy in front of the structure at low water level fig 12 shows the percentage of transmitted reflected and dissipated wave energy through the prbw corresponding to a varying relative crest freeboard rc hm0 i we see that the smallest dissipated wave energy 26 corresponds to the prbw in the submerged state rc hm0 i 1 5 in the case of the largest transmitted wave energy 68 the reflected wave energy is the smallest 6 the value of the dissipated wave energy increases gradually when changing from submerged state to emerged state 58 we also see that the reflected wave energy also increases with this trend and the largest 32 corresponds to rc hm0 i 1 5 which has a decreased transmitted wave energy 10 as the relative crest freeboard continues to increase rc hm0 i 1 5 the wave energy dissipated continues to increase the transmitted wave energy decreases slightly almost unchanged by about 10 and the reflected wave energy decreases slightly 2 4 5 influence of the wave slope on the front of the breakwater structure the relationship between the slope of waves and the wave coefficients is considered based on sp in which sp is slope of the wave corresponding to the peak period of the spectra crest tp the slope of the wave in front of the breakwater structure has an inverted relationship with coefficients of wave transmission and wave reflection see fig 13 between the wave reflection coefficient and the wave transmission coefficient that are measured directly in experiment the sensitivity of the correlation between the slope of the wave in front of the structure to the wave transmission coefficient is higher than the wave reflection coefficient this is indicated in fig 13 by the angular coefficient a which is greater in the resulting correlation lines direct measurements from the experiments of the wave transmission and the wave reflection coefficients results in the formulation of the correlation between the wave dissipation coefficient and the slope of wave this is a covariate relationship as indicated by fig 13 where the effect of the slope of the wave on the coefficient of wave dissipation depends on the value of the crest freeboard rc the relationship between rc hm0 i and both the wave transmission coefficient kt and the coefficient of wave reflection kr with different periods of waves is shown in fig 14 the effect of changing the wave period on the coefficient of wave transmission tends to be clearer than the wave reflection coefficient in the three wave conditions of hs 8 cm 12 cm and 16 cm especially in the case where rc hm0 i 0 1 5 with the same experimental wave height the greater the periodic wave t 2 23s the greater the transmission coefficient and the reflection coefficient compared to the small period wave t 1 34s the trend of the changing of the kt wave transmission coefficient is the most clear in the cases corresponding to rc hm0 i 0 1 5 2 4 6 developing an experimental formula to describe the wave transmission through a pile rock breakwater the earlier analysis of parameters that influence wave transmission through prbws is the base for building an experimental formula to describe this process the experimental formula that we present is built based on the previously available formula of van der meer and daemen 1994 and angremond et al 1996 therefore the wave transmission coefficient and the wave reflection coefficient are effected by several main factors including the relative freeboard rc hm0 i and the slope of the waves so note that compared to angremond et al 1996 the crest width b is not present in our equation eq 6 since in this case the porous breakwater is considered a narrow crested type of structure in fact its effect is implicitly included the general experimental formula is shown as 6 k t f r c h m 0 i s p k t a r c h m 0 i b s p c where a b are experimental constants of effectiveness of the factors relative freeboard rc hm0 i slope of waves sp c is a featured constant of other factors that is not considered in this experiment a b and c are determined by regression analysis with the data of the corresponding variables obtained from the experimental results the values of a b and c in this formula are obtained from regression analysis of the experimental data results from the fitting of the formulation of wave transmission with the relative freeboard rc hm0 i and the slope of the waves so the values of a b c are calculated my maximizing the correlation coefficient r2 results of this analysis are shown in fig 15 and demonstrate that the r2 value reaches a maximum of 0 83 when a 0 167 b 4 172 c 0 634 the fitted negative values of a and b show that there is an inverted relationship between the relative freeboard and the slope of the waves so the result of the regression analysis method gives the corresponding formula 7 k t 0 167 r c h m 0 i 4 172 s 0 0 634 with the range of application of the formula corresponding to r c h m 0 i 1 49 1 48 s o 0 009 0 051 k t 0 28 0 84 3 wave transmission through pile rock breakwater from observation in the field 3 1 observational setup to calculate the effectiveness of wave reduction from a prbw in the field a measurement campaign was carried out at a prbw structure located along the ganh hao coastline from the 18 19th of february 2020 a north east monsoon dominant time period along the coastline of the mekong delta there are two main wind seasons and the east sea is influenced by the northeast monsoon from november to march next year the installed instruments to measure wave reduction include two wave gauges with code ossi 010 022 that were provided by ocean sensor systems inc usa the locations of the installed equipment are approximately 30 m in front of and behind the prbw the measuring instrument locations on the front side of the prbw instrument sn001 and on the rear side of the prbw instrument sn002 at ganh hao are illustrated in fig 16 3 2 analysis of the results and comparison with experimental laboratory results the relationship between the wave height h1 3 and the wave period t1 3 from the field measured data is shown in fig 17 the observed wave height h1 3 ranges from 0 09 m to 0 81 m and the wave period values ranged from 3 04 s to 7 72 s analyzing the results we see that there is a positive trend between h1 3 and t1 3 when h1 3 0 4 m and in this range the wave period increases from 3 s to 7 s however when h1 3 0 4 m and h1 3 increases from 0 4 m to 0 8 m the wave period has only a slight variation around a value of t1 3 7 s indicated by the red line in fig 17 this stabilizing of the t1 3 is an indication that the wave threshold and the wave characteristic in this region has fully reached its maximum value the similarity in the shape of the wave spectrum between the observed field measurements and the laboratory experimental data is shown in fig 18 at the location before the construction the blue line the wave spectrum has a peak shape of power spectrum with a high energy distribution within frequency range of 0 1 0 16 hz in the field observations fig 18a and a frequency range of 0 5 1 0 hz in the laboratory experiments fig 18b note that in both cases there are some other frequency bands with smaller energy distributions at the location behind construction the red line the wave spectrum is flattened and the frequency bands are larger than is typical with a very small power spectrum due to the energy dissipation process when the wave transmits through the breakwater interestingly the appearance of gravity waves i e infragravity waves is also found in both field measurement and experimental data with frequency ranges from 0 006 hz to 0 02 hz see fig 18 the measured wave spectra as shown in fig 18 at a location on the foreshore instruments wg4 and sn002 clearly exhibits multiple peaks and flattens as the wave increases low frequency or infragravity waves are present and generated by the breaking processes of short period waves on the shallow foreshore as noted by baldock 2012 alternatively forced bound long waves induced by wave grouping are also released as free infragravity waves at the breaking points of the gravity waves the existence of these infragravity waves is probably inherent to the wave dynamics on a shallow foreshore as short gravity waves break the relative importance of infragravity waves start to increase this trend is in agreement with the earlier study performed by baldock 2012 fig 19 shows the results of analyzing the transmission coefficient between the field measurement and the laboratory experiment the results show that the transmission coefficient kt is similar in both the trends and the variable values in relation to the relative crest freeboard rc hi the transmission coefficient kt through the breakwater ranges from 0 26 to 0 56 corresponding to the rc hi value varying from 0 to 1 4 in the field measurements notably the wave transmission coefficient obtained from field measurement tends to be smaller than those derived from the laboratory experiment this difference may be due to the influence of the model ratio and other factors that impact the field measurement moreover the physical model reproduces wave propagation in two dimensions with a scale of 1 5 however the field measurement results are three dimensional and the ratio is 1 1 4 conclusions and recommendations pile rock breakwaters show significant potential to reduce erosion and rehabilitate mangrove forests in the vmd prbws have significant advantages over other styles of breakwaters these advantages include a reduced deadweight of construction materials and additional stability when compared to traditional trapezoidal breakwaters based on previous research that focused on prbw the main objective of this study was to better understand the hydraulic performance of prbws by analyzing the results from performing a series of physical model wave transmission experiments to address this objective this study has built a physical model to test hydraulic performance and wave transmission through prbw in the laboratory and compared with observations in the field the wave transmission process through the prbw is influenced by two important factors the relative crest freeboard rc hm0 and the slope of waves the results from the wave transmission through a prbw from observations in the laboratory showed the following 1 the short wave energy is mostly dissipated or reflected and that the waves behind the prbw are mostly long wave energy 2 the prbw structure works effectively with the wave transmission coefficient kt 0 3 0 4 when the breakwater works in the emerged state 3 the effect of the slope of the wave on the wave transmission coefficient is clearer than the wave reflection coefficient following the observations in the laboratory an experimental formula to describe the wave transmission through a prwb was developed and then applied to observations in the field this allowed the development of a relationship diagram between the transmission coefficient kt and the relative crest freeboard rc hi in both the experimental data and the field measured data the results indicate a high reliability for further design of prbws in addition to this relationship the experimental and measured results both showed the emergence of and increase of gravity waves the results from this work provide direction on the future design process of prbws firstly particular attention should be paid to the case of a high wave reflection coefficient kr 0 45 0 56 secondly in the case of an emerged breakwater special attention must be paid to the design of toe scour protection and for the case when the wave height before the prbw hm0 f is larger than the incident wave height hm0 i when this is 1 1 4 times larger this needs to be considered carefully to calculate the stability and the structure of the prbw future investigations related to prbws will need to consider the additional complexity of analyzing the complex wave energy dissipation by permeable breakwaters in addition to this future work will need to investigate variables that were not considered in this study including the influence of the width of the breakwater s crest and influence of the size of the rocks in the prbw on the wave transmission coefficient declaration of competing interest the authors declare that they have no known competing financial interests or personal relationships that could have appeared to influence the work reported in this paper acknowledgments this work was partially supported by the ministry of science and technology most vietnam in a national project no đtđl cn 07 17 research appropriate solutions and applicable technologies to prevent erosion stabilize the coastline and estuaries of the mekong river from tien giang to soc trang and the southern institute of water resources research the authors greatly appreciate the editor and also deeply thank the three anonymous reviewers for their constructive comments to improve the manuscript

this paper presents a spacing configuration based energy saving optimization approach for a pair of auvs to achieve minimum resistance through the hull forms and propeller interactions the traveling resistance is relevant to hull lines optimization design which uncertainties exist in design variables need to be considered seriously a reliability analysis based on the first order reliability method demonstrates that the engineering quality is not acceptable thus the design for six sigma was performed with uncertainty optimization to improve the design levels two body force models rans ut and rans ho were used to represent the propeller as an axial and a tangential momentum source term the results highlight that the radial thrust distribution has a significant impact of the propeller performance for a pair of auvs the energy consumption of the fleet is classified into six zones depending on the spacing configurations with a longitudinal offset and transverse separation this study details and categorizes the relevant sources of the drag reduction and provides the most effective fleet configuration for the optimal energy profits to validate previous experimental results based on energy considerations the optimal fleet configuration is determined to show excellent adaptability and reliability to provide insights for decision makers keywords twin auvs reliability based optimization design design for six sigma dfss body force model spacing configurations fleet energy 1 introduction autonomous underwater vehicles auvs are controlled remotely using integrated actuation systems without external power or umbilical transmission during a mission the operation commands are often not limited to a single hull the members cooperate to perform certain tasks such as pipeline inspection fernandes et al 2015 mine hunting nguyen et al 2014 and deep ocean exploration zhou et al 2011 caiti et al 2014 while maintaining a geometric formation however there is finite incentive to consume less than the vehicle s total useful energy capacity instead of making full use of the energy this is because the propulsion costs are likely to increase the holistic energy costs this has led to increments in the energy consumption of vehicles which should be mitigated when the auv moves without a formation energy consumption may be reduced using the optimum hull form that is required to minimize the traveling resistance joung et al 2009 yan et al 2013 from a practical perspective there could be different sources of uncertainties in a problem e g environmental factors design variables performance estimates if the uncertainty of these parameters is frequently neglected this leads to products with a low robustness and potential hidden dangers in the design process as a result the results can cause a large deviation after continuous iteration and mutual coupling hence the uncertainty of the problem has to be considered by limiting the parameters with the means of probabilistic distributions and spatial variations then the optimal criteria are used for the optimization design in this context diez and peri 2010 takes the lead in setting the uncertainty parameters for the ship design to achieve a robust solution the robust design optimization rdo approach has been developed to solve single objective minimization problems such as those of the shell design diez and peri 2012 wave response papanikolaou et al 2014 and the velocity disturbance xia and shao 2014 with the advent of reliability based concept design there has also been an increased focus on the application of the reliability based design rbd hannapel and vlahopoulos 2010 this ensures that the optimal solution will satisfy the constraints in the presence of the uncertainty within a prescribed reliability level further computational efficiency in any stage during ship shell development is ensured using the first order reliability method form yang et al 2012 for estimating the reliability however this method is generally used to solve higher order equations otherwise it loses its assessment accuracy in some applications choi and yoo 2012 to replace the expensive functions during the optimization for shortening the computational time the subject of developing the approximation models hannapel 2012 related to the uncertainties is rational the design of experiment doe technique was developed to acquire the performance information which is quite useful for the ship design aldous et al 2015 recently based on estimation methods for the engineering design of distribution parameters the accuracy of the performance has been improved by extending the doe these methods include the taguchi method tm zheng et al 2016 monte carlo methods mcm hou et al 2018 and the response surface methodology rsm lafifi et al 2019 to satisfy the increasing demand for quality the design for six sigma dfss koziotek and derlukiewicz 2012 was presented to reduce the variability results to obtain higher productivity and quality and avoid potential defects dfss can effectively ensure that the quality level reaches 6σ which is widely used in several engineering design fields in the aspect of beginning the ship design this reflects the filtered data of the dfss which has more reliability for the environmental disturbance hou et al 2018 in addition a part of the energy benefit is contributed by the propulsive efficiency which has been enhanced likewise the hydrodynamic performance on the propeller is an influential factor stevenson et al 2007 phillips et al 2008 hough and ordway 1965 introduced the body force model to prescribe the thrust and moment distributions based on the radial circulation distributions the interactions of the rotating propeller which induce the axial and swirl accelerations in the fluid acting on the propeller are considered to be the source terms depending on the coupling method used with the reynolds averaged navier stokes rans equations the rans ut and rans ho models were developed to calculate the viscous flow over the stern by performing simulations phillips et al 2010a the results can be used to reveal the hydrodynamic behaviors in the same way as the experimental results a series of studies has been performed over a range of operational reynolds numbers to investigate the influence of the propeller race on the towed prolate spheroids and the self propelled auvs phillips et al 2010 rattanasiri et al 2012 2012a 2014 for a fleet of auvs the energy consumption consists of the individual energy cost of a single hull and the entire loss is related to the total drag variations in recent years many experiments suggest that the drag of a single hull is reduced for the specific fleet formation that is based on the spacing between the members in contrast the fleet energy profits can be promoted by ameliorating the individual drag reduction positively to some extent rattanasiri et al 2013 2015 afterwards molland and utama 2002 proposed the fleet configuration concept although not completely unified this concept distinguishes two standard spacing references namely the transverse separation s l and the longitudinal offset d l the main problem is that it is very unitary to perform the formation scheme when the energy changes preclude the propeller s effect at least for the unified hull dimension in fact the performance of the individual auv is determined by its hull shape which considerable influences the fleet energy benefit liang et al 2017 in summary the concept of fleet energy consumption is introduced as a drag reduction index that consists of three aspects and the overall procedures can be described as shown in fig 1 minimal energy consumption of an individual auv is required to minimize the single resistance obtained from the optimal hull shape the influence of propulsion is considered to obtain the complete drag for an independent auv which is achieved by predicting the hydrodynamic performance of the propeller by coupling the interactions between the hull and the propeller this study was extended to investigate the combined drag reduction of a fleet dominated by the spacing between members this study aims to provide guidance for operators for developing an energy saving approach for multiple auvs with various spacing configurations the auv hull lines are assumed to have a nystrom axial symmetry revolution body with uncertainty parameters based on the datcom formula the traveling resistance is obtained by establishing a deterministic design optimization dod model using the multi island genetic algorithm miga the first order reliability method form is employed to assess the reliability that corresponds to the levels of risks in the uncertainties thereby using dfss technology to improve the quality for the ship design optimization considering the influence of the thrust and torque two body force models rans ut and rans ho are used in simulations to predict the propeller self propulsion factors the energy consumption of the auvs fleet is defined as the index of the drag reduction which depends upon the transverse separation and the longitudinal offset the dominant spacing has been classified into six regions to investigate the effect of the various configurations on the energy budget 2 bare hull study 2 1 nystrom shape assumed in hull nystrom 1863 proposed the mathematical formula of the regular axial symmetry revolution body the head shape can be determined by rotating an ellipse around the main axis and the tail shape is formed by rotating a parabola around a straight line perpendicular to the directrix the nystrom type auv is composed of three parts the fore body the parallel middle body and the after body the implementation of the hull lines is controlled using six adjustable design parameters the formula of the hull shape is shown in eq 1 1 f o r e b o d y s h a p e y s x d 2 1 x s l s n s 1 n s a f t e r b o d y s h a p e y w x d 2 1 x w l w 1 n w where d is the middle body diameter a l s d is the fore body curve design parameter b l p d is the parallel middle body curve design parameter c l w d is the after body curve design parameter n s is the shape index of the fore body curve and n w is the shape index of the after body curve these six adjustable design parameters control the curves length and shape x is the distance from the vertex of bow l s is the fore body length l p is the cylinder length l w is the after body length x s and x w are the distance from the maximum radius of the fore body and the after body respectively the main properties of the nystrom auv are described in fig 2 2 2 resistance estimation method in regard to the research on the axial symmetry revolution body for expressing the auv hull shape the sailing resistance is calculated using an empirical formula computational fluid dynamics cfd and a model experiment the real environment is established artificially which leads to a high cost and a long period when employing the test model similarly when using the cfd method fast calculation results can be achieved only on high collocation computer hardware systems which are relatively expensive compared with the aforementioned methods the cost can be significantly reduced by using the empirical formula however the error is critical even though the mathematical algorithm is only considered in order to overcome the shortcoming of the low accuracy in the conventional formula de barros et al 2008 introduced the datcom formula using a semi empirical estimate method for predicting the auv traveling resistance for the bare hull the datcom formula shown in eq 2 provided a better approximation in comparison with the experimental results 2 r t 1 2 c v ρ s b u 2 1 2 c f ρ s s u 2 c v 1 02 c f 1 1 5 l d 1 5 7 l d 3 s s s b where r t is the resistance from a single hull c v is the viscous drag coefficient c f is the estimate of the skin friction drag coefficient according to 1957 ittc criterion l is the whole body length for the bare hull s b and s s are the maximum cross sectional area and the body wetted area respectively ρ is the water density and u is the traveling speed in this research nystrom body is considered as a single auv case and its resistance is estimated from the datcom formula in order to validate the enough accuracy of datcom formula cfd results would be used as the criterion all cases were computed using a k ε based turbulence model with no slip wall condition to solve the rans equations the domain is discretized using multiblock unstructured grids the grid is comprised of five base blocks with a total of 1 2 million elements discretization of the convection terms and viscous terms is achieved using a second order upwind scheme and the second order centered scheme respectively the pressure velocity coupling is solved by simple method fig 3 shows that the values estimated from the datcom formula are in agreement with the results of the numerical simulation the advantage of the datcom formula is that it has an excellent fitting accuracy for the ship resistance therefore it can be used in the single bare hull design process 2 3 deterministic optimization design dod to reduce the energy consumption of the auv during navigation the minimum traveling resistance is taken as the optimization objective this can limit the constraint conditions by restricting the volume and length because the electromechanical equipment requires sufficient installation space for the deterministic case without considering the random disturbance in the optimization results it is feasible that the constraints would be satisfied when inputting the design variables of six adjustable parameters in section 2 1 therefore an optimization target of the minimum resistance is realized by the deterministic optimization design dod model with the miga gao et al 2016 as described in table 1 table 2 shows the results of 5000 iterations of the miga notably the optimal design parameters come close to the constraint boundaries this means that uncertainty is probably present in the form of processing inaccuracies due to machine operating conditions generally in practical engineering it is inevitable that there will be some external factors associated with the machine or operators such as artificial disturbances dimension errors and drill wears that introduce uncertainty risks in other words stochastic uncertainties exist in the real world uncertainty analyses and optimization therefore have extreme importance for ship design considering the damage caused by dimension deviation the input design variables of a and n s and the output design variables of v and l are considered to be the risk factors if they are disturbed even slightly the design variables can easily violate the constraint boundaries due to the anisotropy of the materials and the processing technology in practical production in this study form was applied for the uncertainty analysis with respect to the dod results the aim is to control the design variables away from the failure surface 3 uncertainty optimization design 3 1 form reliability analysis since the uncertain characteristics of the parameters have a direct effect on the system performance s uncertainty a reliability analysis should be carried out to accurately estimate the performance uncertainty in the initial design stage an advantage of form is that when a small amount of uncertain factors are considered in the two dimensional space as a random distribution the accuracy of the computations can be effectively ensured here suppose the uncertainty parameters b i represents the variables in the performance function and p corresponds to a nonlinear system at this point the reliability closely corresponds to the probability of satisfying constraints in the system which is given by a set of means and variances this can be determined using eqs 3 and 4 3 μ p p μ b 1 μ b 2 μ the performance function respectively as demonstrated in eq 3 and eq 4 the definition of the variance of the performance function in terms of the uncertainty parameters variances and the sensitivity only needs a low computational efficiency to solve the problem of the auv hull optimization the form transforms all of the random variables into standard normal variables hou et al 2018 this method converts the basic x variable space of a formulated limit state function g x into a u space where the variables u i are independent and are standard normal variables the failure limit state surface g point in order to observe these variables conveniently to satisfy the boundaries conditions or not in a realistic application the results from the reliability analysis of the dod model are used to measure the design quality of the σ level in the presence of the data the performance probability is estimated considering the source of the uncertainties as detailed in section 2 3 and table 3 the standard deviation σ is limited to 1 of μ which is useful when evaluating the quality of the results accordingly σ is defined as a small percentage of μ which can improve the reliability of the performance measures regarding the probability limitation that was discussed previously six design variables exhibited a strong normal distribution these design variables are regarded as uncertainty inputs and they have a finite range within a fixed interval in contrast the outputs are limited to a relatively wide range to satisfy the constraints and may present a greater danger due to uncertainty the inputs could dominate the outputs directly if the design results of the inputs are unacceptable slightly the output errors have a significant harmful effect on production performance the former is therefore considered a minor uncertainty factor and the latter as a main uncertainty factor accordingly v and l were identified as significant factors affecting the response outputs that is if the output quality level improves it is likely that all the uncertainty parameters will be within a suitable range for the design according to the σ level the quality can be measured effectively and considered as a percent variation or a probabilistic constraint which depends on the desired range within σ for the product requirement in this case the σ levels of v and l are all below 1 0 and range of an acceptable performance within 3 σ this criterion is mostly met for the desired product however in actual situations the 3 σ quality level is considered to be a poor design that contains hidden dangers resulting from its performance limitations as the 3 σ quality level is deemed unacceptable a new design concept based on the 6 σ quality was developed by motorola harry and schroeder 2000 this concept reflects the number of defects per million parts converted by the σ level the variability metrics are listed in table 5 as a powerful tool dfss is widely used in manufacturing processes typically the robust design for the six sigma quality includes two core ideas mean on target and minimize variation which are decomposed into the target function f and this can be determined improve the two probabilistic design quality goals reliability and robustness to achieve a 6σ design with respect to improvement of the two mentioned quality goals the reliability is increased by striving to maintain the performance within the constraints or acceptable limits that are associated with the shifted distribution consistently the robustness is improved by reducing the variability and sensitivity of the design that is associated with the shrunk distribution koch et al 2004 fig 6 represents the 3 σ design is promoted to 6 σ design with the aim of the probability that the certain value with both shift and shrink the reliability level is achieved the robustness improved and the worst case performance not significantly affected this is the desired goal in implementing the initial condition the dod model and dfss technology 4 body force model for the self propelled auv to understand the features of the flow encircling the propeller disc the body force models developed by hough and ordway 1965 were used as a new simulation method for describing the hydrodynamic performance of vehicles powered by a propulsion system a more insightful numerical simulation that is based on the reynolds averaged navier stokes rans method indicates that this is an efficient computation that can obtain an accurate outcome which has been demonstrated in a few published papers phillips et al 2008 rattanasiri et al 2012 following this approach the geometry of the propeller is not explicitly represented and a radial distribution of the thrust and torque is provided the tip and root are assumed to be null in order to meet the best circulation mode two models rans ut and rans ho were used in this study based on whether the torque distribution exists or not 4 1 uniform thrust distribution model rans ut the rans ut body force model is applied to the conceptual design of the auv propeller while assuming a uniform distribution of the thrust over the propeller disc and neglecting the torque the axial momentum source term f b x and the tangential momentum source term f b θ can determined through eq 8 and eq 9 respectively 8 f b x t δ x π r p 2 r h 2 9 f b θ 0 where δ x is the thickness of the propeller sub domain r p and r h are the radius of the propeller and the hub respectively and t is the self propelled thrust according to the numerical predictions or the open water tests fig 8 following this approach the physical dimensions of the virtual domain should be selected to represent the propeller perfectly however the mesh domain with the cylinder hardly coincides to the real region modeled from the propeller irregular shape thus the calculated solution of the thrust based on the body force model is modified to approximate the theoretical value specifically the error is limited to 2 based on the thrust correction 4 2 hough and ordway thrust and torque distribution model rans ho the rans ho body force model was proposed by hough and ordway and they considered the circulation distribution which has zero loading at the tip and the root it assumes that the thrust and the torque are required to capture the slipstream directly through the propeller this distribution was coupled with a rans simulation and was implemented by rattanasiri et al 2015 the aforementioned technique was adopted for the present study the non dimensional thrust distribution f b x and the non dimensional torque distribution f b θ are given by eqs 10 13 10 f b x a x r 1 r 11 f b θ a θ r 1 r 1 y h r y h and 12 a x c t h δ x 105 16 4 3 y h 1 y h 13 a θ k q δ x j the wake fraction and n r is the revolutions per second 4 3 self propulsion factors prediction according to the optimization results of the auv hull based on the dfss in section 3 the body force model is used to predict the propeller self propulsion factors herein the ratio of the finite length of the propeller disc and the maximum diameter of the disc is suggested to be more than 0 1 as verified equality thrust method is used with rans ut and rans ho to predict the self propulsion factors depending on whether the torque distribution is considered it is impossible to measure all the parameters of the self propulsion factors directly an estimate formula is employed to obtain the thrust coefficient with respect to j as presented by eq 22 22 k t t j 2 4 ρ v a 2 r p 2 where k t is the estimation of the thrust coefficient after rendering the k t curve and the experimental open water curves of k q and k t into the same figure the advance coefficient j is obtained which is the abscissa of the intersection point and this is demonstrated in fig 10 in addition the other parameters were obtained from the j result and are presented in table 8 when comparing the results the propeller self propulsion factors predicted by rans ho are clearly similar to those predicted by rans ut although the tangential velocity is distributed which surrounds the disc the propeller dimensions are dominated by the axial momentum source term rather than the tangential momentum source term in other words if the auv propeller is operated at only a thrust distribution then the performance related to the considered torque can be determined equivalently moreover the simulation time is significantly reduced because only the thrust is acting on the cylindrical region with an axial velocity distribution hence the computational cost can be effectively reduced the prediction of the propeller self propulsion factors was accurately performed by the rans ho and rans ut body force models these models were validated by researchers from shanghai jiaotong university wu et al 2013 their summaries for the problems are very close to our study results consequently in later sections the resultant effect of the propeller interaction is more achievable given by the rans ut body force model to effectively lighten the computational burden and to maintain the precision 5 optimal configuration of the fleet on the drag to thoroughly investigate the interference of the propeller on the downstream flow assuming that the auv is fully submerged in deep water the effect of the wave is neglected by implementing the thrust distribution on the propeller using rans ut the impact of the propeller is to re energize the wake for a single hull however this race will interact with the following auv directly downstream hence it impacts its own drag even the total energy consumption of an auv fleet may be driven by the change in the individual drag for one vehicle 5 1 twin hulls formation a comparative test with a pair of auvs formation was performed to understand the flow over the body especially the resistance characteristics of the viscous interaction between the bodies molland and utama 2002 the spacing for the twin hull formation is defined as a transverse separation s l and a longitudinal offset d l with a number of ratios the parameters are defined as follows d represents the longitudinal distance between each nose of the bodies s is the transverse distance between the sidelines of each body l is the total length of a single auv a 0 is the auv formation and the interactive formation by varying the transverse separation s l 0 165 0 0 17 0 27 0 37 and 0 47 the longitudinal offset d l 0 0 27 0 57 0 87 1 17 1 47 and 1 77 were selected the auv has an impact on spacing which was validated by rattanasiri in a series of tests for a variety of configurations rattanasiri et al 2013 in this study some findings are discussed in terms of the is the single case drag coefficient the signs and indicate the increase and the decrease of the self propelled drag and it also represents the energy benefit and deficit respectively 5 3 spacing configurations for the auv fleet it should be noted that the results suggest some energy beneficial configurations exist for the individuals and the whole fleet for some configurations this may increase the burden for the members in some specific configurations although the changes of the individual drags exist the same trend very small gains or losses are possible for the fleet these results are classified into six regions as shown in fig 12 depending on the different signs for the configuration percentage difference given in table 9 5 3 1 parallel region the parallel region is when the leader and the follower travel towards the inflow direction with a parallel formation this configuration is defined at d l 0 which indicates that the noses are aligned with the same tangent an increment in the total drag is demonstrated in fig 13 a it depends on the increase in each hull as shown in fig 14 a however it hardly increases more than 2 focusing on a single vehicle for comparison the drag increment of the leader is approximately equal to that of the follower owing to the symmetric numerical fluid domain theoretically the comparison between the two hulls reveals identical drag variations in the wind tunnel mercker 1986 however the source of the error is likely affected by the wall condition that is established as a finite tank rather than an infinite field in addition the drag increment for each hull is reduced along with the extended spacing owing to the viscous interactions these characteristics of the drag penalty were suggested in an experimental study molland and utama 2002 that the minimum transverse separation must be at least 0 5 l to preclude body to body interaction 5 3 2 echelon region the follower achieves synchronization between 0 27 d l 0 57 meanwhile the transverse separation is limited at s l 0 17 and s l 0 47 in addition the configuration of the fleet has the same formation as the echelon or a part of vee can be divided into the echelon region from fig 13 b and fig 14 b there is a significant increase in the leader s drag and the follower shows a contrary tendency finally these changes have a slightly negative influence on the combined drag since this region is discontinuous with a symmetric distribution the viscous interactions experience a strong disturbance when a pair body surface adheres at s l 0 17 otherwise this appears to be a relatively steady state for a long distance where s l 0 47 particularly in an unaccompanied auv the rise and fall of the individual drags are almost equal in addition the follower has an increment in its energy profit this is due to the change in the pressure dominated by the bow shape however an increase of the total drag that is exerted onto the fleet leads to very little loss of energy in other words there are no benefits that refer to the fleet energy in this region 5 3 3 low gain region as the longitudinal offset is limited to one body length with d l 1 17 the scope of the transverse separation s l is extended from 0 17 to 0 47 from this the spacing configuration of the fleet is categorized as a low gain region the individual drag corresponding to a single hull presents the trend that these coefficients first increase and then decrease toward the zero drag depicted in fig 14 b the measurand is the combined drag in the fleet which reflects the low energy savings and it is on average less than 2 phillips et al 2008 as demonstrated in fig 13 b when considering fig 14 b there is an inflection point that is clearly located at d l 0 87 which leads to a violent drop for the individual drag this is caused by the force interaction that a low gain is obtained for the fleet s energy although the characteristics of the single hull resistance are similar to those in the echelon region the energy scheme was optimized with a relatively smaller magnitude 5 3 4 following region as a unique region where the nose of the follower is fixed near the trailing edge of the leader the transverse separation and the longitudinal offset are limited at s l 0 and d l 0 87 respectively for the first time the drag of the leader auv is provided with a reduction in fig 14 b a moderate increase of 0 8 in the combined drag was observed as shown in fig 13 b the source of the drag dropping which is significant for the leader was identified to be the increased pressure recovery as suggested by rattanasiri et al 2014 the downstream pressure of the frontal vehicle was reinforced due to the bow stagnation point of a 1 offset backward thus the pressure resistance of the a 0 is reduced leading to a decrease in the individual drag this configuration presents a streamline formation for the fleets underwater however the augment of the total energy consumption may adversely affect the endurance 5 3 5 low interaction region by placing the follower at a posterior lateral position for d l 1 17 and 0 s l 0 37 the reference to the leader where the longitudinal distance between a pair of propellers is beyond one body length at the beginning the individual drag of the frontal auv experiences a significant decrease at 0 s l 0 17 in fig 14 a thus both hulls are surrounded by the steady flow and obtain a wake recovery to supply the energy for the fleet consequently less than 5 energy is saved in the formation as demonstrated in fig 13 a these characteristics occurred due to the body to body interactions near the body surface the boundary layer flow is considered to exhibit turbulent changes the beginning of this region will be referred to as the transition point in which the velocity shows an abnormal fluctuation or an anomaly silverstein and becker 1938 the maximum drag dropping of the fleet is implemented by the minimum race deduction of the leader s propeller when the spacing configuration is s l 0 these results agree with those obtained in by molland and utama 2002 in which the optimal transverse separation is obtained at s l 0 05 5 3 6 beneficial region for the largest region where the vehicle behind the frontal propeller is submerged in a fully developed turbulent flow the longitudinal offset is limited at d l 1 17 but the transverse separation s l is extended to all the conditions according to fig 13 b and fig 14 a the combined drag is decreased by the follower s propeller wake recovery rattanasiri et al 2014 thus the total energy significantly improves across the fleet by having an increase in the longitudinal offset until d l 1 47 the variation of the leader drag tends to be stable because of the reinforced downstream flow thus these hydrodynamic behaviors are replicated from cars that have a slipstream in the convoy the results of this study are close to the empirical constants applied in cars tested by crabtree 1998 for example regardless of the auvs or the road vehicles at d l 1 17 and s l 0 the drag reduction of the leader is 18 in the end the combined drag for the fleets is reduced by at least half for the individuals at 9 the propeller of the leading auv may directly affect the bow of the following auv by producing a downstream flow when d l 1 77 the distance between the twin hulls is sufficient for the interaction of the propeller wake to be neglected rattanasiri et al 2015 therefore the individual drag coefficients for the leader and the follower are equal to the single hull s drag coefficient hence a b and c can be estimated to be zero by adopting this configuration it is obvious that the energy profits improve the productivity for the auv fleet 6 conclusion this study attempts to investigate the energy saving approach for the auvs fleet depending on both the spacing configurations and the propeller interactions which has a high relevance to hull form design this is first achieved by creating the hull lines design for an individual vehicle and then extended to consider a fleet of two self propelled auvs operating at a range of longitudinal offset and transverse separation it is found that because the previous analysis for the most significant sources of uncertainty is not performed the deterministic optimization design has been conducted for the case study considered here the design variables are likely to violate the constraint boundaries easily in operating environment hence the form reliability analysis is employed to assess the quality levels of the parameters however the results indicate that some parameters are found to have the unacceptable reliabilities which is not reaching the design standard in engineering as a result the dfss technology that is used in this study to improve the quality levels holds great potential in engineering optimization for vehicle design it is demonstrated that the body force models rans ut and rans ho for replicating the impact of the propeller could be used by modeling the momentum source terms the results highlight the radial thrust distribution has a significant impact of the propeller performance the tangential momentum source term is determined by the torque distribution however it is found to have a faint effect on the propeller performance in comparison to the axial momentum source term by aiming to understand the energy budget of a fleet to achieve energy savings this study provides useful information for the operator to determine an effective formation of a pair of auvs this stems from the fact that the type and the particular configuration of the vehicle under study along with the influence of the propeller race must be considered and that dominant spacing must be chosen six zones are identified based on the characteristics of the drag changes these are the parallel region echelon region low gain region following region low interaction region and beneficial region the optimum energy configuration can be indicated in the transverse separation and the longitudinal offset with respect to the spacing of the twin hull as is discussed in this research the beneficial region where the follower is placed directly behind the leader with the longitudinal distance beyond one body length is found the most effective formation based on energy considerations our future work will be focused on increasing the number of auvs in a fleet while addressing a comparison of the energy consumption that may be influenced by the team formation in addition towing tank
