this paper presents a spacing configuration based energy saving optimization approach for a pair of auvs to achieve minimum resistance through the hull forms and propeller interactions the traveling resistance is relevant to hull lines optimization design which uncertainties exist in design variables need to be considered seriously a reliability analysis based on the first order reliability method demonstrates that the engineering quality is not acceptable thus the design for six sigma was performed with uncertainty optimization to improve the design levels two body force models rans ut and rans ho were used to represent the propeller as an axial and a tangential momentum source term the results highlight that the radial thrust distribution has a significant impact of the propeller performance for a pair of auvs the energy consumption of the fleet is classified into six zones depending on the spacing configurations with a longitudinal offset and transverse separation this study details and categorizes the relevant sources of the drag reduction and provides the most effective fleet configuration for the optimal energy profits to validate previous experimental results based on energy considerations the optimal fleet configuration is determined to show excellent adaptability and reliability to provide insights for decision makers keywords twin auvs reliability based optimization design design for six sigma dfss body force model spacing configurations fleet energy 1 introduction autonomous underwater vehicles auvs are controlled remotely using integrated actuation systems without external power or umbilical transmission during a mission the operation commands are often not limited to a single hull the members cooperate to perform certain tasks such as pipeline inspection fernandes et al 2015 mine hunting nguyen et al 2014 and deep ocean exploration zhou et al 2011 caiti et al 2014 while maintaining a geometric formation however there is finite incentive to consume less than the vehicle s total useful energy capacity instead of making full use of the energy this is because the propulsion costs are likely to increase the holistic energy costs this has led to increments in the energy consumption of vehicles which should be mitigated when the auv moves without a formation energy consumption may be reduced using the optimum hull form that is required to minimize the traveling resistance joung et al 2009 yan et al 2013 from a practical perspective there could be different sources of uncertainties in a problem e g environmental factors design variables performance estimates if the uncertainty of these parameters is frequently neglected this leads to products with a low robustness and potential hidden dangers in the design process as a result the results can cause a large deviation after continuous iteration and mutual coupling hence the uncertainty of the problem has to be considered by limiting the parameters with the means of probabilistic distributions and spatial variations then the optimal criteria are used for the optimization design in this context diez and peri 2010 takes the lead in setting the uncertainty parameters for the ship design to achieve a robust solution the robust design optimization rdo approach has been developed to solve single objective minimization problems such as those of the shell design diez and peri 2012 wave response papanikolaou et al 2014 and the velocity disturbance xia and shao 2014 with the advent of reliability based concept design there has also been an increased focus on the application of the reliability based design rbd hannapel and vlahopoulos 2010 this ensures that the optimal solution will satisfy the constraints in the presence of the uncertainty within a prescribed reliability level further computational efficiency in any stage during ship shell development is ensured using the first order reliability method form yang et al 2012 for estimating the reliability however this method is generally used to solve higher order equations otherwise it loses its assessment accuracy in some applications choi and yoo 2012 to replace the expensive functions during the optimization for shortening the computational time the subject of developing the approximation models hannapel 2012 related to the uncertainties is rational the design of experiment doe technique was developed to acquire the performance information which is quite useful for the ship design aldous et al 2015 recently based on estimation methods for the engineering design of distribution parameters the accuracy of the performance has been improved by extending the doe these methods include the taguchi method tm zheng et al 2016 monte carlo methods mcm hou et al 2018 and the response surface methodology rsm lafifi et al 2019 to satisfy the increasing demand for quality the design for six sigma dfss koziotek and derlukiewicz 2012 was presented to reduce the variability results to obtain higher productivity and quality and avoid potential defects dfss can effectively ensure that the quality level reaches 6σ which is widely used in several engineering design fields in the aspect of beginning the ship design this reflects the filtered data of the dfss which has more reliability for the environmental disturbance hou et al 2018 in addition a part of the energy benefit is contributed by the propulsive efficiency which has been enhanced likewise the hydrodynamic performance on the propeller is an influential factor stevenson et al 2007 phillips et al 2008 hough and ordway 1965 introduced the body force model to prescribe the thrust and moment distributions based on the radial circulation distributions the interactions of the rotating propeller which induce the axial and swirl accelerations in the fluid acting on the propeller are considered to be the source terms depending on the coupling method used with the reynolds averaged navier stokes rans equations the rans ut and rans ho models were developed to calculate the viscous flow over the stern by performing simulations phillips et al 2010a the results can be used to reveal the hydrodynamic behaviors in the same way as the experimental results a series of studies has been performed over a range of operational reynolds numbers to investigate the influence of the propeller race on the towed prolate spheroids and the self propelled auvs phillips et al 2010 rattanasiri et al 2012 2012a 2014 for a fleet of auvs the energy consumption consists of the individual energy cost of a single hull and the entire loss is related to the total drag variations in recent years many experiments suggest that the drag of a single hull is reduced for the specific fleet formation that is based on the spacing between the members in contrast the fleet energy profits can be promoted by ameliorating the individual drag reduction positively to some extent rattanasiri et al 2013 2015 afterwards molland and utama 2002 proposed the fleet configuration concept although not completely unified this concept distinguishes two standard spacing references namely the transverse separation s l and the longitudinal offset d l the main problem is that it is very unitary to perform the formation scheme when the energy changes preclude the propeller s effect at least for the unified hull dimension in fact the performance of the individual auv is determined by its hull shape which considerable influences the fleet energy benefit liang et al 2017 in summary the concept of fleet energy consumption is introduced as a drag reduction index that consists of three aspects and the overall procedures can be described as shown in fig 1 minimal energy consumption of an individual auv is required to minimize the single resistance obtained from the optimal hull shape the influence of propulsion is considered to obtain the complete drag for an independent auv which is achieved by predicting the hydrodynamic performance of the propeller by coupling the interactions between the hull and the propeller this study was extended to investigate the combined drag reduction of a fleet dominated by the spacing between members this study aims to provide guidance for operators for developing an energy saving approach for multiple auvs with various spacing configurations the auv hull lines are assumed to have a nystrom axial symmetry revolution body with uncertainty parameters based on the datcom formula the traveling resistance is obtained by establishing a deterministic design optimization dod model using the multi island genetic algorithm miga the first order reliability method form is employed to assess the reliability that corresponds to the levels of risks in the uncertainties thereby using dfss technology to improve the quality for the ship design optimization considering the influence of the thrust and torque two body force models rans ut and rans ho are used in simulations to predict the propeller self propulsion factors the energy consumption of the auvs fleet is defined as the index of the drag reduction which depends upon the transverse separation and the longitudinal offset the dominant spacing has been classified into six regions to investigate the effect of the various configurations on the energy budget 2 bare hull study 2 1 nystrom shape assumed in hull nystrom 1863 proposed the mathematical formula of the regular axial symmetry revolution body the head shape can be determined by rotating an ellipse around the main axis and the tail shape is formed by rotating a parabola around a straight line perpendicular to the directrix the nystrom type auv is composed of three parts the fore body the parallel middle body and the after body the implementation of the hull lines is controlled using six adjustable design parameters the formula of the hull shape is shown in eq 1 1 f o r e b o d y s h a p e y s x d 2 1 x s l s n s 1 n s a f t e r b o d y s h a p e y w x d 2 1 x w l w 1 n w where d is the middle body diameter a l s d is the fore body curve design parameter b l p d is the parallel middle body curve design parameter c l w d is the after body curve design parameter n s is the shape index of the fore body curve and n w is the shape index of the after body curve these six adjustable design parameters control the curves length and shape x is the distance from the vertex of bow l s is the fore body length l p is the cylinder length l w is the after body length x s and x w are the distance from the maximum radius of the fore body and the after body respectively the main properties of the nystrom auv are described in fig 2 2 2 resistance estimation method in regard to the research on the axial symmetry revolution body for expressing the auv hull shape the sailing resistance is calculated using an empirical formula computational fluid dynamics cfd and a model experiment the real environment is established artificially which leads to a high cost and a long period when employing the test model similarly when using the cfd method fast calculation results can be achieved only on high collocation computer hardware systems which are relatively expensive compared with the aforementioned methods the cost can be significantly reduced by using the empirical formula however the error is critical even though the mathematical algorithm is only considered in order to overcome the shortcoming of the low accuracy in the conventional formula de barros et al 2008 introduced the datcom formula using a semi empirical estimate method for predicting the auv traveling resistance for the bare hull the datcom formula shown in eq 2 provided a better approximation in comparison with the experimental results 2 r t 1 2 c v ρ s b u 2 1 2 c f ρ s s u 2 c v 1 02 c f 1 1 5 l d 1 5 7 l d 3 s s s b where r t is the resistance from a single hull c v is the viscous drag coefficient c f is the estimate of the skin friction drag coefficient according to 1957 ittc criterion l is the whole body length for the bare hull s b and s s are the maximum cross sectional area and the body wetted area respectively ρ is the water density and u is the traveling speed in this research nystrom body is considered as a single auv case and its resistance is estimated from the datcom formula in order to validate the enough accuracy of datcom formula cfd results would be used as the criterion all cases were computed using a k ε based turbulence model with no slip wall condition to solve the rans equations the domain is discretized using multiblock unstructured grids the grid is comprised of five base blocks with a total of 1 2 million elements discretization of the convection terms and viscous terms is achieved using a second order upwind scheme and the second order centered scheme respectively the pressure velocity coupling is solved by simple method fig 3 shows that the values estimated from the datcom formula are in agreement with the results of the numerical simulation the advantage of the datcom formula is that it has an excellent fitting accuracy for the ship resistance therefore it can be used in the single bare hull design process 2 3 deterministic optimization design dod to reduce the energy consumption of the auv during navigation the minimum traveling resistance is taken as the optimization objective this can limit the constraint conditions by restricting the volume and length because the electromechanical equipment requires sufficient installation space for the deterministic case without considering the random disturbance in the optimization results it is feasible that the constraints would be satisfied when inputting the design variables of six adjustable parameters in section 2 1 therefore an optimization target of the minimum resistance is realized by the deterministic optimization design dod model with the miga gao et al 2016 as described in table 1 table 2 shows the results of 5000 iterations of the miga notably the optimal design parameters come close to the constraint boundaries this means that uncertainty is probably present in the form of processing inaccuracies due to machine operating conditions generally in practical engineering it is inevitable that there will be some external factors associated with the machine or operators such as artificial disturbances dimension errors and drill wears that introduce uncertainty risks in other words stochastic uncertainties exist in the real world uncertainty analyses and optimization therefore have extreme importance for ship design considering the damage caused by dimension deviation the input design variables of a and n s and the output design variables of v and l are considered to be the risk factors if they are disturbed even slightly the design variables can easily violate the constraint boundaries due to the anisotropy of the materials and the processing technology in practical production in this study form was applied for the uncertainty analysis with respect to the dod results the aim is to control the design variables away from the failure surface 3 uncertainty optimization design 3 1 form reliability analysis since the uncertain characteristics of the parameters have a direct effect on the system performance s uncertainty a reliability analysis should be carried out to accurately estimate the performance uncertainty in the initial design stage an advantage of form is that when a small amount of uncertain factors are considered in the two dimensional space as a random distribution the accuracy of the computations can be effectively ensured here suppose the uncertainty parameters b i represents the variables in the performance function and p corresponds to a nonlinear system at this point the reliability closely corresponds to the probability of satisfying constraints in the system which is given by a set of means and variances this can be determined using eqs 3 and 4 3 μ p p μ b 1 μ b 2 μ b i 4 σ p 2 i 1 n p b i 2 σ b i 2 where μ b i is the mean of b i σ b i 2 is the variance of b i p b i is the system sensitivity associated with b i and μ p and σ p 2 are the mean and the variance of the performance function respectively as demonstrated in eq 3 and eq 4 the definition of the variance of the performance function in terms of the uncertainty parameters variances and the sensitivity only needs a low computational efficiency to solve the problem of the auv hull optimization the form transforms all of the random variables into standard normal variables hou et al 2018 this method converts the basic x variable space of a formulated limit state function g x into a u space where the variables u i are independent and are standard normal variables the failure limit state surface g 0 separates all combinations of x that lie in the failure domain f from those in the survival domain s consequently the probability of failure p f can be obtained using eq 5 5 p f p r x f p r g x 0 g x 0 f x x d x s where f x x is the joint probability density function pdf of x the reliability index β is the minimum distance between the point defined by the values of the mean point and the failure surface in other words β may be regarded as a safety margin to define how far the system is from failure as depicted in fig 4 if the condition fails higher risks may occur for determining the design point in order to observe these variables conveniently to satisfy the boundaries conditions or not in a realistic application the results from the reliability analysis of the dod model are used to measure the design quality of the σ level in the presence of the data the performance probability is estimated considering the source of the uncertainties as detailed in section 2 3 and table 3 the standard deviation σ is limited to 1 of μ which is useful when evaluating the quality of the results accordingly σ is defined as a small percentage of μ which can improve the reliability of the performance measures regarding the probability limitation that was discussed previously six design variables exhibited a strong normal distribution these design variables are regarded as uncertainty inputs and they have a finite range within a fixed interval in contrast the outputs are limited to a relatively wide range to satisfy the constraints and may present a greater danger due to uncertainty the inputs could dominate the outputs directly if the design results of the inputs are unacceptable slightly the output errors have a significant harmful effect on production performance the former is therefore considered a minor uncertainty factor and the latter as a main uncertainty factor accordingly v and l were identified as significant factors affecting the response outputs that is if the output quality level improves it is likely that all the uncertainty parameters will be within a suitable range for the design according to the σ level the quality can be measured effectively and considered as a percent variation or a probabilistic constraint which depends on the desired range within σ for the product requirement in this case the σ levels of v and l are all below 1 0 and they correspond to a poor design in practice as shown in table 4 for the purposes of increasing the design standard it is necessary to carry out the uncertainty optimization for the design of the auv hull form to achieve the next step 3 2 uncertainty optimization design based on dfss it might be guaranteed consistently for the manufacturing quality per batch the 3 σ quality level is defined as the range of an acceptable performance within 3 σ this criterion is mostly met for the desired product however in actual situations the 3 σ quality level is considered to be a poor design that contains hidden dangers resulting from its performance limitations as the 3 σ quality level is deemed unacceptable a new design concept based on the 6 σ quality was developed by motorola harry and schroeder 2000 this concept reflects the number of defects per million parts converted by the σ level the variability metrics are listed in table 5 as a powerful tool dfss is widely used in manufacturing processes typically the robust design for the six sigma quality includes two core ideas mean on target and minimize variation which are decomposed into the target function f and this can be determined as follows 6 f i 1 n ω 1 i s 1 i μ y i ω 2 i s 2 i σ y i 2 where i is the performance response of the performance parameter set y n is the number of responses μ y i and σ y i 2 are the mean and the or maximized the sign is used when the response mean minimized and the sign is used when the response mean is maximized fig 5 presents the implementations of the 6 σ approach which transforms all input parameters the target function f and the limit state function g are subject to constraints that the sigma level number m must reach m 6 to ensure the high quality requirement this aims to improve the two probabilistic design quality goals reliability and robustness to achieve a 6σ design with respect to improvement of the two mentioned quality goals the reliability is increased by striving to maintain the performance within the constraints or acceptable limits that are associated with the shifted distribution consistently the robustness is improved by reducing the variability and sensitivity of the design that is associated with the shrunk distribution koch et al 2004 fig 6 represents the 3 σ design is promoted to 6 σ design with the aim of the probability that the performance will remain within the set limits is essentially 100 the performance distribution must be shrunk to improve the robustness also the reliability is strived to maintain performance within acceptable limits which is defined as the probability of satisfying constraints the lower specification limit lsl and the upper specification limit usl for the target variations are held fixed to a certain value with both shift and shrink the reliability level is achieved the robustness improved and the worst case performance not significantly affected this is the desired goal in implementing dfss in this section the dfss optimization is applied to the hull design of a bare auv which is subjected to uncertain usage conditions as mentioned earlier the parameters are set in accordance with the probability distribution the previous inputs are all normally distributed and can be simply transformed to avoid errors due to the worst case performances table 6 also presents the uncertainty the initial condition the dod model and dfss technology 4 body force model for the self propelled auv to understand the features of the flow encircling the propeller disc the body force models developed by hough and ordway 1965 were used as a new simulation method for describing the hydrodynamic performance of vehicles powered by a propulsion system a more insightful numerical simulation that is based on the reynolds averaged navier stokes rans method indicates that this is an efficient computation that can obtain an accurate outcome which has been demonstrated in a few published papers phillips et al 2008 rattanasiri et al 2012 following this approach the geometry of the propeller is not explicitly represented and a radial distribution of the thrust and torque is provided the tip and root are assumed to be null in order to meet the best circulation mode two models rans ut and rans ho were used in this study based on whether the torque distribution exists or not 4 1 uniform thrust distribution model rans ut the rans ut body force model is applied to the conceptual design of the auv propeller while assuming a uniform distribution of the thrust over the propeller disc and neglecting the torque the axial momentum source term f b x and the tangential momentum source term f b θ can determined through eq 8 and eq 9 respectively 8 f b x t δ x π r p 2 r h 2 9 f b θ 0 where δ x is the thickness of the propeller sub domain r p and r h are the radius of the propeller and the hub respectively and t is the self propelled thrust according to the numerical predictions or the coincides to the real region modeled from the propeller irregular shape thus the calculated solution of the thrust based on the body force model is modified to approximate the theoretical value specifically the error is limited to 2 based on the thrust correction 4 2 hough and ordway thrust and torque distribution model rans ho the rans ho body force model was proposed by hough and ordway and they considered the circulation distribution which has zero loading at the tip and the root it assumes that the thrust and the torque are required to capture the slipstream directly through the the wake fraction and n r is the revolutions per second 4 3 self propulsion factors prediction according to the optimization results of the auv hull based on the dfss in section 3 the body force model is used to predict the propeller self propulsion factors herein the ratio of the finite length of the propeller disc and the maximum diameter of the disc is suggested to be more than 0 1 as verified equality thrust method is used with rans ut and rans ho to predict the self propulsion factors depending on whether the torque distribution is considered it is impossible to measure all the parameters of the self propulsion factors directly an estimate formula is employed to obtain the thrust coefficient with respect to j as presented by eq 22 22 k t t j 2 4 ρ v a 2 r p 2 where k t is the estimation of the thrust coefficient after rendering the k t curve and the experimental open water curves of k q and k t into the same figure the advance coefficient j is obtained which is the abscissa of the intersection point and this is demonstrated in fig 10 in addition the other parameters were obtained from the j result and are presented in table 8 when comparing the results the propeller self propulsion factors predicted by rans ho are clearly similar to those predicted by rans ut although the tangential velocity is distributed which surrounds the disc the propeller dimensions are dominated by the axial momentum source term rather than the tangential momentum source term in other words if the auv propeller is operated at only a thrust distribution then the performance related to the considered torque can be determined equivalently moreover the simulation time is significantly reduced because only the thrust is acting on the cylindrical region with an axial velocity distribution hence the computational cost can be effectively reduced the prediction of the propeller self propulsion factors was accurately performed by the rans ho and rans ut body force models these models were validated by researchers from shanghai jiaotong university wu et al 2013 their summaries for the problems are very close to our study results consequently in later sections the resultant effect of the propeller interaction is more achievable given by the rans ut body force model to effectively lighten the computational burden and to maintain the precision 5 optimal configuration of the fleet on the drag to thoroughly investigate the interference of the propeller on the downstream flow assuming that the auv is fully submerged in deep water the effect of the wave is neglected by implementing the thrust distribution on the propeller using rans ut the impact of the propeller is to re energize the wake for a single hull however this race will interact with the following auv directly downstream hence it impacts its own drag even the total energy consumption of an auv fleet may be driven by the change in the individual drag for one vehicle 5 1 twin hulls formation a comparative test with a pair of auvs formation was performed to understand the flow over the body especially the resistance characteristics of the viscous interaction between the bodies molland and utama 2002 the spacing for the twin hull formation is defined as a transverse separation s l and a longitudinal offset d l with a number of ratios the parameters are defined as follows d represents the longitudinal distance between each nose of the bodies s is the transverse distance between the sidelines of each body l is the total length of a single auv a 0 is the auv formation and the interactive formation by varying the transverse separation s l 0 165 0 0 17 0 27 0 37 and 0 47 the longitudinal offset d l 0 0 27 0 57 0 87 1 17 1 47 and 1 77 were selected the auv has an impact on spacing which was validated by rattanasiri in a series of tests for a variety of configurations rattanasiri et al 2013 in this study some findings are discussed in terms of the is the single case drag coefficient the signs and indicate the increase and the decrease of the self propelled drag and it also represents the energy benefit and deficit respectively 5 3 spacing configurations for the auv fleet it should be noted that the results suggest some energy beneficial configurations exist for the individuals and the whole fleet for some configurations this may increase the burden for the members in some specific configurations although the changes of the individual drags exist the same trend very small gains or losses are possible for the fleet these results are classified into six regions as shown in fig 12 depending on the different signs for the configuration percentage difference given in table 9 5 3 1 parallel region the parallel region is when the leader and the follower travel towards the inflow direction with a parallel formation this configuration is defined at d l 0 which indicates that the noses are aligned with the same tangent an increment in the total drag is demonstrated in fig 13 a it depends on the increase in each hull as shown in fig 14 a however it hardly increases more than 2 focusing on a single vehicle for comparison the drag increment of the leader is approximately equal to that of the follower owing to the symmetric numerical fluid domain theoretically the comparison between the two hulls reveals identical drag variations in the wind tunnel mercker 1986 however the source of the error is likely affected by the wall condition that is established as a finite tank rather than an infinite field in addition the drag increment for each hull is reduced along with the extended spacing owing to the viscous interactions these characteristics of the drag penalty were suggested in an experimental study molland and utama 2002 that the minimum transverse separation must be at least 0 5 l to preclude body to body interaction 5 3 2 echelon region the follower achieves synchronization between 0 27 d l 0 57 meanwhile the transverse separation is limited at s l 0 17 and s l 0 47 in addition the configuration of the fleet has the same formation as the echelon or a part of vee can be divided into the echelon region from fig 13 b and fig 14 b there is a significant increase in the leader s drag and the follower shows a contrary tendency finally these changes have a slightly negative influence on the combined drag since this region is discontinuous with a symmetric distribution the viscous interactions experience a strong disturbance when a pair body surface adheres at s l 0 17 otherwise this appears to be a relatively steady state for a long distance where s l 0 47 particularly in an unaccompanied auv the rise and fall of the individual drags are almost equal in addition the follower has an increment in its energy profit this is due to the change in the pressure dominated by the bow shape however an increase of the total drag that is exerted onto the fleet leads to very little loss of energy in other words there are no benefits that refer to the fleet energy in this region 5 3 3 low gain region as the longitudinal offset is limited to one body length with d l 1 17 the scope of the transverse separation s l is extended from 0 17 to 0 47 from this the spacing configuration of the fleet is categorized as a low gain region the individual drag corresponding to a single hull presents the trend that these coefficients first increase and then decrease toward the zero drag depicted in fig 14 b the measurand is the combined drag in the fleet which reflects the low energy savings and it is on average less than 2 phillips et al 2008 as demonstrated in fig 13 b when considering fig 14 b there is an inflection point that is clearly located at d l 0 87 which leads to a violent drop for the individual drag this is caused by the force interaction that a low gain is obtained for the fleet s energy although the characteristics of the single hull resistance are similar to those in the echelon region the energy scheme was optimized with a relatively smaller magnitude 5 3 4 following region as a unique region where the nose of the follower is fixed near the trailing edge of the leader the transverse separation and the longitudinal offset are limited at s l 0 and d l 0 87 respectively for the first time the drag of the leader auv is provided with a reduction in fig 14 b a moderate increase of 0 8 in the combined drag was observed as shown in fig 13 b the source of the drag dropping which is significant for the leader was identified to be the increased pressure recovery as suggested by rattanasiri et al 2014 the downstream pressure of the frontal vehicle was reinforced due to the bow stagnation point of a 1 offset backward thus the pressure resistance of the a 0 is reduced leading to a decrease in the individual drag this configuration presents a streamline formation for the fleets underwater however the augment of the total energy consumption may adversely affect the endurance 5 3 5 low interaction region by placing the follower at a posterior lateral position for d l 1 17 and 0 s l 0 37 the reference to the leader where the longitudinal distance between a pair of propellers is beyond one body length at the beginning the individual drag of the frontal auv experiences a significant decrease at 0 s l 0 17 in fig 14 a thus both hulls are surrounded by the steady flow and obtain a wake recovery to supply the energy for the fleet consequently less than 5 energy is saved in the formation as demonstrated in fig 13 a these characteristics occurred due to the body to body interactions near the body surface the boundary layer flow is considered to exhibit turbulent changes the beginning of this region will be referred to as the transition point in which the velocity shows an abnormal fluctuation or an anomaly silverstein and becker 1938 the maximum drag dropping of the fleet is implemented by the minimum race deduction of the leader s propeller when the spacing configuration is s l 0 these results agree with those obtained in by molland and utama 2002 in which the optimal transverse separation is obtained at s l 0 05 5 3 6 beneficial region for the largest region where the vehicle behind the frontal propeller is submerged in a fully developed turbulent flow the longitudinal offset is limited at d l 1 17 but the transverse separation s l is extended to all the conditions according to fig 13 b and fig 14 a the combined drag is decreased by the follower s propeller wake recovery rattanasiri et al 2014 thus the total energy significantly improves across the fleet by having an increase in the longitudinal offset until d l 1 47 the variation of the leader drag tends to be stable because of the reinforced downstream flow thus these hydrodynamic behaviors are replicated from cars that have a slipstream in the convoy the results of this study are close to the empirical constants applied in cars tested by crabtree 1998 for example regardless of the auvs or the road vehicles at d l 1 17 and s l 0 the drag reduction of the leader is 18 in the end the combined drag for the fleets is reduced by at least half for the individuals at 9 the propeller of the leading auv may directly affect the bow of the following auv by producing a downstream flow when d l 1 77 the distance between the twin hulls is sufficient for the interaction of the propeller wake to be neglected rattanasiri et al 2015 therefore the individual drag coefficients for the leader and the follower are equal to the single hull s drag coefficient hence a b and c can be estimated to be zero by adopting this configuration it is obvious that the energy profits improve the productivity for the auv fleet 6 conclusion this study attempts to investigate the energy saving approach for the auvs fleet depending on both the spacing configurations and the propeller interactions which has a high relevance to hull form design this is first achieved by creating the hull lines design for an individual vehicle and then extended to consider a fleet of two self propelled auvs operating at a range of longitudinal offset and transverse separation it is found that because the previous analysis for the most significant sources of uncertainty is not performed the deterministic optimization design has been conducted for the case study considered here the design variables are likely to violate the constraint boundaries easily in operating environment hence the form reliability analysis is employed to assess the quality levels of the parameters however the results indicate that some parameters are found to have the unacceptable reliabilities which is not reaching the design standard in engineering as a result the dfss technology that is used in this study to improve the quality levels holds great potential in engineering optimization for vehicle design it is demonstrated that the body force models rans ut and rans ho for replicating the impact of the propeller could be used by modeling the momentum source terms the results highlight the radial thrust distribution has a significant impact of the propeller performance the tangential momentum source term is determined by the torque distribution however it is found to have a faint effect on the propeller performance in comparison to the axial momentum source term by aiming to understand the energy budget of a fleet to achieve energy savings this study provides useful information for the operator to determine an effective formation of a pair of auvs this stems from the fact that the type and the particular configuration of the vehicle under study along with the influence of the propeller race must be considered and that dominant spacing must be chosen six zones are identified based on the characteristics of the drag changes these are the parallel region echelon region low gain region following region low interaction region and beneficial region the optimum energy configuration can be indicated in the transverse separation and the longitudinal offset with respect to the spacing of the twin hull as is discussed in this research the beneficial region where the follower is placed directly behind the leader with the longitudinal distance beyond one body length is found the most effective formation based on energy considerations our future work will be focused on increasing the number of auvs in a fleet while addressing a comparison of the energy consumption that may be influenced by the team formation in addition towing tank the oscillation patterns of two 1 dof cylinder oscillators undergoing viv and galloping are investigated in a free surface water channel for 3 2 104 re 1 2 105 the cylinders are arranged in tandem and supported by springs for a range of different spring stiffness and damping parameters the efficiency of a current energy converter cec based on flow induced oscillation fio of multiple cylinders in tandem is critically related to the cylinder oscillation patterns due to the limited number of studies on the fio for multiple cylindrical or prismatic bodies their oscillation patterns have neither been identified nor classified the surfaces of the cylinders are modified by turbulence stimulation to enhance fio three different center to center spacing five stiffness and six damping ratios for a total of 90 sets of experiments were conducted the current velocity range is from 0 34 m s to 1 32 m s from more than 2000 tests five major patterns nine sub patterns are identified and classified the patterns are defined based on the amplitudes frequencies and the phase angle differences between the two cylinders the characteristics and mechanics of each oscillation pattern are explored and explained from the perspective of fluid structure interaction fsi by systematically varying the parameters the underlying hydrodynamic mechanisms including the coupling level between vortices and cylinders the shielding effect the wake effect and the stability states are revealed few preliminary observations on the connection between oscillation pattern and harnessed power by the tandem cylinders are reported keywords hydrokinetic energy harnessing flow induced oscillation vortex induced vibration galloping tandem cylinders synergistic oscillation patterns 1 introduction flow induced oscillation fio is a phenomenon that occurs with flexible or elastically supported cylindrical prismatic structures in a fluid stream vortex induced vibration viv and galloping are the two most common fio for elongated bodies with bluff cross sections in currents viv is mainly induced by the wake vortex shedding while galloping is due to the instability of a shear layer fios of circular cylinders are widely studied because of the extensive engineering applications underwater and in air comprehensive reviews of viv were published by bearman 1984 and williamson and govardhan 2004 galloping does not occur with smooth circular cylinders in a uniform flow asymmetry is required for galloping and it may be caused by body geometry or flow thus studies on galloping are on non circular cylinders and prisms park et al 2013 ding et al 2015 mannini et al 2014 or on cylinders in nonuniform flows hover and triantafyllou 2001 the marine renewable energy laboratory mrelab developed a turbulence stimulation method labeled passive turbulence control ptc to destabilize a shear layer and trigger galloping for single or multiple circular cylinders using selective surface roughness distribution bernitsas et al 2008 park et al 2011 a map of ptc to fio was developed to reveal the effect of the roughness distribution on the dynamic response of circular cylinders in uniform flow this map is a guide for fio enhancement for harnessing marine hydrodynamic energy park et al 2013 2017 in fied testing the effect of ptc was achieved by adding locally metal sheet layers without surface roughness along with anti fouling coating marine fouling was prevented the fio characteristics change substantially when there are multiple cylinders in the flow because there are more factors affecting the fluid structure interaction the vortex shedding timing and the transition path of the vortices are changed by the presence of other cylinders shed vortices may also merge counteract or shift to other forms during or following shedding the spacing between the cylinders is the most crucial factor which greatly affects the vortex shedding behavior and the pressure distribution around cylinders igarashi 1981 classified two regimes for two stationary cylinders in tandem according to whether von kármán vortex streets are generated between the two cylinders zdravkovich 1985 1977 analyzed the vortex behavior more comprehensively and presented a map of vortex shedding modes for two cylinders placed side by side in tandem and in staggered arrangements with various spacing assi et al 2006 2010 2013 performed a series of experiments on the wake induced vibration wiv of a cylinder on springs in the wake of a fixed cylinder wiv did not only build up a higher oscillation amplitude than the viv of a single isolated cylinder but also sustained it when the vortex shedding frequency from the upstream cylinder was far higher than the natural frequency of the downstream cylinder it was suggested that the oscillation of the downstream cylinder was dominated by the unsteady vortex structure interactions rather than the resonance of the oscillation and vortex shedding as in viv assi et al 2013 also presented the concept of wake stiffness in which the wake vortices from the upstream cylinder has an effect similar to a linear spring on the oscillation of the downstream cylinder even if the structural springs were removed the wake spring effect was validated within a range of amplitude of oscillation in most of the fio viv and galloping scenarios with a single oscillating cylinder the oscillation is sinusoidal with only one dominant oscillation frequency when both tandem placed cylinders are oscillating the interactions are more complex because the upstream cylinder is not only affecting the downstream cylinder but is also being affected by the mutual interaction xu et al 2019 kim et al 2009 investigated fio of two circular cylinders in tandem with different spacing values response was classified in five different regimes with qualitatively different response the oscillation of the upstream cylinder was observed to be suppressed by the fixed downstream cylinder in regime iv while the downstream cylinder is independent on the upstream cylinder in other regimes the fio of the upstream cylinder has a strong influence on the downstream cylinder the inflow velocity for the downstream cylinder is always slower than that of the upstream cylinder due to the blockage of the upstream cylinder as a result the wake vortex shedding frequencies for the two cylinders are always different in viv according to the strouhal law st f s d c u where st is strouhal number f s is the vortex shedding frequency for a stationary cylinder d c is the characteristic dimension perpendicular to the flow and u is the inflow velocity the vortices shed from the two cylinders can either work together to enhance the oscillation or work against each other to suppress the oscillation this depends on the interaction of the vortices and the motions of the cylinders which depend on the oscillator parameters i e spring stiffness damping ratio spacing between cylinders and flow speed mahbub alam and zhou 2007 studied the phase lag between the vortex shedding with the lift force with various cross sections when 4 7 104 re 6 5 104 an empirical equation was derived to relate the phase lag with strouhal number center to center spacing and the minimum spacing at which the vortices can shed in the gap qin et al 2019 systematically examined how vortex behavior including reattachment detachment rolling up and shedding affect the fio characteristics of two cylinders in tandem within the approximate range of 5 103 re 6 104 fan et al 2020b 2020a investigated the fio mode of a more complicated system which has three 2 dof cylinders placed in tandem by both wind tunnel experiments and cfd simulations four regimes were classified according to the fio mode and spacing with a reynolds number range of 3 1 103 re 6 2 104 they also proposed four wake interference criteria based on velocities wake induced galloping was observed in cfd results galloping is not triggered by the wake vortex shedding but the instability of the shear layer as a highly non linear phenomenon galloping of a two cylinder system shows more attractors in the current study which were not identified in previous studies the underlying mechanism of fluid structure interactions can be explored by studying the oscillation patterns the pattern characteristics can provide a better understanding when designing the system parameters of structures in water or air flows that would help in stabilizing structures prone to fio either for suppression as in risers or for enhancement to improve the performance of hydrokinetic energy converters the fio characteristics of two elastically supported cylinders in tandem were systematically investigated by the mrelab experimentally computationally and analytically to optimize the performance of the vivace converter developed by bernitsas et al 2008 ptc introduced by park et al 2011 was applied by lan et al 2018 who identified three oscillation patterns of two cylinders in viv and galloping with a combination of stiffness and damping ratio this was based on phase lag between the motion of two cylinders in tandem namely the in phase pattern the out of phase pattern and the continuously changing pattern between the two sun et al 2017 experimentally tested the energy harnessing performance of two cylinders in tandem with center to center spacing ratio 1 57 x 0 d 2 57 spring stiffness 400 n m k 1200 n m and total damping ratio from 0 02 ζ 0 26 in the present study the tests in the research by sun et al 2017 for hydrokinetic energy harnessing are analyzed from a hydrodynamic perspective more patterns are observed than the previous study of lan et al 2018 with an improved classification method which is based on the coupling level of the oscillations of the two cylinders the details of the experimental set up are presented in section 2 the pattern classification method is introduced in section 3 in section 4 maps of the oscillation patterns vs damping ratio ζ and reynolds number re are presented a flow chart describing the fluid structure interaction process is proposed to understand the mutual effect between the cylinders and explain the causes for each pattern from the perspective of hydrodynamics some special cases are studied specifically in this section and conclusions are summarized at the end 2 experiment set up all tests were performed in the low turbulence free surface water ltfsw channel in the mrelab of the university of michigan fig 1 a the test section is 1 0 m in width 1 52 m in depth and 2 44 m in length 37 85 m3 of water is circulating in the channel with a maximum speed of 1 35 m s the water temperature was maintained around 19 5 c the water depth at the test section was 1 17 m for the present study the inflow velocity ranges from 0 34 m s to 1 35 m s and a 0 04 m s interval was used taking the diameter of the cylinder d 0 0889 m as the characteristic dimension the reynolds number range is 3 2 104 re 1 2 105 the test models are two aluminum circular cylinders modified with ptc strips for turbulence simulation as shown in fig 1 b two strips are applied to each cylinder covering the surface from 20 to 36 with respect to the forward stagnation point which was previously studied extensively as the best choice for harnessing energy in galloping sun et al 2017 the system parameters are presented in table 1 the cylinders are supported by two end springs emulated by the vck controller in order to achieve the desired stiffness and damping ratio the cylinder is constrained to move in the crossflow direction only as shown in fig 1 c the system calibration method for designing and implementing a no bias controller called vck system can be found in previous work by sun et al 2015 the displacement signal of each cylinder is recorded by the encoder of the servo motor with a resolution of less than 0 0001 m according to previous research the 2nd cylinder would have very limited influence on the 1st cylinder for spacing x 0 d 3 0 which means that the 1st cylinder would act like an isolated single cylinder kim et al 2013 kim and bernitsas 2016 the oscillation pattern of the 1st cylinder would not be affected by the 2nd cylinder in that situation it is more like a problem of the downstream cylinder s oscillation pattern under different kinds of perturbation from the wake of the upstream cylinder i e wake induced vibration rather than the interactive fio pattern studied in this paper this paper is aimed at understanding the synergy of two cylinders in flow induced oscillations thus the spacing range selected in this research is relatively narrow 90 sets of tests were involved in this study with three parameters including 3 center to center spacing values x 0 d 1 57 2 01 2 57 5 stiffness values k 400 n m 600 n m 800 n m 1000 n m 1200 n m and 6 total damping ratios ζ 0 06 0 10 0 14 0 18 0 22 0 26 for each of the ninety sets of tests about 25 velocity values were tested note that the stiffness and damping ratio for both cylinders are identical during each set of tests a detailed analysis of the test measurements can be found in sun et al 2017 3 pattern classification 3 1 classification method cylinder oscillation especially monochromatic is quantified by its amplitude and frequency in the case of two cylinders their relative position is important to illustrate and understand the fio mechanism the phase angle difference pad between the two cylinders defines their relative position pad is defined as the angular degree of the instantaneous position of the upstream 1st cylinder y 1 t leading that of the downstream 2nd cylinder y 2 t as shown in equation 1 where y 1 t and y 2 t represent the hilbert transform projection of y 1 t and y 2 t respectively 1 pad α 1 α 2 y 1 t y 2 t y 2 t y 1 t y 1 t y 2 t y 1 t y 2 t besides pad other tools used to illustrate the properties of the various response patterns are a the power spectral density calculated by discrete fourier transform dft to present the overall frequency content of a signal b the instantaneous frequency for each cycle calculated to show how the oscillation pattern shifts from one stage to the other within the same experiment huang et al 2009 huang and shen 2014 c the instantaneous frequency normalized by the natural frequency in vacuo d the instantaneous power calculated according to equation 2 where p harness i t is the instantaneous harnessing power c harness is the harnessing damping coefficient ẏ i t is the instantaneous oscillating velocity of the cylinder the derivation of equation 2 can be found in previous papers sun et al 2016 sun and bernitsas 2019 2 p h a r n e s s i t c h a r n e s s y i t y i t suffice to mention here that in the classical linear oscillator model with linear viscous damping the instantaneous damping force is c h a r n e s s y i t when multiplied by the oscillating cylinder velocity y i t it yields the instantaneous power in oscillating cylinder e p harness shows the power harnessing ability of a vivace converter in each pattern and stage f the phase diagram is used to understand the non linear behavior of the oscillating cylinders based on all the parameters mentioned above five major patterns for a total of nine sub patterns are identified the properties of each pattern are shown in figs 2 16 with a summary table in fig 17 3 2 pattern 1a pattern 1 is the fully synchronized pattern in which the fio s of the two cylinders have the same and only one frequency there are two sub patterns for pattern 1 patten 1a is the most common pattern in the tests as shown in fig 2 the oscillations of the two cylinders are synchronized in frequency the psd shows that both cylinders appear to have monochromatic responses with minimal variation in the instantaneous frequency as a function of time thus the time histories of both cylinders appear to be sinusoidal the two motions are also in phase the cycle to cycle frequencies of the two cylinders are nearly constant and equal the phase angle difference between the oscillations of the cylinders is also constant in the current case the pad is about 0 but it can be any constant in other cases for pattern 1 in this case the 1st upstream cylinder has a higher oscillation amplitude than that of the 2nd downstream cylinder detailed results can be found in sun et al 2017 for the amplitude ratio frequency harnessed power and efficiency ding et al 2019 conducted numerical simulations to explore the fsi mechanisms of a two cylinder vivace the flow field and dynamical response of a typical pattern 1a are shown in fig 3 the oscillations and the lift force of the two cylinders are synchronized in frequency with a 20⁰ pad the vortices shed from the upper lower side of the 1st cylinder touch the corresponding side of the 2nd cylinder and merge with the wake vortices of the 2nd cylinder as a consequence there is only one vortex street behind the two cylinders there is no independent wake shedding from the 2nd cylinder in this scenario the oscillations of the two cylinders are both controlled by the vortices shed from the 1st cylinder 3 3 pattern 1b pattern 1b is similar to pattern 1 but the 2nd cylinder has a higher amplitude than the 1st cylinder as shown in fig 4 the oscillations of the two cylinders are still synchronized in frequency but are out of phase with a pad around 140 note that the value of pad is not used to distinguish pattern 1b from pattern 1a both of the patterns can have a constant pad of any value within the range 180 180 the instantaneous frequencies also show more variation than pattern 1a which means the oscillations are as stable as in pattern 1a an example can also be found in ding et al 2019 where the flow field is visualized fig 5 note that the spacing stiffness and damping ratio of the cfd simulation is the same with the experimental test in fig 4 but the reynolds number is different the oscillations are still synchronized but the amplitude of the 2nd cylinder is slightly higher than that of the 1st cylinder compared to the flow field of pattern 1a in fig 3 a major difference is that the wake vortices of the 1st cylinder do not shed in the gap region but shed behind the 2nd cylinder as can be seen in each phase of the cycle there is always a vortical band connecting the two cylinders the exciting force for the 1st cylinder is smaller than the 2nd cylinder because the shedding mainly occurs behind the 2nd cylinder 3 4 pattern 2a pattern 2 is a partially coupled pattern in which the cylinders may have more than one response frequency but the dominant frequencies are the same pattern 2 has two sub patterns in pattern 2a the 1st cylinder has only one oscillation frequency while the 2nd cylinder has more than one oscillating frequency as shown in fig 6 the dominant frequencies of the two cylinders are equal the time history of the 2nd cylinder shows beating which indicates that the cylinder oscillation has two close frequencies this is confirmed by the psd pad is periodically changing within a specific range according to the frequency difference this pattern implies that the 2nd cylinder is subjected to the influence of the upstream wake vortex shedding from the 1st cylinder and also to its own wake vortex shedding however due to the shielding effect the inflow velocity for the two cylinders are not the same hence the vortex shedding frequencies are not the same either the wake shedding of the 1st cylinder is much more powerful as can be seen from the power spectrum curve ding et al 2015 presented a cfd study on the fio of multiple cylinders one case is shown in fig 7 the beating displacement history implies that the 2nd cylinder has two frequencies the evolution of the flow field shows clearly that each of the cylinders has its own vortex shedding the first frequency of the 2nd cylinder comes from its own wake vortex shedding note that this frequency should be lower than that of the 1st cylinder due to the shielding effect as mentioned earlier meanwhile the 2nd cylinder is also under the impact of the vortices shed from the 1st cylinder which explains the source and nature of the second frequency conceptually there could be another pattern to match pattern 3 when the 1st cylinder having more than one frequency while the 2nd cylinder having only one however this phenomenon was not observed experimentally this is the case because the wake of the 2nd cylinder is too weak and too far away from the 1st cylinder to have an impact on the oscillation of the 1st cylinder without the 2nd cylinder being affected by the wake of the 1st cylinder 3 5 pattern 2b as shown in fig 8 pattern 2b occurs when both cylinders have more than one frequency but their dominant frequencies are the same this means that the vibration and the wake of the 2nd cylinder have a stronger influence on the 1st cylinder the influence on the 1st cylinder is due to the fluid structure interactions in the gap region specifically depending on the timing the upstream vortices hit the 2nd cylinder and whether those vortices wrap around the second cylinder or shed through the gap between the two cylinders the frequency of excitation changes creating a two frequency excitation for both cylinders the evolution of the flow field in one cycle was simulated with a 2d urans method by ding et al 2013 and is shown in fig 9 this is presented only for the purpose of visualization so the spacing and damping ratios differ from the experimental test both cylinders are oscillating with two frequencies according to the displacement histories and psd while the dominant frequencies are the same the 1st cylinder is at the same location in phase 1 t tn 1 0 112 and phase 8 t tn 1 2 081 however the shed vortices of the 1st cylinder in phase 8 have very different forms compared with that in phase 1 it is the presence of the 2nd cylinder periodically affecting the formation of the wake vortices of the 1st cylinder and thus affecting the hydrodynamic force and the oscillation of the 1st cylinder 3 6 pattern 3a pattern 3 is the decoupled pattern in which the two cylinders have different dominant frequencies pattern 3 also has two sub patterns as shown in fig 10 pattern 3a is very similar to pattern 2b but the distinction between patterns 3a and 2b is clear there is more than one frequency for each cylinder but the dominant frequencies are different compared to pattern 2b pattern 3a has a lower level weaker of coupling between the cylinders it implies that each cylinder s oscillation is controlled by its own vortex shedding even though affected by the other s thus this pattern is classified as the decoupled pattern 3 7 pattern 3b pattern 3b represents cases in which both cylinders have one frequency but the frequencies are not equal the frequency of the 1st cylinder is always higher than that of the 2nd as shown in fig 11 due to the shielding effect the inflow velocity for the 2nd cylinder is always lower than that of the 1st cylinder in the initial branch and the upper branch of viv the oscillating frequency is positively associated with the flow velocity therefore the frequency for the 2nd cylinder is unlikely to be higher than that of the 1st cylinder in these two branches on the other hand if the two cylinders are placed apart by more than 3 0d the 2nd cylinder would have very limited influence on the 1st cylinder the 1st cylinder would act like an isolated single cylinder it would enter galloping after the upper branch of viv no lower branch of viv was observed for a single ptc cylinder according to previous research by kim et al 2013 the oscillation frequencies of two tandem cylinders with ptc and variable spacings are provided in fig 12 in this pattern the oscillations of the two cylinders are fully de coupled the wake vortex shedding of each cylinder must be strong enough to take control of its own cylinder oscillation and make the interactions between the cylinders negligible no cases were identified experimentally where the 2nd cylinder had a higher frequency than the first this is expected because the 2nd cylinder usually has a lower inflow velocity due to the shielding effect therefore the vortex shedding frequency should also be lower than that of the 1st cylinder s according to the strouhal law for stationary cylinders 3 8 pattern 4a in pattern 4 only one of the two cylinders is oscillating while the other one remains practically stationary pattern 4a occurs when the 1st cylinder is oscillating while the 2nd cylinder s oscillation is negligible as illustrated in fig 13 this is mainly the case because the wake vortex shedding of the 1st cylinder drives the 1st cylinder to oscillate but suppresses the wake of the 2nd cylinder at the same time when the shedding directions are opposite note that in some cases the cylinders remain static because of the static coulomb friction force cfd results ding et al 2013 are shown in fig 14 note that the damping ratio of the cfd case is lower than that of the experimental case the oscillation of the 1st cylinder is much more intense than that of the 2nd cylinder the vortices shed from the 1st cylinder grab the wake vortex of the 2nd cylinder while passing by leaving the 2nd cylinder without circulation no obvious vortex street can be found behind the 2nd cylinder therefore the amplitude of the 2nd cylinder is nearly completely suppressed 3 9 pattern 4b pattern 4b is just the opposite of pattern 4a which can be seen in fig 15 the wake vortex shedding of the 1st cylinder is not strong enough to oscillate the 1st cylinder but it is strong enough to oscillate the 2nd cylinder when its vortex shedding is in phase 3 10 pattern 5 pattern 5 is different from the others as the oscillation mode shifts from one pattern to another the shifting occurs intermittently but not periodically from the perspective of nonlinear dynamics it indicates that a non linear phenomenon where more than one stable attractor exists an example is shown in fig 16 multiple variations have been observed stationary as shown in figs 18 20 most of the cases in the initial branch of viv are synchronized patterns interspersed with patterns 4a and 4b pattern 4b occurs because the wake vortex shedding behind the 2nd cylinder is too weak and slow due to shielding by the 1st cylinder the oscillation of the 2nd cylinder in this branch is completely controlled by the wake vortices from the 1st cylinder as the flow speed increases viv shifts to the upper branch when the vortex shedding mode changes from the 2s mode to 2p mode for the 1st cylinder williamson and roshko 1988 the decoupled patterns start to show when the wake vortices of the 2nd cylinder are strong enough and the vortex shedding frequency is high enough to get coupled with the natural frequency of the 2nd cylinder two oscillation frequencies exist in this region one is from the vortex shedding of the 1st cylinder and the other one is from the 2nd further increase of the flow velocity increases the strouhal frequency of the 1st cylinder becoming too high to remain coupled with the natural frequency then viv tends to cease or enter the lower branch while the viv of the 2nd cylinder is still in high intensity as shown in pattern 1b the oscillation of the 2nd cylinder can have a significant influence on the 1st cylinder where pattern 2b occurs as shown in fig 18 pattern 5 mainly occurs when x 0 d 1 57 in the transition region around re 8 75 104 and in galloping re 9 104 in the transition region both driving mechanisms of viv and galloping exist when the onset of galloping occurs before the end of the viv upper branch the oscillation shifts intermittently between the viv mode and the galloping mode once galloping is fully developed both of the cylinders are synchronized again pattern 5 still occurs in some cases in fully developed galloping it will be analyzed more specifically in the following section the occurrence of each pattern is summarized in fig 21 as can be seen pattern 1a is the 2 01 and 2 57 the major sub patterns are pattern 2a and pattern 3b in which the upstream cylinder has only one frequency this is the case because the influence of the downstream cylinder on the upstream cylinder diminishes as the spacing between the two cylinders widens 4 1 effect of parameters on fio energy to understand the coupling process in viv the relations between the cylinder oscillations are presented in fig 22 u 1 and u 2 represent the average inflow for the 1st and 2nd cylinder respectively y 1 and y 2 represent the cylinder motions w 1 and w 2 represent the wake vortex shedding interaction i j represents the interaction between the i th cylinder and the j th wake which includes the vortex force applied on the i th cylinder from the j th wake and also the disturbance of the vortices in wake j from the i th cylinder u 1 is the incoming flow velocity which is set by the channel u 2 is determined by u 1 the shielding effect of the 1st cylinder and the spacing between the cylinders longer spacing gives the flow more space to recover its velocity y 1 is controlled by the stiffness damping ratio and interaction1 1 from the wake vortex shedding w 1 here we neglect the direct effect from w 2 because of the distance w 1 is mainly the von kármán vortex street which is synchronized with the motion y 1 however it is also under the effect of y 2 y 2 is undergoing two interactions interaction2 1 and interaction2 2 interaction2 1 decreases with increasing spacing w 2 is synchronized with y 2 and also disturbed by w 1 such disturbances could be enhancing or suppressing depending on the frequency and phase values the effect of the disturbances decreases with increasing spacing as well the damping ratio ζ can affect the oscillation amplitude which leads to the changes in the shielding effect this can be observed in all of the cases in figs 19 and 20 when the spacing is 2 01 or 2 57 higher damping ratios narrow the partially coupled pattern 2 or decoupled pattern 3 regions which means that lower oscillation amplitudes cause a higher coupling level in viv the higher amplitudes of y 2 lead to stronger wake vortex shedding w 2 which makes it harder to be controlled by w 1 so the frequency component is more prominent than in the high damping low amplitude cases another possible reason is that the high amplitude of y 1 leads to a stronger shielding effect which means the u 2 is lower for the low damping cases and the vortex shedding frequency would be lower according to strouhal law therefore there could be a more significant difference between the vortex shedding frequencies of w 1 and w 2 and it would be more difficult for the motions to get coupled however the partially coupled and decoupled regions do not shrink with higher damping ratios at spacing 1 57 as shown in fig 18 that occurs mainly because the short gap distance leads to a minimal velocity recovery for u 2 due to the shielding effect the higher difference between u 1 and u 2 causes a more significant difference between the vortex shedding frequencies of w 1 and w 2 so it is too narrow in this particular spacing for the wakes to be synchronized regardless of the amplitudes of y 1 and y 2 in other cases with longer velocity recovery distances the difference between u 1 and u 2 would be smaller and it would also be easier for the cylinders to get coupled that is the reason why more synchronized patterns appear in figs 19 and 20 spring stiffness controls the natural frequency and then leads to the coupling level between y 1 and w 1 at a certain inflow velocity and the coupling level among w 1 y 2 and w 2 as well as the stiffness of the cylinders increases the oscillations tend to be fully coupled or synchronized as can be seen in figs 18 20 there are fewer decoupled patterns pattern 3 with the higher stiffness for all the spacing and damping ratios 4 2 oscillation patterns and converted hydrokinetic power the patterns are summarized based on their oscillational characteristics which is also the foundation of the power harnessing calculation in oscillations kinetic power exchanges between the cylinders and the fluid and spacing as shown in figs 18 20 when the amplitude is high the frequency is low and the spacing ratio is 1 57 the oscillation shifts between two different scenarios without any apparent change in external flow conditions the pattern is a manifestation of the nonlinearity of the oscillations from the nonlinear dynamic point of view there are multiple stable limit oscillation cycles lco and the lcos are close to each other small perturbations can lead the motion trajectory from one lco to another lco taking the case in fig 16 for example the phase difference between the motions is 180 for the first 14 s the cylinders are oscillating perfectly out of phase the amplitude of the 1st cylinder is higher than that of the 2nd cylinder then the 1st cylinder starts oscillating slower and the 2nd cylinder starts oscillating faster the pad keeps dropping for the next 30 s during which the 1st cylinder oscillates one and a half cycles more than the 2nd cylinder the two cylinders oscillate in phase from the 44th second until the end of the recording in this case there are at least two stable lcos one is the out of phase mode in the first 14 s and the other one is the in phase mode in the last 14 s the middle period can also be a stable stage similar to pattern 3b or just the transition path between the two obvious attractors there are other types of pattern 5 being observed some of them are selected and presented in fig 24 they all share five obvious similarities 1 during the shift the instantaneous frequency changes 2 during the shift the 1st cylinder s frequency is reduced oscillating slower and the 2nd cylinder s frequency increases oscillating faster 3 pad shifts always by about 180 4 the oscillations of the cylinders change simultaneously 5 the shifts cause changes to the energy harnessing power they also exhibit some different characteristics 1 there are two shifting processes one being instantaneous and the other very slow as shown in fig 16 the process starts from the 15th second and ends at the 44th second it takes 29 s or 48 of the sampling time 60 s however it takes only 5 s for the oscillation mode to change from out of phase mode to in phase mode in the case of fig 24 a 2 the vibration shifts from in phase mode to out of phase mode within 3 s in fig 24 b it is only 8 or 5 of the sampling time the shift can be unidirectional or bidirectional according to the pad in fig 24 c and d in the current research the fio patterns of two ptc cylinder in tandem are classified based on displacement and frequency measurements other dynamical characteristics i e the hydrodynamic force and the phase shift between force and displacement contain additional information to reveal the underlying mechanics further flow field analysis including vortex patterns and shear layer stability may be helpful in explaining the underlying mechanism for each pattern they all deserve further investigation in the future 6 conclusions the oscillation patterns for two tandem placed cylinders with turbulence stimulation in the form of selective roughness were identified and classified in this study the classification method and the characteristics of each pattern were presented the occurrence of each pattern was explained based on the interaction between cylinder motion and timing of vortices interfering with the 2nd cylinder or its shear layers or its wake 1 in the viv region the oscillations of the two cylinders mainly have three coupling levels fully synchronized partially coupled and fully decoupled depending on the fluid structure interaction among the two cylinders and the two wake vortex shedding the synchronized mode occurs when both cylinders are dominated by the wake of the upstream cylinder the partially coupled and fully decoupled modes occur when the wake of the downstream cylinder is strong enough to affect or dominate the oscillation of the 2nd cylinder in viv as the flow speed increases oscillation mode changes from fully synchronized to partially coupled and then fully decoupled 2 some key phenomena are observed especially on how the downstream cylinder is affecting the upstream cylinder in the viv region this occurs when the inflow velocity is beyond the region of the viv of the 1st cylinder but the 2nd cylinder is still in viv due to the shielding effect the oscillation of the 2nd cylinder periodically perturbs the wake of the 1st cylinder and gives the upstream cylinder another frequency 3 the system parameters including cylinder spacing spring stiffness and damping ratio are playing important roles in the fio patterns generally speaking higher damping ratio and higher stiffness make it easier for the two cylinders to synchronize the motions of the cylinders tend to decouple with lower damping ratio and lower stiffness especially when the wake vortex shedding frequency of the 2nd cylinder approaches the natural frequency in 5 104 re 8 105 4 nonlinear behavior occurs in the galloping region multiple attractors exist in galloping which leads to pattern shifting some crucial factors deserve further investigation such as the shielding effect and the velocity recovery behind
