the oscillation patterns of two 1 dof cylinder oscillators undergoing viv and galloping are investigated in a free surface water channel for 3 2 104 re 1 2 105 the cylinders are arranged in tandem and supported by springs for a range of different spring stiffness and damping parameters the efficiency of a current energy converter cec based on flow induced oscillation fio of multiple cylinders in tandem is critically related to the cylinder oscillation patterns due to the limited number of studies on the fio for multiple cylindrical or prismatic bodies their oscillation patterns have neither been identified nor classified the surfaces of the cylinders are modified by turbulence stimulation to enhance fio three different center to center spacing five stiffness and six damping ratios for a total of 90 sets of experiments were conducted the current velocity range is from 0 34 m s to 1 32 m s from more than 2000 tests five major patterns nine sub patterns are identified and classified the patterns are defined based on the amplitudes frequencies and the phase angle differences between the two cylinders the characteristics and mechanics of each oscillation pattern are explored and explained from the perspective of fluid structure interaction fsi by systematically varying the parameters the underlying hydrodynamic mechanisms including the coupling level between vortices and cylinders the shielding effect the wake effect and the stability states are revealed few preliminary observations on the connection between oscillation pattern and harnessed power by the tandem cylinders are reported keywords hydrokinetic energy harnessing flow induced oscillation vortex induced vibration galloping tandem cylinders synergistic oscillation patterns 1 introduction flow induced oscillation fio is a phenomenon that occurs with flexible or elastically supported cylindrical prismatic structures in a fluid stream vortex induced vibration viv and galloping are the two most common fio for elongated bodies with bluff cross sections in currents viv is mainly induced by the wake vortex shedding while galloping is due to the instability of a shear layer fios of circular cylinders are widely studied because of the extensive engineering applications underwater and in air comprehensive reviews of viv were published by bearman 1984 and williamson and govardhan 2004 galloping does not occur with smooth circular cylinders in a uniform flow asymmetry is required for galloping and it may be caused by body geometry or flow thus studies on galloping are on non circular cylinders and prisms park et al 2013 ding et al 2015 mannini et al 2014 or on cylinders in nonuniform flows hover and triantafyllou 2001 the marine renewable energy laboratory mrelab developed a turbulence stimulation method labeled passive turbulence control ptc to destabilize a shear layer and trigger galloping for single or multiple circular cylinders using selective surface roughness distribution bernitsas et al 2008 park et al 2011 a map of ptc to fio was developed to reveal the effect of the roughness distribution on the dynamic response of circular cylinders in uniform flow this map is a guide for fio enhancement for harnessing marine hydrodynamic energy park et al 2013 2017 in fied testing the effect of ptc was achieved by adding locally metal sheet layers without surface roughness along with anti fouling coating marine fouling was prevented the fio characteristics change substantially when there are multiple cylinders in the flow because there are more factors affecting the fluid structure interaction the vortex shedding timing and the transition path of the vortices are changed by the presence of other cylinders shed vortices may also merge counteract or shift to other forms during or following shedding the spacing between the cylinders is the most crucial factor which greatly affects the vortex shedding behavior and the pressure distribution around cylinders igarashi 1981 classified two regimes for two stationary cylinders in tandem according to whether von kármán vortex streets are generated between the two cylinders zdravkovich 1985 1977 analyzed the vortex behavior more comprehensively and presented a map of vortex shedding modes for two cylinders placed side by side in tandem and in staggered arrangements with various spacing assi et al 2006 2010 2013 performed a series of experiments on the wake induced vibration wiv of a cylinder on springs in the wake of a fixed cylinder wiv did not only build up a higher oscillation amplitude than the viv of a single isolated cylinder but also sustained it when the vortex shedding frequency from the upstream cylinder was far higher than the natural frequency of the downstream cylinder it was suggested that the oscillation of the downstream cylinder was dominated by the unsteady vortex structure interactions rather than the resonance of the oscillation and vortex shedding as in viv assi et al 2013 also presented the concept of wake stiffness in which the wake vortices from the upstream cylinder has an effect similar to a linear spring on the oscillation of the downstream cylinder even if the structural springs were removed the wake spring effect was validated within a range of amplitude of oscillation in most of the fio viv and galloping scenarios with a single oscillating cylinder the oscillation is sinusoidal with only one dominant oscillation frequency when both tandem placed cylinders are oscillating the interactions are more complex because the upstream cylinder is not only affecting the downstream cylinder but is also being affected by the mutual interaction xu et al 2019 kim et al 2009 investigated fio of two circular cylinders in tandem with different spacing values response was classified in five different regimes with qualitatively different response the oscillation of the upstream cylinder was observed to be suppressed by the fixed downstream cylinder in regime iv while the downstream cylinder is independent on the upstream cylinder in other regimes the fio of the upstream cylinder has a strong influence on the downstream cylinder the inflow velocity for the downstream cylinder is always slower than that of the upstream cylinder due to the blockage of the upstream cylinder as a result the wake vortex shedding frequencies for the two cylinders are always different in viv according to the strouhal law st f s d c u where st is strouhal number f s is the vortex shedding frequency for a stationary cylinder d c is the characteristic dimension perpendicular to the flow and u is the inflow velocity the vortices shed from the two cylinders can either work together to enhance the oscillation or work against each other to suppress the oscillation this depends on the interaction of the vortices and the motions of the cylinders which depend on the oscillator parameters i e spring stiffness damping ratio spacing between cylinders and flow speed mahbub alam and zhou 2007 studied the phase lag between the vortex shedding with the lift force with various cross sections when 4 7 104 re 6 5 104 an empirical equation was derived to relate the phase lag with strouhal number center to center spacing and the minimum spacing at which the vortices can shed in the gap qin et al 2019 systematically examined how vortex behavior including reattachment detachment rolling up and shedding affect the fio characteristics of two cylinders in tandem within the approximate range of 5 103 re 6 104 fan et al 2020b 2020a investigated the fio mode of a more complicated system which has three 2 dof cylinders placed in tandem by both wind tunnel experiments and cfd simulations four regimes were classified according to the fio mode and spacing with a reynolds number range of 3 1 103 re 6 2 104 they also proposed four wake interference criteria based on velocities wake induced galloping was observed in cfd results galloping is not triggered by the wake vortex shedding but the instability of the shear layer as a highly non linear phenomenon galloping of a two cylinder system shows more attractors in the current study which were not identified in previous studies the underlying mechanism of fluid structure interactions can be explored by studying the oscillation patterns the pattern characteristics can provide a better understanding when designing the system parameters of structures in water or air flows that would help in stabilizing structures prone to fio either for suppression as in risers or for enhancement to improve the performance of hydrokinetic energy converters the fio characteristics of two elastically supported cylinders in tandem were systematically investigated by the mrelab experimentally computationally and analytically to optimize the performance of the vivace converter developed by bernitsas et al 2008 ptc introduced by park et al 2011 was applied by lan et al 2018 who identified three oscillation patterns of two cylinders in viv and galloping with a combination of stiffness and damping ratio this was based on phase lag between the motion of two cylinders in tandem namely the in phase pattern the out of phase pattern and the continuously changing pattern between the two sun et al 2017 experimentally tested the energy harnessing performance of two cylinders in tandem with center to center spacing ratio 1 57 x 0 d 2 57 spring stiffness 400 n m k 1200 n m and total damping ratio from 0 02 ζ 0 26 in the present study the tests in the research by sun et al 2017 for hydrokinetic energy harnessing are analyzed from a hydrodynamic perspective more patterns are observed than the previous study of lan et al 2018 with an improved classification method which is based on the coupling level of the oscillations of the two cylinders the details of the experimental set up are presented in section 2 the pattern classification method is introduced in section 3 in section 4 maps of the oscillation patterns vs damping ratio ζ and reynolds number re are presented a flow chart describing the fluid structure interaction process is proposed to understand the mutual effect between the cylinders and explain the causes for each pattern from the perspective of hydrodynamics some special cases are studied specifically in this section and conclusions are summarized at the end 2 experiment set up all tests were performed in the low turbulence free surface water ltfsw channel in the mrelab of the university of michigan fig 1 a the test section is 1 0 m in width 1 52 m in depth and 2 44 m in length 37 85 m3 of water is circulating in the channel with a maximum speed of 1 35 m s the water temperature was maintained around 19 5 c the water depth at the test section was 1 17 m for the present study the inflow velocity ranges from 0 34 m s to 1 35 m s and a 0 04 m s interval was used taking the diameter of the cylinder d 0 0889 m as the characteristic dimension the reynolds number range is 3 2 104 re 1 2 105 the test models are two aluminum circular cylinders modified with ptc strips for turbulence simulation as shown in fig 1 b two strips are applied to each cylinder covering the surface from 20 to 36 with respect to the forward stagnation point which was previously studied extensively as the best choice for harnessing energy in galloping sun et al 2017 the system parameters are presented in table 1 the cylinders are supported by two end springs emulated by the vck controller in order to achieve the desired stiffness and damping ratio the cylinder is constrained to move in the crossflow direction only as shown in fig 1 c the system calibration method for designing and implementing a no bias controller called vck system can be found in previous work by sun et al 2015 the displacement signal of each cylinder is recorded by the encoder of the servo motor with a resolution of less than 0 0001 m according to previous research the 2nd cylinder would have very limited influence on the 1st cylinder for spacing x 0 d 3 0 which means that the 1st cylinder would act like an isolated single cylinder kim et al 2013 kim and bernitsas 2016 the oscillation pattern of the 1st cylinder would not be affected by the 2nd cylinder in that situation it is more like a problem of the downstream cylinder s oscillation pattern under different kinds of perturbation from the wake of the upstream cylinder i e wake induced vibration rather than the interactive fio pattern studied in this paper this paper is aimed at understanding the synergy of two cylinders in flow induced oscillations thus the spacing range selected in this research is relatively narrow 90 sets of tests were involved in this study with three parameters including 3 center to center spacing values x 0 d 1 57 2 01 2 57 5 stiffness values k 400 n m 600 n m 800 n m 1000 n m 1200 n m and 6 total damping ratios ζ 0 06 0 10 0 14 0 18 0 22 0 26 for each of the ninety sets of tests about 25 velocity values were tested note that the stiffness and damping ratio for both cylinders are identical during each set of tests a detailed analysis of the test measurements can be found in sun et al 2017 3 pattern classification 3 1 classification method cylinder oscillation especially monochromatic is quantified by its amplitude and frequency in the case of two cylinders their relative position is important to illustrate and understand the fio mechanism the phase angle difference pad between the two cylinders defines their relative position pad is defined as the angular degree of the instantaneous position of the upstream 1st cylinder y 1 t leading that of the downstream 2nd cylinder y 2 t as shown in equation 1 where y 1 t and y 2 t represent the hilbert transform projection of y 1 t and y 2 t respectively 1 pad α 1 α 2 y 1 t y 2 t y 2 t y 1 t y 1 t y 2 t y 1 t y 2 t besides pad other tools used to illustrate the properties of the various response patterns are a the power spectral density calculated by discrete fourier transform dft to present the overall frequency content of a signal b the instantaneous frequency for each cycle calculated to show how the oscillation pattern shifts from one stage to the other within the same experiment huang et al 2009 huang and shen 2014 c the instantaneous frequency normalized by the natural frequency in vacuo d the instantaneous power calculated according to equation 2 where p harness i t is the instantaneous harnessing power c harness is the harnessing damping coefficient ẏ i t is the instantaneous oscillating velocity of the cylinder the derivation of equation 2 can be found in previous papers sun et al 2016 sun and bernitsas 2019 2 p h a r n e s s i t c h a r n e s s y i t y i t suffice to mention here that in the classical linear oscillator model with linear viscous damping the instantaneous damping force is c h a r n e s s y i t when multiplied by the oscillating cylinder velocity y i t it yields the instantaneous power in oscillating cylinder e p harness shows the power harnessing ability of a vivace converter in each pattern and stage f the phase diagram is used to understand the non linear behavior of the oscillating cylinders based on all the parameters mentioned above five major patterns for a total of nine sub patterns are identified the properties of each pattern are shown in figs 2 16 with a summary table in fig 17 3 2 pattern 1a pattern 1 is the fully synchronized pattern in which the fio s of the two cylinders have the same and only one frequency there are two sub patterns for pattern 1 patten 1a is the most common pattern in the tests as shown in fig 2 the oscillations of the two cylinders are synchronized in frequency the psd shows that both cylinders appear to have monochromatic responses with minimal variation in the instantaneous frequency as a function of time thus the time histories of both cylinders appear to be sinusoidal the two motions are also in phase the cycle to cycle frequencies of the two cylinders are nearly constant and equal the phase angle difference between the oscillations of the cylinders is also constant in the current case the pad is about 0 but it can be any constant in other cases for pattern 1 in this case the 1st upstream cylinder has a higher oscillation amplitude than that of the 2nd downstream cylinder detailed results can be found in sun et al 2017 for the amplitude ratio frequency harnessed power and efficiency ding et al 2019 conducted numerical simulations to explore the fsi mechanisms of a two cylinder vivace the flow field and dynamical response of a typical pattern 1a are shown in fig 3 the oscillations and the lift force of the two cylinders are synchronized in frequency with a 20⁰ pad the vortices shed from the upper lower side of the 1st cylinder touch the corresponding side of the 2nd cylinder and merge with the wake vortices of the 2nd cylinder as a consequence there is only one vortex street behind the two cylinders there is no independent wake shedding from the 2nd cylinder in this scenario the oscillations of the two cylinders are both controlled by the vortices shed from the 1st cylinder 3 3 pattern 1b pattern 1b is similar to pattern 1 but the 2nd cylinder has a higher amplitude than the 1st cylinder as shown in fig 4 the oscillations of the two cylinders are still synchronized in frequency but are out of phase with a pad around 140 note that the value of pad is not used to distinguish pattern 1b from pattern 1a both of the patterns can have a constant pad of any value within the range 180 180 the instantaneous frequencies also show more variation than pattern 1a which means the oscillations are as stable as in pattern 1a an example can also be found in ding et al 2019 where the flow field is visualized fig 5 note that the spacing stiffness and damping ratio of the cfd simulation is the same with the experimental test in fig 4 but the reynolds number is different the oscillations are still synchronized but the amplitude of the 2nd cylinder is slightly higher than that of the 1st cylinder compared to the flow field of pattern 1a in fig 3 a major difference is that the wake vortices of the 1st cylinder do not shed in the gap region but shed behind the 2nd cylinder as can be seen in each phase of the cycle there is always a vortical band connecting the two cylinders the exciting force for the 1st cylinder is smaller than the 2nd cylinder because the shedding mainly occurs behind the 2nd cylinder 3 4 pattern 2a pattern 2 is a partially coupled pattern in which the cylinders may have more than one response frequency but the dominant frequencies are the same pattern 2 has two sub patterns in pattern 2a the 1st cylinder has only one oscillation frequency while the 2nd cylinder has more than one oscillating frequency as shown in fig 6 the dominant frequencies of the two cylinders are equal the time history of the 2nd cylinder shows beating which indicates that the cylinder oscillation has two close frequencies this is confirmed by the psd pad is periodically changing within a specific range according to the frequency difference this pattern implies that the 2nd cylinder is subjected to the influence of the upstream wake vortex shedding from the 1st cylinder and also to its own wake vortex shedding however due to the shielding effect the inflow velocity for the two cylinders are not the same hence the vortex shedding frequencies are not the same either the wake shedding of the 1st cylinder is much more powerful as can be seen from the power spectrum curve ding et al 2015 presented a cfd study on the fio of multiple cylinders one case is shown in fig 7 the beating displacement history implies that the 2nd cylinder has two frequencies the evolution of the flow field shows clearly that each of the cylinders has its own vortex shedding the first frequency of the 2nd cylinder comes from its own wake vortex shedding note that this frequency should be lower than that of the 1st cylinder due to the shielding effect as mentioned earlier meanwhile the 2nd cylinder is also under the impact of the vortices shed from the 1st cylinder which explains the source and nature of the second frequency conceptually there could be another pattern to match pattern 3 when the 1st cylinder having more than one frequency while the 2nd cylinder having only one however this phenomenon was not observed experimentally this is the case because the wake of the 2nd cylinder is too weak and too far away from the 1st cylinder to have an impact on the oscillation of the 1st cylinder without the 2nd cylinder being affected by the wake of the 1st cylinder 3 5 pattern 2b as shown in fig 8 pattern 2b occurs when both cylinders have more than one frequency but their dominant frequencies are the same this means that the vibration and the wake of the 2nd cylinder have a stronger influence on the 1st cylinder the influence on the 1st cylinder is due to the fluid structure interactions in the gap region specifically depending on the timing the upstream vortices hit the 2nd cylinder and whether those vortices wrap around the second cylinder or shed through the gap between the two cylinders the frequency of excitation changes creating a two frequency excitation for both cylinders the evolution of the flow field in one cycle was simulated with a 2d urans method by ding et al 2013 and is shown in fig 9 this is presented only for the purpose of visualization so the spacing and damping ratios differ from the experimental test both cylinders are oscillating with two frequencies according to the displacement histories and psd while the dominant frequencies are the same the 1st cylinder is at the same location in phase 1 t tn 1 0 112 and phase 8 t tn 1 2 081 however the shed vortices of the 1st cylinder in phase 8 have very different forms compared with that in phase 1 it is the presence of the 2nd cylinder periodically affecting the formation of the wake vortices of the 1st cylinder and thus affecting the hydrodynamic force and the oscillation of the 1st cylinder 3 6 pattern 3a pattern 3 is the decoupled pattern in which the two cylinders have different dominant frequencies pattern 3 also has two sub patterns as shown in fig 10 pattern 3a is very similar to pattern 2b but the distinction between patterns 3a and 2b is clear there is more than one frequency for each cylinder but the dominant frequencies are different compared to pattern 2b pattern 3a has a lower level weaker of coupling between the cylinders it implies that each cylinder s oscillation is controlled by its own vortex shedding even though affected by the other s thus this pattern is classified as the decoupled pattern 3 7 pattern 3b pattern 3b represents cases in which both cylinders have one frequency but the frequencies are not equal the frequency of the 1st cylinder is always higher than that of the 2nd as shown in fig 11 due to the shielding effect the inflow velocity for the 2nd cylinder is always lower than that of the 1st cylinder in the initial branch and the upper branch of viv the oscillating frequency is positively associated with the flow velocity therefore the frequency for the 2nd cylinder is unlikely to be higher than that of the 1st cylinder in these two branches on the other hand if the two cylinders are placed apart by more than 3 0d the 2nd cylinder would have very limited influence on the 1st cylinder the 1st cylinder would act like an isolated single cylinder it would enter galloping after the upper branch of viv no lower branch of viv was observed for a single ptc cylinder according to previous research by kim et al 2013 the oscillation frequencies of two tandem cylinders with ptc and variable spacings are provided in fig 12 in this pattern the oscillations of the two cylinders are fully de coupled the wake vortex shedding of each cylinder must be strong enough to take control of its own cylinder oscillation and make the interactions between the cylinders negligible no cases were identified experimentally where the 2nd cylinder had a higher frequency than the first this is expected because the 2nd cylinder usually has a lower inflow velocity due to the shielding effect therefore the vortex shedding frequency should also be lower than that of the 1st cylinder s according to the strouhal law for stationary cylinders 3 8 pattern 4a in pattern 4 only one of the two cylinders is oscillating while the other one remains practically stationary pattern 4a occurs when the 1st cylinder is oscillating while the 2nd cylinder s oscillation is negligible as illustrated in fig 13 this is mainly the case because the wake vortex shedding of the 1st cylinder drives the 1st cylinder to oscillate but suppresses the wake of the 2nd cylinder at the same time when the shedding directions are opposite note that in some cases the cylinders remain static because of the static coulomb friction force cfd results ding et al 2013 are shown in fig 14 note that the damping ratio of the cfd case is lower than that of the experimental case the oscillation of the 1st cylinder is much more intense than that of the 2nd cylinder the vortices shed from the 1st cylinder grab the wake vortex of the 2nd cylinder while passing by leaving the 2nd cylinder without circulation no obvious vortex street can be found behind the 2nd cylinder therefore the amplitude of the 2nd cylinder is nearly completely suppressed 3 9 pattern 4b pattern 4b is just the opposite of pattern 4a which can be seen in fig 15 the wake vortex shedding of the 1st cylinder is not strong enough to oscillate the 1st cylinder but it is strong enough to oscillate the 2nd cylinder when its vortex shedding is in phase 3 10 pattern 5 pattern 5 is different from the others as the oscillation mode shifts from one pattern to another the shifting occurs intermittently but not periodically from the perspective of nonlinear dynamics it indicates that a non linear phenomenon where more than one stable attractor exists an example is shown in fig 16 multiple variations have been observed experimentally and computationally ding et al 2013 2016 3 11 summary the identification method and the characteristics of each pattern are summarized in table 2 a1 and a2 represent the oscillation frequency for each cylinder when there is more than one frequency fi j i j 1 2 is the j th most prominent frequency of the i th cylinder the hydrodynamic mechanisms are summarized in table 3 y 1 and y 2 represent the cylinder motions w 1 and w 2 represent the wake vortex shedding of the upstream and downstream cylinder respectively a summary of the dynamic characteristics of all the patterns is plotted in fig 17 for easy comparison 4 maps of patterns vs ζ re in fio regions fifteen maps of the patterns are presented in figs 18 20 for the three tandem spacing and the five spring stiffness values tested the patterns are mapped on the damping ratio reynolds number domain ζ re noted that in galloping only patterns 1 and 5 exist and all the other patterns occur in viv and transition so the viv patterns are investigated first three colors are used to indicate the coupling level of the motions of the tandem cylinders a green labels indicate fully synchronized motions in patterns 1 and 5 b yellow labels indicate pattern2 in which the coupling between the cylinders is still dominant but other factors play part in the motions c blue labels indicate pattern 3 in which the coupling is not dominant anymore or even the motions may be decoupled d red labels indicate pattern 4 which describes the scenarios where only one of the cylinders is oscillating while the other one is practically stationary as shown in figs 18 20 most of the cases in the initial branch of viv are synchronized patterns interspersed with patterns 4a and 4b pattern 4b occurs because the wake vortex shedding behind the 2nd cylinder is too weak and slow due to shielding by the 1st cylinder the oscillation of the 2nd cylinder in this branch is completely controlled by the wake vortices from the 1st cylinder as the flow speed increases viv shifts to the upper branch when the vortex shedding mode changes from the 2s mode to 2p mode for the 1st cylinder williamson and roshko 1988 the decoupled patterns start to show when the wake vortices of the 2nd cylinder are strong enough and the vortex shedding frequency is high enough to get coupled with the natural frequency of the 2nd cylinder two oscillation frequencies exist in this region one is from the vortex shedding of the 1st cylinder and the other one is from the 2nd further increase of the flow velocity increases the strouhal frequency of the 1st cylinder becoming too high to remain coupled with the natural frequency then viv tends to cease or enter the lower branch while the viv of the 2nd cylinder is still in high intensity as shown in pattern 1b the oscillation of the 2nd cylinder can have a significant influence on the 1st cylinder where pattern 2b occurs as shown in fig 18 pattern 5 mainly occurs when x 0 d 1 57 in the transition region around re 8 75 104 and in galloping re 9 104 in the transition region both driving mechanisms of viv and galloping exist when the onset of galloping occurs before the end of the viv upper branch the oscillation shifts intermittently between the viv mode and the galloping mode once galloping is fully developed both of the cylinders are synchronized again pattern 5 still occurs in some cases in fully developed galloping it will be analyzed more specifically in the following section the occurrence of each pattern is summarized in fig 21 as can be seen pattern 1a is the most common pattern at all three spacings tested the percentage of pattern 1 increases with x0 d while the sub pattern 1b decreases this means that as the spacing becomes wider it is easier for the two cylinders to synchronize but the amplitude of the 2nd cylinder can hardly be higher than that of the 1st cylinder the proportions of pattern 4 and pattern 5 decrease with x0 d the overall percentage of patterns 2 and 3 does not change significantly with x0 d when x0 d 1 57 the major sub patterns are pattern 2b and pattern 3a in which the upstream cylinder has two frequencies when x0 d 2 01 and 2 57 the major sub patterns are pattern 2a and pattern 3b in which the upstream cylinder has only one frequency this is the case because the influence of the downstream cylinder on the upstream cylinder diminishes as the spacing between the two cylinders widens 4 1 effect of parameters on fio energy to understand the coupling process in viv the relations between the cylinder oscillations are presented in fig 22 u 1 and u 2 represent the average inflow for the 1st and 2nd cylinder respectively y 1 and y 2 represent the cylinder motions w 1 and w 2 represent the wake vortex shedding interaction i j represents the interaction between the i th cylinder and the j th wake which includes the vortex force applied on the i th cylinder from the j th wake and also the disturbance of the vortices in wake j from the i th cylinder u 1 is the incoming flow velocity which is set by the channel u 2 is determined by u 1 the shielding effect of the 1st cylinder and the spacing between the cylinders longer spacing gives the flow more space to recover its velocity y 1 is controlled by the stiffness damping ratio and interaction1 1 from the wake vortex shedding w 1 here we neglect the direct effect from w 2 because of the distance w 1 is mainly the von kármán vortex street which is synchronized with the motion y 1 however it is also under the effect of y 2 y 2 is undergoing two interactions interaction2 1 and interaction2 2 interaction2 1 decreases with increasing spacing w 2 is synchronized with y 2 and also disturbed by w 1 such disturbances could be enhancing or suppressing depending on the frequency and phase values the effect of the disturbances decreases with increasing spacing as well the damping ratio ζ can affect the oscillation amplitude which leads to the changes in the shielding effect this can be observed in all of the cases in figs 19 and 20 when the spacing is 2 01 or 2 57 higher damping ratios narrow the partially coupled pattern 2 or decoupled pattern 3 regions which means that lower oscillation amplitudes cause a higher coupling level in viv the higher amplitudes of y 2 lead to stronger wake vortex shedding w 2 which makes it harder to be controlled by w 1 so the frequency component is more prominent than in the high damping low amplitude cases another possible reason is that the high amplitude of y 1 leads to a stronger shielding effect which means the u 2 is lower for the low damping cases and the vortex shedding frequency would be lower according to strouhal law therefore there could be a more significant difference between the vortex shedding frequencies of w 1 and w 2 and it would be more difficult for the motions to get coupled however the partially coupled and decoupled regions do not shrink with higher damping ratios at spacing 1 57 as shown in fig 18 that occurs mainly because the short gap distance leads to a minimal velocity recovery for u 2 due to the shielding effect the higher difference between u 1 and u 2 causes a more significant difference between the vortex shedding frequencies of w 1 and w 2 so it is too narrow in this particular spacing for the wakes to be synchronized regardless of the amplitudes of y 1 and y 2 in other cases with longer velocity recovery distances the difference between u 1 and u 2 would be smaller and it would also be easier for the cylinders to get coupled that is the reason why more synchronized patterns appear in figs 19 and 20 spring stiffness controls the natural frequency and then leads to the coupling level between y 1 and w 1 at a certain inflow velocity and the coupling level among w 1 y 2 and w 2 as well as the stiffness of the cylinders increases the oscillations tend to be fully coupled or synchronized as can be seen in figs 18 20 there are fewer decoupled patterns pattern 3 with the higher stiffness for all the spacing and damping ratios 4 2 oscillation patterns and converted hydrokinetic power the patterns are summarized based on their oscillational characteristics which is also the foundation of the power harnessing calculation in oscillations kinetic power exchanges between the cylinders and the fluid it is reasonable to expect that there may exist a relationship between patterns and power in the oscillator fig 23 shows the energy harnessing power related to the patterns the colors in the graph represent the different coupling level four cases are selected for each spacing to represent the low stiffness low damping cases the low stiffness high damping cases the high stiffness low damping cases and the high stiffness high damping cases regardless in all the tandem cylinder tests the harnessed energy of the upstream cylinder increases significantly compared to the isolated cylinder c since f i n t e r a c t i o n 1 1 monotonically increases before or at the beginning of viv it is easy to understand that pattern 4b can only occur at the lowest velocity of each set of tests if f i n t e r a c t i o n 1 1 is high enough to drive y 1 at a certain velocity then it should also be able to drive it at higher velocities in most of the cases pattern 4b is followed by pattern 1a which means the cylinders are synchronized however as the inflow velocity u 1 increases a little this synchronization is broken w 1 is no longer helping w 2 to drive y 2 and they even work against each other so that the amplitude of the total hydrodynamic force is lower than that of the static coulomb friction force and pattern 4a appears this trend should also work for the cases with spacing equal to 2 01 however no pattern 4b is recorded it is speculated that the test range was not wide or fine enough to reveal pattern 4b 4 3 2 phase shift phenomena pattern 5 pattern 5 mostly occurs at low k ζ and spacing as shown in figs 18 20 when the amplitude is high the frequency is low and the spacing ratio is 1 57 the oscillation shifts between two different scenarios without any apparent change in external flow conditions the pattern is a manifestation of the nonlinearity of the oscillations from the nonlinear dynamic point of view there are multiple stable limit oscillation cycles lco and the lcos are close to each other small perturbations can lead the motion trajectory from one lco to another lco taking the case in fig 16 for example the phase difference between the motions is 180 for the first 14 s the cylinders are oscillating perfectly out of phase the amplitude of the 1st cylinder is higher than that of the 2nd cylinder then the 1st cylinder starts oscillating slower and the 2nd cylinder starts oscillating faster the pad keeps dropping for the next 30 s during which the 1st cylinder oscillates one and a half cycles more than the 2nd cylinder the two cylinders oscillate in phase from the 44th second until the end of the recording in this case there are at least two stable lcos one is the out of phase mode in the first 14 s and the other one is the in phase mode in the last 14 s the middle period can also be a stable stage similar to pattern 3b or just the transition path between the two obvious attractors there are other types of pattern 5 being observed some of them are selected and presented in fig 24 they all share five obvious similarities 1 during the shift the instantaneous frequency changes 2 during the shift the 1st cylinder s frequency is reduced oscillating slower and the 2nd cylinder s frequency increases oscillating faster 3 pad shifts always by about 180 4 the oscillations of the cylinders change simultaneously 5 the shifts cause changes to the energy harnessing power they also exhibit some different characteristics 1 there are two shifting processes one being instantaneous and the other very slow as shown in fig 16 the process starts from the 15th second and ends at the 44th second it takes 29 s or 48 of the sampling time 60 s however it takes only 5 s for the oscillation mode to change from out of phase mode to in phase mode in the case of fig 24 a 2 the vibration shifts from in phase mode to out of phase mode within 3 s in fig 24 b it is only 8 or 5 of the sampling time the shift can be unidirectional or bidirectional according to the pad in fig 24 c and d in the current research the fio patterns of two ptc cylinder in tandem are classified based on displacement and frequency measurements other dynamical characteristics i e the hydrodynamic force and the phase shift between force and displacement contain additional information to reveal the underlying mechanics further flow field analysis including vortex patterns and shear layer stability may be helpful in explaining the underlying mechanism for each pattern they all deserve further investigation in the future 6 conclusions the oscillation patterns for two tandem placed cylinders with turbulence stimulation in the form of selective roughness were identified and classified in this study the classification method and the characteristics of each pattern were presented the occurrence of each pattern was explained based on the interaction between cylinder motion and timing of vortices interfering with the 2nd cylinder or its shear layers or its wake 1 in the viv region the oscillations of the two cylinders mainly have three coupling levels fully synchronized partially coupled and fully decoupled depending on the fluid structure interaction among the two cylinders and the two wake vortex shedding the synchronized mode occurs when both cylinders are dominated by the wake of the upstream cylinder the partially coupled and fully decoupled modes occur when the wake of the downstream cylinder is strong enough to affect or dominate the oscillation of the 2nd cylinder in viv as the flow speed increases oscillation mode changes from fully synchronized to partially coupled and then fully decoupled 2 some key phenomena are observed especially on how the downstream cylinder is affecting the upstream cylinder in the viv region this occurs when the inflow velocity is beyond the region of the viv of the 1st cylinder but the 2nd cylinder is still in viv due to the shielding effect the oscillation of the 2nd cylinder periodically perturbs the wake of the 1st cylinder and gives the upstream cylinder another frequency 3 the system parameters including cylinder spacing spring stiffness and damping ratio are playing important roles in the fio patterns generally speaking higher damping ratio and higher stiffness make it easier for the two cylinders to synchronize the motions of the cylinders tend to decouple with lower damping ratio and lower stiffness especially when the wake vortex shedding frequency of the 2nd cylinder approaches the natural frequency in 5 104 re 8 105 4 nonlinear behavior occurs in the galloping region multiple attractors exist in galloping which leads to pattern shifting some crucial factors deserve further investigation such as the shielding effect and the velocity recovery behind
